After calculating your business income and business expenses, you are ready to calculate your net profit or net loss from business activities. You do this by taking your business income minus your business expenses. If your expenses are less than your income, the difference is net profit and becomes a part of your income on line 3 of Table 1 (Model 1040). If your expenses are greater than your income, the difference is net loss. You can usually deduct that loss from your total income on line 3 of Table 1 (Model 1040). However, in some cases, your loss is limited. This chapter briefly explains three of those situations. Other situations that may limit your loss are explained in the instructions for Table C, line G and line 32. If you have multiple business activities, you must calculate your net profit or net loss for each activity separately on each Table C.

Your losses from trade or business may be limited. Use Form 461 to determine the amount of your excess losses, if any. Your excess losses will be included in your income on line 8p of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) and considered as NOL that you must carry over and deduct in the following tax year. For more information on limiting excess losses, see the instructions for Form 461.

Losses from operating a business are the most common reason for a net operating loss. For details on operating losses, see Issue 536. This issue explains how to calculate a net operating loss (NOL), when to use NOL, how to request a NOL deduction and how to calculate a NOL transfer.

If you do not continue your business to make profit, there is a limit to the deductions you can make. You cannot use the losses from this activity to offset other income. Activities you do as a hobby, or primarily for sports or entertainment purposes, have this limit. For details on non-profit activities, see Hobbies or business: here's what you need to know about left-handed occupations.
The rules on SE taxation apply regardless of how old you are and even if you are receiving social security benefits as well as Medicare benefits.
Usually, you must file SE tax along with the SE form (Form 1040) if your net income from self-employment is $400 or more. Use the SE form to calculate your net income from self-employment.
If you are self-employed as an individual business or independent contractor, you usually use Form C (Form 1040) to calculate your taxable self-employed income.
The self-employed tax rate in 2024 on net income is 15.3% (12.4% social security tax plus 2.9% Medicare tax).

Only the first $168,600 of your total scholarship, bonus and net income in 2024 is subject to any combination of 12.4% SE social security tax, social security tax, or Tier 1 of the railway pension tax. Your total scholarship, bonus and net income in 2024 is subject to any combination of 2.9% SE social security tax, Medicare tax, or Tier 1 of the railway pension tax. If your scholarship and bonus are subject to Social Security tax or Tier 1 of the railway pension tax, or both, and total at least $168,600, please do not file 12.4% SE social security tax on any of your net income. However, you must file 2.9% Medicare tax on your total net income.

The additional 0.9% Medicare tax may apply to you if your net income from self-employment exceeds the limit (based on your tax status). For more information, see Self-Employment Tax (SE) in Chapter 1 and Form 8959 and the accompanying instructions.

Generally, foreign residents are subject to self-employment taxes according to the same rules as U.S. citizens. Temporary residents are not subject to self-employment taxes unless an international social security treaty (also called a comprehensive agreement) substantially determines that they are insured under the U.S. social security system. However, residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, or American Samoa are subject to SE taxes, as they are considered U.S. residents for SE tax purposes. For more information on foreigners, see Issue 519, U.S. Tax Guidelines for Foreigners.

If you have SE taxable income from multiple trades, businesses or professions, you must combine the net profits (or losses) of all activities to determine your total SE taxable income. Losses from one business activity will reduce your profits from another business activity.

If any income from a trade or business, not from a joint venture, is income from the spouses' common property under the laws of the state, then that income is aggregated with the SE taxable income of your spouse who conducts that trade or business.

Excluded from taxable income are profits or losses from the liquidation of assets that are not stockpiled for sale or held primarily for sale to customers. This is not subject to the liquidation being an involuntary sale, exchange or conversion.

If you are self-employed and reduce or discontinue your business activities, any payments you receive from insurance or other sources for lost business income are included in your SE taxable income. If you are not working at the time of receiving the payment, that payment is still related to your business activity and is included in your SE taxable income, even if that business activity is temporarily not being carried out.
You are not subject to SE tax if you are under 18 and are working for your parent.

If you work for a church or a church-controlled organization that qualifies (not being a pastor, member of a religious order or a Christian Science practitioner) and have elected to be exempt from social security and Medicare taxes, you are subject to SE tax if you receive $108.28 or more in salary from the church or organization. For more information, please see Issue 517, Social Security and Other Information for Religious and Religious-Related Workers.

If you are a crew member on a fishing or seafood vessel, your income is subject to SE tax if all of the following conditions apply. 1. You do not receive any payment for work other than your catch share or a portion of the proceeds from the sale of the catch, unless such payment meets all of the following conditions. 1. That payment does not exceed $100 per trip. 2. That payment is only received if there is a minimum catch. 3. That payment is only for additional tasks (such as assistant, engineer or cook) for which additional cash payment is common in the fishing industry. 2. You receive a portion of the catch or a portion of the proceeds from the sale of the catch. 3. Your share depends on the quantity of catch. 4. The size of the crew of a fishing vessel is usually less than 10 people. (A crew is considered to be less than 10 people if the average size of the crew on trips made in the last 4 calendar quarters is less than 10.)
Fees received for services you perform as a notary are declared on Schedule C but are not subject to SE tax (see the Guide to Schedule SE (Form 1040)).
You are subject to SE tax if you are a state or local government employee, paid only on a fee-based basis, and your services are not covered by an interstate social security agreement.

You are subject to SE tax if both of the following conditions are met. 1. You are a U.S. citizen employed in the U.S., Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands or the U.S. Virgin Islands by: 1.

If you are a U.S. citizen or a self-employed resident foreigner living outside the United States, in most cases you are required to pay SE tax. Income earned abroad from self-employment cannot be deducted by exclusion of foreign income when calculating your self-employment tax.

The United States has social security agreements with many countries to eliminate the possibility of double taxation under both social security systems. Under these agreements, you usually only pay social security and Medicare taxes to the country in which you live. The country in which you are taxed will issue a certificate proving that you are exempt from social security tax in that country. For more information, see the Guide to the SE Form (Form 1040).

You may want to use the optional method (discussed later) when you have a loss or a small net profit and any of the following applies: You want to receive a tax credit for social security benefits. You have a child or dependent care expense that may therefore claim a tax credit. (The optional method may increase your earned income, which may increase the tax credit.) You receive an earned income tax credit. (The optional method may increase your earned income, which may increase the tax credit.) You receive an additional child tax credit. (The optional method may increase your earned income, which may increase the tax credit.)

Using the optional method can increase your SE tax. Paying more SE tax may result in you receiving higher benefits when you retire. Using the optional method can also reduce your AGI by deducting half of SE tax on Form 1040 or 1040-SR, which may affect your ability to qualify for tax credits, deductions, or other amounts that depend on the AGI limit. Calculate your AGI using and not using the optional method to see whether the optional method benefits you. If you use one of the two or both optional methods, you must calculate and file SE tax to due date using these methods even if there is a lower tax rate or no tax when using the normal method. The optional method can only be used to calculate your SE tax. To calculate your income tax, add your actual income to your total income, regardless of which method you use to determine SE tax.

To calculate your net income by the standard method, multiply your self-employed income by 92.35% (0.9235). To calculate your net income by the standard method, see row 4a of Table SE (Form 1040). The net income calculated by the standard method is also called the actual net income.

Please use the non-farm option only for non-farm income. You can use this option if you meet all of the following criteria. 1. You are regularly self-employed. This means that your actual net income from self-employment was $400 or more in at least 2 of the 3 tax years preceding the year you use this option. For this purpose, the net income of the previous year can be from farm or non-farm income, or both. 2. You have used this option for less than 5 years. (There is a lifetime limit of 5 years.) These years do not have to be consecutive. 3. Your net non-farm income: 1. Below $7,493 and 2. Below 72,189% of your total non-farm income.
Typically, gross non-farm income is the sum of the amounts from: Line 7 of Schedule C (Form 1040); and Box 14, Code C, Schedule K-1 (Form 1065) (earned from non-farm joint ventures).
If you meet the three eligibility criteria explained in the previous section, please use the table below to calculate your non-farm net income from self-employment using the non-farm option method.

You cannot use this method to declare an amount lower than your actual net non-farm income from self-employment. Your actual net non-farm income is the net non-farm income calculated by the normal method, as explained in the previous section.
The following examples illustrate how net income is calculated when total non-farm income is $10,380 or less.
The following examples illustrate how net income is calculated when total non-farm income is higher than $10,380.
Please use the agricultural option method only for income from agricultural business activities. See Issue 225 for information on this method.

You may declare less than the total actual net income of both agricultural and non-agricultural activities but not less than the actual net non-agricultural income. If you use both options, you may declare no more than $6,920 as your combined net income from your self-employed work.

If you use a tax year other than the calendar year, you must use the tax rate and maximum income limit that are in effect at the time of the start of your tax year. Even if the tax rate or maximum income limit changes during your tax year, please continue to use the same tax rate and limit throughout your tax year.

Use the Form SE (Form 1040) to calculate and file your SE tax. If you file Form 1040 or 1040–SR, enter the SE tax on line 4 of Form 2 (Form 1040) and attach the Form SE to your form. If you file Form 1040–SS, enter the SE tax on line 3, and attach the Form SE to your form. If you need to pay SE tax, you must file Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040–SS, if applicable (with the Form SE attached) even if you do not file a federal income tax return yourself.

Even if you file a joint tax return, you cannot file a joint SE form. This is true whether one or both of your spouses have SE taxable income. If both have SE taxable income, each of you must complete a separate SE form. Please attach both forms to the joint tax return.

If you have more than one business or business activity, you must combine the net profit (or net loss) from each business activity to calculate your SE tax. A loss from one business activity will reduce your profit from another business activity. File an SE form showing income from self-employed work, however file a separate Form C or F for each business activity.

We accept most taxpayer returns. If we investigate your tax return or select it for audit, it does not mean that you are not honest. The investigation or audit may or may not result in a tax increase. We may close your file without any changes or you may receive a tax refund. The process of selecting a tax return for audit begins in one of two ways. One way is to use computer programming to identify tax returns that may contain incorrect amounts. These programming can be based on information sheets, such as Form 1099 and W-2; in studies of previous audits; or on some issues identified from special projects. Another way is to use information from external sources that indicate that a tax return may contain incorrect amounts. These sources may include the press, public documents and individuals. If we determine that this information is accurate and reliable, we may use that information to select a tax return for audit. Issue 556, Checking Returns, Right of Appeal, and Claiming a Tax Refund, explains the rules and procedures that we follow in audit activities. The following sections provide an overview of how we conduct audit activities.

We handle many checks and investigations by mail. We will send you a letter requesting additional information or a reason why we believe that your tax return may need to be changed. You can reply by mail or request a personal interview with the auditor. If you send us the requested information by mail or provide an explanation, we may agree or disagree and will explain the reasons for any changes. If there is anything you do not understand, please do not hesitate to write to us.

If we notify you of the conduct of the audit by means of a personal interview, or if you request such an interview, you have the right to agree on a time and place for the interview that is reasonable and convenient for both you and the IRS. If our auditor proposes any changes to your tax return, they will explain the reasons for the change. You may meet with the auditor's supervisor if you do not agree with the changes.

If we have checked your return for the same conditions in one of the previous two years and have not proposed a change in your tax liability, please contact us as soon as possible so that we can consider discontinuing the check.

If you do not agree with the changes proposed by the auditor, you may file a complaint with the IRS Independent Appeals Office. Most disputes can be resolved without the need for costly and time-consuming court hearings. Your right to appeal is explained in detail in both Issue 5, Your Right to Appeal and How to Prepare an Appeal if You Disagree, and Issue 556. If you do not wish to resolve through the Appeals Office or disagree with the decision of this office, you may bring your case to the U.S. Tax Court, the U.S. Federal Court of Appeals, or the U.S. District Court of your place of residence. If you bring your case to court, the IRS will be responsible for providing evidence as to whether you have kept complete records to demonstrate your tax liability, cooperated with the IRS, and met certain other conditions. If the court agrees with you on most issues in the case and finds most of our views unreasonable, you may be entitled to compensation for certain administrative and litigation costs. You will not be eligible for recovery of these costs unless you have attempted to resolve your case administratively, including through the appeals system, and provided us with the information necessary to resolve the case.
Your right to appeal against taxation is detailed in Publication 1660, The Right to Appeal against Taxation.

In general, both you and your spouse are responsible, jointly and severally, for paying the full amount of taxes, interests or fines due on your joint tax return. If you want to have a waiver of debt due in relation to your spouse (or former spouse), you must request it by filing Form 8857, Request for Waiver for Unmarried Spouse. In some cases, Form 8857 may need to be filed within 2 years of the date the IRS first attempts to collect taxes from you. Please do not file Form 8857 together with Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. For more information, please see Issue 971, Waiver for Unmarried Spouse and Form 8857, or you can call the Unmarried Spouse office at the toll-free number 855-851-2009.

In general, the IRS will deal directly with you or your legally authorized representative. However, sometimes we also contact others if we need information that you cannot provide or to verify information we have received. If we contact other people, such as neighbors, banks, employers or employees, we will usually need to give them some limited information, such as your name. The law strictly prohibits us from disclosing any information beyond what is necessary to gather or verify the information we are looking for. The need to contact other people may continue if your case is still ongoing. If we contact others, you have the right to request a list of those we have contacted. Your request can be made by phone, by letter or during a personal interview.

You can file a tax refund claim if you believe you have paid too much tax. Normally, you must file this claim within 3 years from the date you filed the original tax return, or 2 years from the tax filing date, whichever is later. Issue 556 provides additional information about tax refunds. If you have received a tax refund but have not filed a tax return, you must file a tax refund claim within 2 years from the date the tax was paid in order to receive the tax refund. General law allows interest on the tax refund if it is not returned within 45 days from the date you filed the tax refund claim.

If you have a question about a tax issue, need assistance preparing your tax return, or want to download free publications, forms or guides, visit IRS.gov and find resources that can help you right away.

After you have received all your payroll and income statements (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.); unemployment benefit statements (by mail or in digital format) or other government payments (Form 1099-G); and copies of interest, dividends and pensions from banks and investment companies (Form 1099), you have a number of options for preparing and filing your tax return. You can prepare your tax return yourself. See if you qualify for free tax preparation or hire a tax expert to prepare your tax return for you.

Taxpayers who need information about the assistance services can call 833-690-0598. The Helpline can answer questions about current and future products and support services available through alternative means (phone, email, big print, audio, etc.). The Helpline does not have access to your IRS account. For help with tax law, tax refunds, or account-related issues, visit IRS.gov/LetUsHelp.
Visit IRS.gov/DisasterRelief to see available disaster relief.
Visit IRS.gov/Forms to view, download and print all the forms, guides and publications you need. You can also visit IRS.gov/OrderForms to order.

You will need an IRS Online Account (OLA) to complete the mobile-friendly forms that require a signature. You will have the option to submit the form online or download a copy to send by mail. You will need scans of your documents to support the filing. Visit IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms for more information.

Download and view most popular tax publications and guides (including Guide to Form 1040) on mobile devices as eBooks at IRS.gov/eBooks. IRS eBooks have been tested using Apple's iBooks for iPad. Our eBooks have not been tested on other specialized eBooks, and the eBook functionality may not work as intended.

Access IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. View how much you owe and break it down by tax year. View payment plan details or sign up for a new payment plan. Make payments, view 5-year payment history and all pending or scheduled payments. Access your tax file, including important data from your most recent tax return, your financial impact payments and records. View electronic copies of selected notifications from the IRS. Approve or reject proxy requests from tax professionals. Update your address or manage your favorite contact methods.

With an online account, you can access a variety of information to help you through the tax season. You can take a record, view your most recently filed tax return and receive your total adjusted income. Create or access your online account at IRS.gov/Account.
This function allows your hired professional to send a proxy request for access to the IRS OLA of individual taxpayers. For more information, visit IRS.gov/TaxProAccount.

The safest and easiest way to receive your tax refund is to e-file and choose a direct deposit, which will transfer your refund directly to your financial account in a secure, electronic way. A direct deposit method also helps to avoid the possibility of lost, stolen, destroyed, or unsuccessful return of deposited checks to the IRS. Eight out of ten taxpayers choose a direct deposit method to receive their tax refund. If you do not have a bank account, visit IRS.gov/DirectDeposit for more information on where to find a bank or credit organization that can open an online account for you.

Your choice to prepare and file your tax return online or file it at your local community, if you qualify, includes the following. Direct File. Direct File is a standard option for filing your federal personal income tax return online—free—directly and securely with the IRS. Direct File is an option for taxpayers in participating states who have a relatively simple tax return to declare certain types of income and claim certain tax credits and deductions. Although Direct File does not prepare state returns, if you live in a participating state, Direct File will guide you to a state-supported tool that you can use to prepare and file your state tax return for free. Visit IRS.gov/DirectFile for more information, program updates and FAQs. Free File. This program allows you to prepare and file your federal personal income tax return for free using software or the Free File self-complete form. However, state tax preparation may not be done through Free File. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile to see if you are eligible to apply for free federal online tax return preparation options, electronic tax returns and direct transfers or direct tax filing. VITA. The Voluntary Income Tax Assistance Program (VITA) provides free tax assistance for low- to middle-income taxpayers, disabled taxpayers and taxpayers with limited English skills who need help preparing their own tax returns. Visit IRS.gov/VITA, download the free IRS2Go app or call 800-906-9887 for information on free tax return preparation services.

The IRS does not proactively contact taxpayers via email, phone calls, text messages (including short links) or social media channels to request the provision or verification of personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords or similar information for credit cards, bank or other financial accounts. Visit IRS.gov/IdentityTheft, the IRS's web page on Identity Theft Center, for information on identity theft and data security for taxpayers, tax practitioners and businesses. If you lose or steal your social security number or you suspect you are a victim of tax-related spoofing, you can learn what steps you should take. Get an Identity Protecting PIN (IP PIN). An IP PIN is a six-digit number given to taxpayers to help prevent the misuse of their SSN in federal income tax fraud. When you have an IP PIN, it will prevent others from filing their tax returns with your SSN. For more information, visit IRS.gov/IPPIN.

The IRS is unable to issue refunds before mid-February for returns that claim an EIC or an Additional Child Tax Credit (ACTC). This applies to the entire amount of the refund, not just the portion related to these tax credits.

U.S. tax payments must be filed with the IRS in U.S. dollars. Electronic assets are not accepted. Visit IRS.gov/Payments for information on how to make payments using any of the following options. IRS Direct Pay : Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax directly from your free payment or savings account. Debit card, app card, or e-wallet: Choose an approved payment processor to pay online or by phone. Electronic Bank Transfer: Schedule payments when filing federal taxes using tax filing software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System: Best choice for businesses. Registration is required. Check or money order: Mail your means of payment to the address listed in the notice or instructions. Cash: You can file taxes in cash at a participating retail store. In-day transfer: You can make transfers within the same day from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution for availability, cost, and timeframe.

Visit IRS.gov/Payments for more information on the options available to you. File an online payment agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to settle your tax obligations in monthly instalments if you are currently unable to file all of your taxes. After completing the online process, you will be notified immediately whether your agreement is approved. Use the Settlement Offer Assessment Tool to see if you can settle your tax debt for less than the total amount you owe. For more information on the Settlement Offer program, please visit IRS.gov/OIC.

Visit IRS.gov/WMAR to track the status of your amended Form 1040-X. Please note that it may take up to 3 weeks from the date you filed your amended tax return for this information to appear on our system, and up to 16 weeks for processing.
Visit IRS.gov/Notices for more information on responding to an IRS notice or letter.

Please note that many questions can be answered on the IRS.gov website without the need for a TAC. Visit IRS.gov/LetUsHelp to see the topics that people ask the most. If you still need help, the TAC will assist you with your tax issues that cannot be resolved online or over the phone. Currently, all TACs offer appointment-based services so that you can get the service you need without having to wait for long periods of time. Before you go, go to the IRS.gov/TACLocator to find your nearest TAC and check the opening hours, services provided and appointments to choose from. Or on the IRS2Go app, under the Stay Connected tab, select the Contact Us option and click on “Local Offices”.

The Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS. The TAS helps taxpayers resolve problems with the IRS, makes administrative and legislative recommendations to prevent or remedy problems, and protects taxpayer rights. We strive to ensure that all taxpayers are treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We are your voice at the IRS.

TAS can help you solve problems that you cannot solve with the IRS yourself. Always try to solve your problem with the IRS first, but if you cannot, come to TAS. Our services are free. TAS assists all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, businesses and tax-exempt organizations. You may be eligible for TAS assistance if your IRS issue is causing you financial difficulties, if you have tried and are unable to solve your issue with the IRS, or if you believe that the IRS system, processes or procedures are not working as expected. For assistance at any time on general taxation topics, please visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov.

The Bill of Rights of the Taxpayer describes the ten basic rights that all taxpayers have when dealing with the IRS. Visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/Taxpayer-Rights to learn more about the rights, what they mean to you and how they apply to the specific situations that you may encounter with the IRS. The TAS strives to protect the rights of the taxpayer and ensure that the IRS is administering tax law in a fair and equitable manner.

Although the taxpayer always signs the return, you are ultimately responsible for providing all the information necessary for the taxpayer to prepare your return correctly and to ensure that all items declared on the return are accurate. Anyone who is paid to file a tax return for another person must have a thorough understanding of tax matters. For more information on choosing a taxpayer, see Choosing a taxpayer on IRS.gov.

The Department of Social Security (SSA) provides online services at SSA.gov/employer with fast, free and secure W-2 filing options for CPA, accountants, registered agents and those who process Form W-2, Payroll and Tax Report, and Form W-2c, Revised Payroll and Tax Report.

If you are a sole proprietorship, partnership, or S-corp, you can see your tax information stored in the IRS files and do more with a corporate tax account. Visit IRS.gov/BusinessAccount for more information.

Visit IRS.gov/SocialMedia to see the various social media tools that the IRS uses to share the latest information about tax changes, fraud warnings, innovations, products and services. At the IRS, privacy and security are our top priorities. We use these tools to share publicly available information with you. Please do not post your social security number or other sensitive information on social media sites. Always protect your identity when using any social media site. The following IRS YouTube channels have short informative videos on various tax-related topics in English, Spanish and ASL. Youtube.com/irsvideos. Youtube.com/irsvideosmultilingua. Youtube.com/irsvideosASL.

The IRS is committed to serving taxpayers with limited English proficiency (LEP) by providing OPI services. OPI services are a federally funded program and are provided at Taxpayer Assistance Centers (TACs), most IRS offices, and all VITA/TCE tax filing locations. OPI services are accessible in over 350 languages.

The Small Business Administration (SBA) provides training and educational programs, advisory services, financial programs and contractual support for small business owners. The SBA also has publications and videos on a variety of business topics. Below is a brief presentation of the support provided by the SBA.

SBDC centres provide advisory, training and technical services to current and future small business owners who do not have the resources to use their own advisory services. Assistance will be available in opening, improving or expanding small businesses.

SCORE provides small business consulting and training services to current and future small business owners. SCORE comprises current and former entrepreneurs, who provide their expertise and knowledge to help people open, manage and expand small businesses. SCORE also organizes a series of small business seminars.
You can visit the SBA website at SBA.gov. While visiting the SBA website, you can find a lot of useful information for small business owners.
Please call the SBA Help Desk at 800-U-ASK-SBA (800-827-5722) for general information on programs available to assist small business owners.
You can visit the SBDC without making an appointment to make a request for support for your small business. To find the nearest location, please visit the website or call the SBA Answer Desk.

This chapter explains the business taxes you may have to pay and the forms you may have to file. This chapter also discusses the tax number (TIN). Table 1-1 lists the benefits of filing taxes electronically. Table 1-2 lists the types of federal taxes you may have to pay, due dates and forms to use to file. Table 1-3 provides checklists highlighting typical forms and tables you may need to file if you stop doing business. You may need to receive Form 509, Tax Schedule. The tax schedule lets you know when to file and pay taxes.

Usually, use your SSN as your TIN. You must enter this number on each of your personal income tax return forms, such as Form 1040 and the accompanying tables. To register for an SSN, use Form SS-5, Social Security Card Application. This form is available at the Social Security Administration (SSA) offices or by calling 800-772-1213. This form is also available on the SSA website at SSA.gov/forms/ss–5.

The IRS will issue an ITIN if you are a resident or temporary alien and do not have and cannot qualify for an SSN. The ITIN expires for any taxpayer who fails to file a federal income tax return (or who is not considered a dependent on another taxpayer's tax return) for three consecutive years. In summary, if you need an ITIN, you must attach Form W-7, the IRS Personal Tax Number Application, with the original signed and completed tax return and any other required documents and send it to the address in the Instructions for Form W-7. The exceptions are mentioned in the instructions. If you must include someone else's SSN on your tax return and that person does not have, or cannot receive, an SSN, please enter that person's ITIN. This form is also available in Spanish. This form is available at IRS.gov/FormW7. The ITIN is for tax purposes only. It does not allow the holder to receive social security benefits or change their employment or immigration status.

If you are required to have an EIN, please enter your EIN along with your SSN on Form C as directed.You can register for an EIN: Online by clicking on the Employee Identification Number (EIN) link at IRS.gov/businesses/small provided that the principal place of business is in the United States or U.S. territories — an EIN is issued immediately after the information on the application is verified; By phone at 267-941-1099 (not a toll-free number) only in the event that the principal place of business is located outside the United States or U.S. territories; or By sending a letter or fax containing Form SS-4, Application for an Employee Identification Number.

In the course of your business, you may make certain payments that must be declared on a tax return. These payments are discussed in the section on Tax Returns, later in this chapter. You must provide the recipient of these payments (the person who is paid) with a report stating the total amount paid during the year. You must enter the identification number of the person who is paid and your identification number on tax returns and reports.

If you have employees, you must obtain the SSN from each of them. Enter the name and SSN of each employee exactly as it appears on that employee's social security card. If the name of the employee is not correct as on the card, the employee should request a new card from the SSA. This can happen if the name of the employee has changed due to marriage or divorce. Each employee completes Form W-4, Employee Tax Deduction Certificate, so that federal income tax can be accurately deducted from their salary. If your employees do not have an SSN, they should file Form SS-5 with the SSA.

If you make payments to someone who is not your employee and you are required to report these payments on your information form, get that person's SSN. If you have to report payments to an organization, such as a limited company or partnership, you must get the EIN of that organization. To get the SSN or EIN of the payee, use Form W-9, Requesting Tax Numbers and Certificates. The payee who does not provide you with a tax number may be subject to a deduction. For information on deductions, see the Instructions for the W-9 Applicant and the General Instructions for Certain Information Forms.
This section explains whether you have to file an income tax return and when you have to do so. It also explains how you pay your taxes.

You must file an income tax return for 2024 if you have a net self-employed income of $400 or more. If you have a net self-employed income of less than $400, you still have to file an income tax return if you meet any of the other tax return requirements listed in the Instructions for Form 1040.

Please file your income tax return on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and attach Form C. Enter the net profit or loss from Form C on Form 1 (Form 1040). Use Form C to calculate the net profit or loss from your business activities. If you operate more than one business as an individual enterprise, you must attach separate Forms C for each of these businesses.

Paperless filing is easier than you think and available to most taxpayers who file electronically — including first-time taxpayers aged 16 and over by the end of 2024. If you file electronically using tax filing software or through a tax professional, you will sign your return with the Self-Selected PIN (Personal Identification Number) Method. If you and your spouse are married and file jointly, each of you will need to create a PIN and enter these PINs as your electronic signature. To create a PIN, you will need to know your AGI from the original 2023 income tax return filed (not from the amended tax return, Form 1040-X, or after receiving any math error notice from the IRS). You will also need to provide your DOB. Make sure your DOB is correct and matches the information in the files that the SSA has before you e-file. To do this, check your annual Social Security Report. With the Self-Selected PIN, you don't need to sign or mail anything — even your Form W-2. For more details on the Self-Selected PIN Method, visit IRS.gov.

In most states, you can file both your state tax return electronically and your federal tax return at the same time. For more information, check with your state tax office, your tax professional or IRS.gov.

You can receive your tax refund by post or have your tax refund signed directly into your payment or savings account. With IRS e-file, your tax refund will be issued in half the time it takes to file on paper. Most tax refunds are issued within 21 days.

As with paper tax returns, you may not receive the full amount of your tax refund if you (or your spouse, if filing joint tax) owe a certain amount of money overdue, such as federal tax, state tax, student loan or child benefit. You will be notified if the tax refund you claimed has been offset against your debts. You can file a claim for the injured spouse using Form 8379, Distribution to the Injured Spouse or Form 8857, Claim for Exemption to the Uninjured Spouse, to recover part or all of the joint tax refund transferred to pay your spouse's personal debts.

The IRS will not be able to issue refunds before mid-February 2024 for tax returns that have requested an earned income tax credit or an additional child tax credit.This applies to the entire amount of the tax refund, not just the portion related to these tax credits.

If your tax return shows you are owed tax, you must pay it by the due date of your tax return (without counting any tax extensions) to avoid paying interest as well as late tax penalties. For the 2024 calendar year, please pay by April 15, 2025. You have several options for making your tax return, including scheduling electronic debits from your payment or savings account or by credit card. For more information on tax return options, please visit IRS.gov/Payments.

You will be required to complete Form 8879, IRS e-file Signature Authorization, to allow your provider to enter your self-selected PIN on your tax return. Depending on the provider and the specific service requested, a fee may be charged. To find an IRS authorized e-file provider near you, please visit IRS.gov/Efile/Providers.

A computer with an Internet connection is all you need to file your tax return through IRS e-file. With the use of a personal computer, you can e-file from your home anytime, day or night. Sign your tax return in electronic format with a PIN of your choice to complete the process. No signed form or W-2 forms are required.
If your AGI is $84,000 or less in 2024, you can use the free tax software to prepare and e-file your return.

The public-private partnership between the IRS and these tax software providers has resulted in about a dozen commercially branded and freely available e-file software products. Just visit IRS.gov/FreeFile for more information. You can review each software provider's free use criteria or use online tools to find the free software product that suits your circumstances. Some software providers offer free state tax return services.

The IRS also provides electronic versions of paper IRS forms, which can also be e-filed for free. The Free File Self-Filling Templates are the best choice for people who are experienced in preparing their own tax returns. There are no income limits when using these forms. The Free File Self-Filling Templates perform basic calculations. These templates only support federal tax forms.

Some businesses provide e-files for free to their employees, members, or customers. Others provide it for a fee. Find out whether your employer or financial institution provides IRS e-files as a benefit to employees, members, or customers.

For the 2024 calendar year, Form 1040 or 1040-SR is due on April 15, 2025. If you use a fiscal year (explained in Chapter 2), your tax return will be due on the 15th of the fourth month following the end of the fiscal year. If you file late, you may be liable to a penalty and interest. If you are unable to file your tax return on time, please use Form 4868, Request for Automatic Extension of the Deadline for Filing the U.S. Income Tax Return for Individuals, to request an automatic extension of an additional 6 months. For calendar taxpayers, this will extend the tax return due date to October 15. Filing an extension application does not extend your tax return due date, only extends the tax return filing date.

Federal income tax is a type of immediate tax. You pay tax when you earn or receive income in that year. An employee is usually deducted income tax from their salary. If you do not pay your tax through deduction, or do not pay enough tax in that way, you may have to pay an estimated tax.

You are usually required to pay estimated tax amounts if you think you will have tax liabilities, including self-employment tax (discussed later) of $1,000 or more when filing your tax return. Use Form 1040-ES to calculate and pay your tax. If you are not required to pay estimated tax amounts, you may pay any tax due when filing your tax return. For more information on estimated tax, see Form 505.
Other options include transferring an excess payment from your 2023 tax return to your 2024 estimated tax or sending a cheque or money order by post along with the Form 1040-ES payment receipt.

If you do not pay your income tax and self-employment tax for 2024 by deducting or paying the estimated tax amounts, you may have to pay a fine for the amount outstanding. The IRS will calculate the fine and send you an invoice. Or you can use Form 2210, Refund of Estimated Missing Taxes by Individuals, Estates and Trusts, to see if you have to pay a fine, as well as to calculate the amount of the fine. For more information, see Issue 505.

SE tax is a type of social security and Medicare tax mainly for individuals who work for themselves. This type of tax is similar to social security and Medicare tax and is deducted from the salary of most wage earners. If you earn income as a statutory employee, you do not have to pay self-employment tax on that income. Social security and Medicare taxes are already deducted from that income.

Social security benefits are available to self-employed people as well as to employees. SE tax payments will contribute to your insurance in the social security system. Social security insurance provides you with pension benefits, disability benefits, rest benefit and hospital insurance benefits (Medicare). Please ensure that you declare all your self-employed income. By not declaring it fully, you may reduce your social security benefits when you retire.

You must be insured under the social security system before you can start receiving social security benefits. You are insured if you have the required number of credits (also called the insurance premium), which is discussed below.

For 2024, you will receive one credit, up to a maximum of four credits, for every $1,730 ($1,810 for 2025) of social security taxable income. Therefore, in 2024, if you have an income (self-employment and salary) of $6,920 that is already subject to social security tax, you will receive four credits ($6,920 ÷ $1,730). For an explanation of the number of credits you need to be insured and the benefits for you and your family under the social security program, please consult your nearest SSA office. False declarations to receive or increase social security benefits may result in penalties.

Normally, the SSA will only recognize self-employed income declared on a tax return filed within 3 years, 3 months and 15 days after the tax year in which you earned that income. If you file a tax return or declare a change in your self-employed income after this period, the SSA may change your record, but only to remove or reduce the amount. The SSA will not change your record to increase your self-employed income.
SE tax rules apply no matter how old you are and even if you are receiving social security or Medicare benefits.
The SE tax rate on net income is 15.3% (12.4% social security tax plus 2.9% Medicare tax).

Only the first $168,600 of your total scholarship, bonus and net income in 2024 is subject to any combination of the 2.9% SE tax, Medicare tax, or the 1% Medicare pension tax. If your scholarship and bonus are subject to SE tax or the 1% railway pension tax, or both, and the total is at least $168,600, please do not pay the 12.4% SE tax on any of your net income.

If you have both a salary and self-employed income, the amount limited to apply the Supplemental Medicare Tax on the self-employed income will be deducted (but not lower than 0) from the salary that is subject to the Supplemental Medicare Tax. Use Form 8959, Supplemental Medicare Tax, to calculate this tax.
For information on SE tax calculation methods, see Chapter 10).

For more information, please see Issue 15 (Regulation E), Tax Guide for Employers. This issue explains your tax liabilities as an employer. You do not deduct your deductions for social security and Medicare taxes under the non-refundable and refundable parts of the FFCRA and ARP 2021 tax credits for sick leave and qualifying family leave paid on your employment tax return. Instead, report the tax credits as income. To help you determine whether people you work for are considered employees, please see Issue 15-A. This issue contains information to help you determine whether an individual is an independent contractor or an employee. If you mistakenly classify an employee as an independent contractor, you may be liable for employment tax for that employee plus a penalty. An independent contractor is a self-employed person. You usually do not have to deduct or file any taxes on payments to an independent contractor.
For more information on the tax on income, see Publication 510, Tax on Income.

The federal tax on sales is reported on Form 720, the quarterly federal tax return, and includes a few major tax items listed below. Environmental taxes on the sale or use of ozone-depleting chemicals and imported products containing or manufactured with these chemicals. Information, communication and aviation taxes. Fuel taxes. Taxes on the first-class retail sale of heavy-duty trucks, trailers and tractors. Manufacturers' taxes on the sale or use of many different types of goods. Taxes on indoor sunbathing services.

There is a federal tax on the use of certain trucks, truck trailers and buses on public highways. This tax applies to vehicles with a total taxable weight of 55,000 pounds or more. Tax returns are made on Form 2290, Tax Returns for Heavy Highway Vehicles. For more information, please see the Guide to Form 2290.

If you are filing a quarterly tax return on Form 720, you may have to sign the tax return before the tax return is due. For details on signing the tax return, please see the Instructions for Form 720.

If you make or receive payments in your business, you may have to report them to the IRS on a return. The IRS compares the payments on the return with each person's income tax return to see if the payments are included in your income. You must provide a copy of the return that must be filed with the recipient or payer. In addition to the templates described below, you may have to use other tax returns to report certain types of payments or transactions. For more details about the return and when to file it, see General Guide to Some Returns.

You must also file Form 1099-NEC for each person from whom you have deducted any federal income tax (reported in box 4) under the provisions of the withholding tax laws to pay annual taxes regardless of the amount paid. If you use Form 1099-NEC to report sales of consumer products with a total value of $5,000 or more, you must file Form 1099-NEC with the IRS by January 31.

You must file a Form W-2 to report payments to your employees, such as salaries, bonuses and compensation, income after deduction, social security and other Medicare taxes. You can file the Form W-2 online. For more information on the Form W-2, see the General Instructions for Forms W-2 and W-3.

The law provides the following penalties if you fail to file Form 1099-MISC, Form 1099-NEC, or Form W-2 or fail to declare information correctly. For more information, please refer to the General Instructions for Certain Declarations. Failure to file a declaration. This penalty applies if you fail to file a declaration by the due date, fail to provide the required information in full or declare inaccurate information. Failure to provide accurate reporting of the payee. This penalty applies if you fail to provide the required return to the payee by the requested date, fail to provide the required information in full or declare inaccurate information.

You must file Form 8300, Reporting Cash Payments Over $10,000 Received in a Commercial or Business Activity, if you receive more than $10,000 in cash in a single transaction or more than one related business transaction. Cash includes coins and currencies of the United States and foreign countries. Cash also includes certain monetary instruments such as bank cheques, travelers' cheques and bills of exchange. Cash does not include checks withdrawn from an individual's private account (personal checks). For more information, please see Form 1544, Reporting Cash Payments Over $10,000.

You must calculate your taxable income and file your income tax returns according to an annual accounting cycle called the tax year. In addition, you must use a consistent accounting method, which clearly presents your income and expenses during the tax year.

If there is no mandatory tax year, you will apply a tax year by filing your first income tax return using that tax year. The mandatory tax year is the tax year required by the Tax Service Act or the Import Tax Regulations.

If you have filed your first income tax return using a calendar tax year and then start business as a sole proprietorship, you must continue to use that calendar tax year unless you are approved by the IRS to change it or are allowed to change it without IRS approval. For more information, please see Change your tax year, in the section below. If you apply a calendar tax year, you must maintain books and records and report your income and expenses for the period from January 1 to December 31 of each year.

The fiscal calendar tax year is 12 consecutive months ending on the last day of any month except December. The 52-53 week tax year is the fiscal calendar tax year extending from week 52 to week 53 but not necessarily ending on the last day of the month. If you apply the fiscal calendar tax year, you must maintain your books and records while reporting income and expenses in the same tax year. For more information on the fiscal calendar tax year, including the 52-53 week tax year, please see Issue 538.

Normally, you must file Form 1128, Application to Apply, Change or Retain Tax Year, to request approval from the IRS to change your tax year. See the Form 1128 Guide for exceptions. If you qualify for an automatic approval request, you do not have to pay a user fee. If you do not qualify for automatic approval, you must request a decision. See the Form 1128 Guide for information about user fees if you are requesting a decision.

Accounting policies are a set of rules used to determine when and how income and expenses are reported. Your accounting policies include not only the overall accounting policies used, but also the accounting policies used for any items. You choose the accounting policies for your business when you file your first income tax return, which includes Form C for your business. After that, if you want to change your accounting policies, you usually need to get the IRS's approval. See Changing Accounting Policies, in the next section.
You must use the same accounting method to calculate your taxable income and keep your books. In addition, you must use an accounting method that clearly presents your income.

To be approved, you must file Form 3115. You may obtain IRS approval to change your accounting method by either the automatic change procedure or the prior approval procedure. You may have to pay a user fee. For more information, please see the Guide to Form 3115.

Certain taxpayers may be granted permission by the IRS to change their accounting method. The permission is granted for the tax year that the taxpayer requests the change to (the year of change), provided that the taxpayer follows the automatic change procedure. No user fee is required for registrations filed under the automatic change procedure, which is generally referred to in the 2015-13 Taxation Procedure, 2015-5 I.R.B. 419, available at IRS.gov/IRB/2015-05_IRB#RP-2015-13 (or the replacement procedure). Typically, you must use Form 3115 to request the automatic change. For more information, please see the Guide to Form 3115.

You can account for business and personal items according to different accounting methods. For example, you can calculate your business income according to the accrual method, even when you use the cash method to calculate personal items.

If there are two or more separate and separated enterprises, you can use different accounting methods for each enterprise if that method clearly reflects the income of each enterprise. These methods are only separate and separated if you maintain a full and separate book with records for each enterprise.

Most individuals and many sole proprietors do not have inventory using the cash method because they find it easier to keep records with the cash method. However, if inventory is necessary to account for your income, you will usually use the accrual method to account for sales and purchases, unless you are a small business taxpayer (defined later in this chapter). For more information, please see Inventory, later.

In the cash method, please include all income that you actually received or are deemed to have received in your tax year in your total income. If you receive goods or services, you must include the fair market value of them in your income.

You have a calculated receipt of income when a sum of money is credited to your account or provided to you without restriction. You do not have to own it. If you delegate someone to receive the income on your behalf, you are deemed to have received the amount when the agent receives it.

You cannot keep a check or defer ownership of the same property from one tax year to another to avoid paying income tax. You must declare income in the year you receive or are provided with the property without restriction.
A receipt of a valid check at the end of the tax year is a receipt of estimated income for that year, even if you cannot withdraw cash or sign the check until the following year.

If there are debts paid by others or cancelled by the debtor, you may have to declare part or all of this debt relief as income. If you receive income in this way, you will be deemed to have received this income when the debt is cancelled or paid. For more information, please see Debt cancelled in the section Forms of income in chapter 5.

If you add a sum to your income and in a subsequent year you have to repay all or part of that sum, you can usually deduct the refund in the year you make the refund. If the amount you refund is greater than $3,000, a special rule will apply. For details on the special rule, please see Refunds in Chapter 8 of Edition 17.

Under the cash method, you usually deduct expenses in the tax year you actually pay them. This includes business expenses that you are responsible for the debt due. However, you may not be able to deduct an amount of expense that has been paid in advance or you may be required to capitalize certain expenses, as explained in the next section under the Unified Capitalization Rules.

Under the accrual method, you usually report income in the year in which income is earned and deduct or capitalize expenses in the year in which they are incurred. The purpose of the accrual method is to match income and expenses in the year accurately.

Under the cumulative method, you usually count an amount into your total income for the tax year in which all the events determining the entitlement to receive the income have occurred and you can determine this amount with reasonable accuracy. For a taxpayer who has an appropriate financial statement or such other financial statement as the Chief may designate, the criterion of “all events” for a category of total income is deemed to be met no later than the time it is taken into consideration in an appropriate financial statement or such other financial statement.
The following are the special rules that apply to advance payments, estimated income and changes in payment schedules for services.

If you add a reasonably estimated amount to your total income before expenses and taxes and then determine an exact amount different from the actual one, please take into account the difference in the tax year in which you determined it.

If you perform services at a base rate specified in the contract, you must accumulate income at the base rate, even if you agree to receive payments at a lower rate until you complete the services and then receive the difference.

Normally, you report an advance as income in the year you receive the payment. However, if you receive an advance, you can choose to defer the calculation of this advance on income until the next tax year. You cannot defer the calculation of any payments beyond that tax year. For more information, see Form 538 and Section 451.

Under the cumulative method, you typically deduct or capitalize operating costs when both of the following are met. 1. The “all events” criterion is met when: 1. All actual determining events for the debt due have occurred and 2. The debt due can be determined with reasonable accuracy. 2. Economic activity has occurred.

Normally, you cannot deduct or capitalize business expenses until economic performance occurs. If you have expenses for the goods or services supplied, or for the use of the goods, economic performance occurs when the goods or services are supplied or when the goods are used. If you have expenses for the goods or services you provide yourself to others, economic performance occurs when you supply the goods or services. An exception allows certain periodic items to be treated as incurred in the tax year even if economic performance has not occurred. For more information on economic performance, please see Economic Performance in the section Accrual Method in Issue 538.

When the production, purchase or sale of goods is a factor in the creation of income for a business, you usually have to account for inventory at the beginning and end of your tax year, unless you are a small business taxpayer. If you have to account for inventory, you usually have to use the cumulative method for your purchase and sale transactions. For more information, please see Inventory, in the section below.

You cannot deduct business expenses and interest owed to a related person using the cash method until you make the payment, and the corresponding amount is included in the total income of that person. For this rule, please specify the relationship at the end of the tax year in which the expense or interest will be deducted. If a deduction is not allowed under this rule, the rule will continue to apply even if your relationship with that person ends before the expense or interest is included in that person's total income. The related persons include members of your immediate family, including your brothers and sisters (of the same or different parents), your spouse, your parents, your ancestors, and your immediate grandchildren. For a list of other related persons, please see section 267 of the Tax Code.

In general, any combination of the special method, cash method and accrual method can be used if this combination clearly presents your income and expenses and you use it consistently. However, the following limitations apply. If you need inventory for your own income accounting, you usually have to use the accrual method for purchase and sale transactions. (Please see Inventory in the next section.) You can use the cash method for all other income and expenses. If you use the cash method to calculate income, you must use this method to report your expenses. If you use the accrual method to report expenses, you must use this method to report your income. If you use the combined method including the cash method, please treat the combination as cash method.
Typically, if you produce, buy or sell goods while doing business, you must keep inventory and use the cumulative method for buying and selling goods.

If you are a small business taxpayer, you may choose not to keep inventory, but you must still use an accounting method that clearly reflects income for inventory. If you choose not to keep inventory, you will not be considered as not clearly reflecting income if your inventory accounting method treats inventory as a material or material material or follows your inventory financial accounting method. However, if you choose to keep inventory, you will usually have to use the accumulation method and value inventory annually to determine the capital value of sales in Part III of Schedule C.

You qualify as a small business taxpayer if (a) you have an average annual turnover of $30 million or less in the previous three tax years and (b) you are not a tax avoidance scheme (as defined in section 448(d)(3)). If your business has not been operating for the entire three-year period used to calculate the average turnover, please use the average rate calculated over the period it has been operating and if your business has a predecessor unit, include the total turnover of that unit from the three-year period when calculating the average turnover. If your business (or predecessor unit) has a short tax year in any year of the three-year period, calculate the total annual turnover of your business for the short tax years in that three-year period. See Issue 538 for more information.

If you account for inventory as material and essential goods, please deduct the amounts paid or incurred for the purchase or production of the items of inventory considered as material and essential goods in the year in which they are first used or consumed in the course of your business. Inventory is considered as material and essential goods used or consumed in your business in the year in which you supply such stock to your customers.

Your inventory financial accounting policy is determined based on the accounting policy you use in your appropriate financial statements (as defined in section 451(b)(3)) or, if there is no appropriate financial statement, please base on the accounting policy you use in the books and records that have been prepared in accordance with your accounting procedures.
If you want to change the method of accounting for inventory, you must file Form 3115. See Change of Accounting Method, later.

If you are asked to account for inventory, please include the following items in your accounting. Stocks in the warehouse for sale. Raw materials. Sold finished products. Finished products. Materials that become a physical part of the items intended for sale.

You must value your inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year to determine the capital cost of sales (Schedule C, Line 42). To determine the value of your inventory, you need a method of identifying the items in your inventory and a method of valuing these items. The rules for inventory pricing cannot be the same for all types of businesses. The method you use to value your inventory must follow accounting principles that are generally accepted for similar businesses and must clearly reflect income. Your inventory practices must be consistent from year to year.

Under the unified capitalization rule, you must capitalize direct costs and a portion of indirect costs for production or resale activities. Aggregate these costs on the base value of the assets you produce or purchase for resale, rather than reporting them as a current deduction. You recover costs through depreciation of tangible fixed assets, depreciation of intangible fixed assets or the cost of capital sales when you use, sell or otherwise dispose of the assets.

You may have to follow the unified capitalization rules if you do any of the following, unless the assets are produced for your use outside of business or an activity is carried out for profit. Production of real or personal movable property. For this purpose, personal movable property includes films, audio recordings, videotapes, books or similar assets. Purchase of assets for resale.

These rules do not apply to the following items. 1. Small business taxpayers, defined earlier under Inventories. 2. Assets you produce if the indirect cost to produce those assets is less than $200,000.

There are special accounting methods for some income or expense items. These include the following items. Depreciation of intangible fixed assets, discussed in Chapter 7 of Issue 225. Bad debt, discussed in Topic 453, Depreciation of bad debt. Depreciation, discussed in Chapter 7 of Issue 225. Depreciation of tangible fixed assets, discussed in Issue 946, How to depreciate assets. Selling on instalment, discussed in Issue 537, Selling on instalment. Methods of settlement of long-term contracts. See Section 460.

If you deal with business assets, you may have profits or losses and you declare them on your tax return. However, in some cases, you may have a non-taxable profit or a non-deductible loss. This chapter discusses whether or not you have to settle assets, how to calculate profits or losses, and where to report these.

A trade of the same kind is the exchange of one property for another property of the same kind. This is the most common type of tax-free exchange. To be a trade of the same kind, the property traded and the property received must be both (a) real estate and (b) business or investment property. Report a trade of the same kind on Form 8824, Trade of the same kind. For more information on trade of the same kind, see Note 1 of Note 544.

A sale on instalment is a sale of an asset when you receive at least one payment after the tax year of that asset. If you finance the buyer when you buy your asset, rather than letting the buyer borrow money or mortgage from a third party, it is likely that you are selling on instalment. For more information on selling on instalment, see Issue 537.

The sale of a business is not usually the sale of an asset. Instead, all the assets of the business are sold. Typically, when this happens, each asset is treated as being sold separately for the purpose of determining the profit or loss. Both the buyer and the seller involved in the sale of a business must report to the IRS on the allocation of the sale price among the assets of the business. Use Form 8594, Reporting Purchases of Property Under Section 1060, to provide this information. Both the buyer and the seller must attach Form 8594 to their federal income tax returns for the year in which the sale takes place. For more information on selling a business, see Form 544.

The capital cost or purchase price of an asset is usually the original cost to determine the profit or loss from the sale or other disposition of that asset. However, if you acquire an asset from a gift, inheritance, or in some other way than by purchasing it, you must use a original cost other than its capital cost. For more information on the original cost, see Issue 551, The original cost of an asset.

The adjusted original value of an asset is generally your capital or other original value plus some additional items and minus some discounts such as depreciation and loss for damage. When determining profit or loss, the costs of transferring the asset to the new owner, such as the cost of sale, are added to the adjusted original value of the asset.

Generally, the amount you receive from the transaction is the total amount you receive plus the fair market value of all the property or services you receive. The amount you receive also includes any debts you have to the buyer and any debts you owe to the property you transfer, such as property taxes or mortgage debts.

The profit or loss you realize from the disposal of assets is usually the amount of profit or loss determined for tax purposes. The amount of profit recorded must be included in total income. The losses recorded may be deducted from total income. However, profits or losses from certain asset exchange activities are not recorded. Please see Non-taxable exchanges in the previous section. In addition, you cannot deduct a loss from the disposal of assets held for personal use.

You must classify your profits and losses as ordinary profits or losses or capital gains or losses. You must do this to calculate your net profits or losses. Typically, you will have capital gains or losses if you liquidate capital assets. In most cases, everything you own and use for personal or investment purposes is capital assets. Some assets you use in your business are not capital assets. The profits or losses from liquidating these assets are ordinary profits or losses. However, if you hold the assets for more than one year, you may consider the profits or losses to be capital profits or losses. These are called profits and losses in section 1231. For more information on ordinary and capital profits and losses, see chapters 2 and 3 of Issue 544.

If there is an interest or loss on the capital, you must determine whether it is long-term or short-term. Whether the interest or loss is long-term or short-term depends on how long you own the asset before you settle it. The time you own the asset before you settle it is called the ownership period.
Use Form 6252, Revenue from Sales of Contributions. You may also need to use Form 4797 and Form D (Form 1040).

Your total business tax credit for the year consists of the carry-over of business tax credits from previous years plus the total business tax credit for the current year. In addition, your total business tax credit for the current year may be increased later by carrying over business tax credits from later years. You deduct this tax credit directly into your tax.

All tax credits below are part of the overall business tax credit. The form you use to calculate each tax credit is shown in the brackets. You will also need to complete Form 3800. Some tax credits have expiration dates. Check the instructions for each tax credit to ensure that you have those tax credits for 2024.

This tax credit applies to the cost of starting a retirement program of a newly qualified defined benefit or defined contribution plan (including a 401(k) plan), SIMPLE or simple employee retirement program. For more information, see Issue 560, Small Business Retirement Programs.

This tax credit is a non-refundable tax credit for qualifying small businesses that pay or incur costs to provide facilities for people with disabilities. You must pay or incur costs to make your business compliant with the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. For more information, see Form 8826.
You may qualify for this tax credit if you have employees and are engaged in a business activity in a difficult economic area where the tax credit is available. For more information, see Form 8844.
This tax credit is usually applied to every qualifying low-income building that is put into operation after 1986. For more information, see Form 8586.
These tax credits are for certain types of clean vehicles put into service in the tax year. For more information, see Form 8936.
This tax credit applies to eligible railway maintenance costs paid or incurred in the tax year. For more information, see Form 8900.
This tax credit encourages businesses to hire individuals from target groups with particularly high unemployment rates or other special employment needs. For more information, see Form 5884.

This tax credit is usually equivalent to the portion of the social security and Medicare taxes you (the employer) pay for the food and beverages that your employees receive at your establishments where food and beverages are a customary payment. The tax credit applies whether the food is consumed in or outside your establishment. For more information, see Form 8846.
This tax credit encourages businesses to continue paying salaries to employees who are performing service in the United States uniform forces for a period of more than 30 days.
This tax credit applies to qualifying costs you pay for childcare activities for employees as well as for childcare referral and support services. For more information, see Form 8882.

To request a general business tax credit, you will first need to receive the forms required for requesting business tax credits for the current year. In addition to the tax credit form, you will also need to file Form 3800.

This chapter mainly explains business income and how to account for that income on your tax return and what is not considered as income, and provides guidance for some selected professions. If there is a connection between any income you receive and business activity, then that income is business income. A connection exists in the case where payment for that income would obviously not be made if you did not have business activity. You may have business income even if you are not regularly engaged in that activity full-time. Income from work you do outside, in addition to your regular work, may be business income. For example, you may be doing business by providing services to a carpooling company as a second job. You declare most of your business income, such as income from selling your products or services, in Form C. However, you declare income from the sale of business assets, such as land and office buildings, in other forms instead of Form C. For information on selling business assets, see Chapter 3.

Business income includes the amount of money you receive in your business activity that is accurately displayed on the Form 1099-NEC. This income includes the amount declared as remuneration to non-employees in box 1 of the form. You can find more information in the instructions on the back of the Form 1099-NEC received.

NIL opportunities can be classified as self-employed income. If your NIL income is greater than $600 from any source, including non-cash income, you will receive a Form 1099-NEC or Form 1099-MISC from that source stating the amount of income you must declare on your tax return.

If you are doing business, you may receive a Form 1099-K showing the total amount (including taxes, fees) of all reportable payment transactions. This may not be the amount you should report as income, as it may not include all receipts and may include items not included in your receipts (e.g. consumption tax).
The income you report on Schedule C may be qualified business income and allow you to deduct on line 13 of Form 1040 or 1040-SR. See Form 8995-A or Form 8995 to calculate your deduction, if any.

You must declare on your tax return all income received from your business activities, including income not reported to you on Form 1099 by the payer unless it is excluded by law. In most cases, your business income will be in the form of cash, cheques and credit card payments. But business income can take other forms, such as property or services. These and other types of income are explained below. If you are a U.S. citizen with business income from sources outside the U.S. (income from abroad), you must declare that income on your tax return unless you are exempt from tax under U.S. law. If you live outside the U.S., you may be able to exclude some or all of your business income from abroad. For more details, please see Issue 54, Tax Guidelines for U.S. Citizens and Foreign Residents Living Abroad.

A barter is the exchange of goods or services. You must include in your total revenue, at the time of receipt, the fair market value of the goods or services you receive in exchange for something else. If you barter services with another person and you both have previously agreed on the value of the service, that value will be accepted as the fair market value unless that value can be proven to be unreasonable.

If you are a real estate trader receiving income from renting out real estate or an owner of a hotel, inn, etc., a service provider (housekeeping services, etc.) to customers, please report the income and expenses from renting out in Form C. If you are not a real estate trader or the type of owner described in the sentence above, please report the income and expenses from renting out in Form E. For more information, see Form 527, Residential Property for Rent.

You are a real estate dealer if you are engaged in the business of selling real estate to customers with the purpose of making a profit from those transactions. Rent you receive from real estate that is kept for sale to customers is subject to self-employment tax. However, rent you receive from real estate that is kept for investment or investment is not subject to self-employment tax.

Rent income from a mobile home parking lot is subject to self-employment tax if you are a self-employed mobile home parking lot owner, providing the land and vehicles as well as essential services to provide convenience to the tenants.
