You will generally be considered to provide essential services to the tenants if these services are primarily directed at their convenience and are not usually provided for the purpose of maintaining the land in a state of habitability. Services are essential if the remuneration for these services constitutes a significant part of the rent payments from the tenants. Examples of services not usually provided to provide convenience to the tenants include monitoring and maintenance of the entertainment room provided by the parking lot, distribution of monthly newsletters to the tenants, operation of the laundry facilities and helping tenants buy or sell their mobile home. Examples of services typically provided to maintain the land in a state of rent include the drainage system, connections to the electricity network and the city roads.

Rent income you receive from operating or renting a hotel, inn or apartment house is subject to self-employment tax if you provide services to guests. Generally, you are considered to provide services to guests if these services are primarily aimed at their convenience and not merely providing a room to stay in. An example of services that are not usually provided for the convenience of guests is housekeeping services. However, the provision of heating and lighting, cleaning of stairs and corridors, as well as garbage collection are services that are usually provided for the convenience of guests.
Advances received under a lease without any restriction on their receipt or use are income in the year you receive them. This is generally true regardless of the method or accounting cycle you use.

If your tenant pays someone else under a contract to pay your debts or obligations, please count this payment to your gross revenue when the tenant makes the payment. A common example of this form of income is when the tenant pays your property tax on the property you rent.

The payments you receive to settle the lessee's obligation to restore the leased property to its original state are income calculated for the amount in which the payments exceed the basic adjusted value of the repair of the leased property that was destroyed, damaged, removed or separated by the tenant.

If you are a business that rents out personal property (equipment, vehicles, formal clothing, etc.), include the amount of rent you receive in your total revenue in Schedule C. Advance rent and other payments described in Real Estate Rental in the previous section may also be received when renting out personal property. If you receive any of these payments, count them in your total revenue as explained in that discussion section.

Interest earned on receivables that you have accepted in the course of your business is normally income from business activities. Interest earned on loans is business income if you are a lending business.

If a loan due to you becomes uncollectible in the tax year and you use the accrual method, you must include in your total income the interest accrued up to the time the loan became uncollectible. If the interest accrued afterwards is uncollectible, you may be deducted for bad debt. See Bad debt in chapter 8.

If little or no interest is charged when selling a instalment contract, you may have to consider a portion of each payment as unstated interest. See Unstated Interest and Original Issue Discount (OID) in Issue 537.

Normally, dividends are the business income of a stock trader. However, for most individual businesses and corporate employees, dividends are non-business income. If you hold shares as a personal investment separate from your business activities, dividends from shares are non-business income. If you receive dividends from business insurance premiums that you have deducted in a previous year, you must declare all or part of the dividends as business income on your tax return. For the amount you must declare, see Reclaiming previously deducted items in the Other Income section, in the next section.
This section explains the general rule for calculating debt cancelled into income as well as the exceptions to the general rule.

Normally, if your debt is cancelled or exempted, unless it is a gift or bequest, you must add the cancelled amount to your total income for tax purposes. Report the cancelled amount on line 6 of Schedule C if you incurred the debt in your business activities. If it is a non-business debt, please report the cancelled amount on line 8c of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).
The discussion below includes some exceptions to the general rule that debts are cancelled.

If you owe the seller a sum for an asset you buy and the seller reduces the amount you owe, you usually have no income from the price reduction. Unless you are bankrupt or insolvency, please treat the discount as an adjustment to the purchase price and a reduction in your basic value in the asset.
You do not recognize income from a cancelled debt in the event that the repayment of that debt would result in a deduction.

If a cancelled debt is excluded from income because it arose in a bankruptcy case, then the exclusions in scenarios 2 to 5 do not apply. If this cancelled debt arose when you went bankrupt, then the exclusions in scenarios 3 and 4 do not apply to the case you went bankrupt.

You can choose to exclude (to a certain extent) the cancellation of eligible real estate business debt. If you choose this option, you must deduct the amount excluded from the base value of your depreciable property. Perform this deduction at the beginning of the tax year immediately following the cancellation. However, if you liquidate the asset before that time, you must deduct the base value of the property immediately before the liquidation.

Qualified real estate business debt includes the refinancing of debt described in (3) above, but only to the extent that it does not exceed the debt that is being refinanced. If you are the owner of a non-eligible body (e.g. a member LLC), please refer to Qualified Real Property Business Indebtedness in Chapter 1 of Issue 4681 to see if you qualify for this exclusion. You cannot exclude more than one of the following two amounts. 1. The excess (if any) of: 1. The outstanding principal of the qualifying real estate business debt (immediately before cancellation); 2. The market value (immediately before cancellation) of the commercial real estate that secures the debt, less the outstanding principal of any other qualifying real estate business debt secured by this asset immediately before cancellation. 2. The total adjusted base value of the amortising real estate you hold immediately before cancellation. These adjusted base values are determined based on any decrease in the base value due to cancellation by bankruptcy or default, or of qualifying agricultural debt. Please do not include amortising real estate available when the cancellation is expected.

To exercise this option, please complete Form 982 and attach it to your income tax return for the tax year in which the cancellation occurred. You must file your tax return by the due date (including the extension period). If you file your tax return on time in the year without making the option, you can still make the option by filing an amended tax return within 6 months of the due date of the tax return (excluding the extension period). For more information, please see When to file in the instructions of the form.
The following discussion explains how to deal with other types of business income that you may receive.

Restricted assets are assets of value affected by certain restrictions. If you receive restricted shares or other assets for services rendered, the market value of the assets in excess of the cost will be added to your income in Schedule C when the restrictions are lifted. However, you may choose to be taxed in the year you receive the assets. For more information on adding restricted assets to your income, please see Form 525, Taxable and Non-Taxable Imports.
In the following cases, you must deduct the amortization. This means that you include in your income some or all of the amortization that you have deducted in previous years.

If the use of an asset listed in your business (explained in Chapter 8 under Depreciation) decreases to 50% or less in a tax year after the tax year in which you put the asset into use, you may be required to recover a portion of the depreciation deduction. You do this by adding to your income in Schedule C the depreciation you have deducted in previous years. Use Part IV of Form 4797 to calculate the amount to be added on Schedule C. For more information, see What Is the Business-Use Requirement? in Chapter 5 of Issue 946. This chapter explains how to determine whether an asset is used for more than 50% of your business.

If you make a deduction under section 179 (explained in chapter 8 under Depreciation) on an asset and before the end of the depreciation period of the asset and the percentage used for business purposes falls to 50% or less, you must reclaim a portion of the deduction under section 179. You do this by adding to income in Schedule C a portion of the deduction you made. Use Part IV of Form 4797 to determine the amount to be added in Schedule C. See Chapter 2 of Issue 946 for the time of reclaim.

If you sell or exchange an asset that is subject to depreciation and you earn interest, you may have to treat all or part of the interest from depreciation as ordinary income. You calculate the income from depreciation in Part III of Form 4797. For more information, see Chapter 4 of Issue 544.

Declare debt notes and other evidence of debts issued to you in a transaction selling or exchanging assets that are stockpiled for sale or held primarily for sale to customers in Form C. Typically, you declare them at the principal amount stated in the contract of the loan (less any interest not specified in any contract) or the issue price (or debt instrument with OID) when you receive them.

If you reduce or discontinue your business activities, please declare in Form C any payments for lost business income that you receive from insurance or other sources. Declare those payments in Form C even if your business is not operating at the time of payment.

You must aggregate compensation for the total income received in the tax year from any of the following losses related to your business. Patent infringement. Breach of contract or trust liability. Loss from antitrust litigation.

You are entitled to deduct from your income if the deduction compensates for the actual economic loss. Your deduction is less than the following. The amount of money you received or accumulated for the loss in the tax year minus the amount you have to pay or incur in the tax year to recover that amount. The loss from that loss that you have not deducted is the loss in the tax year.

If you receive any refund, please include it in income in Schedule C. However, do not include it in income if you can reasonably consider it as a deduction of an associated cost, an expense for long-term investment or the price of a capital good sold.

If you recover a bad debt or any other deduction in the previous year, include that refund in your income in Schedule C. However, if all or part of the deduction in the previous years does not reduce your tax, you may exclude the non-reducing part of your income. If you exclude part of the refund from your income, you must include in your tax return a calculation showing how you calculated the deduction.
In some cases, the property or money you receive will not be income.
The increase in value of your property is not income until you realize that value increase through sale or other taxable forms of disposal.

If a tenant builds buildings or repairs your property, then the increase in the value of the property resulting from the repairs is not income for you. However, if the facts show that the repairs were a rent paid to you, then the increase in value is income.
Money borrowed through a goodwill loan is not income for the lender.
State and local consumption taxes apply to the buyer, which you must collect and pay to the state or local government, but are not income tax.

Sending goods to someone else to sell on your behalf is not a sale. Ownership of the goods remains with you (the sender) even after the recipient has owned the goods. Therefore, if you send goods on a consignment form, you do not make a profit or loss until the recipient sells the goods. The goods you have sent for consignment are counted in your inventory until they are sold. Exclude the goods you receive on a consignment form from your inventory. Please count the profit or commission on the goods sent to you in your own income when you sell the goods or when you receive your profit or commission, depending on the accounting method you use.

Some Medicaid exempted payments reported to you on Form 1099-MISC or Form 1099-NEC may not be taxable. For more information on how to report those payments, see the Instructions for Form C (Form 1040).

If you signed a lease after 5 August 1997, you can deduct from your income the building allowance received (in cash or in the form of a rent reduction) from the landlord if you receive the allowance under both of the following conditions. Under a short-term lease of retail land. For the purpose of building or renovating long-term real estate that meets the standards for your business activities on that retail land.

A short-term lease is a lease (or other agreement on the use) of retail space for a period of 15 years or less. The following rules apply to determine whether a lease is for a period of 15 years or less. Please consider the options for renewal when determining whether a lease is for a period of 15 years or less. However, please do not consider any options for renewal at the market price determined at the time of renewal. Two or more consecutive leases that are part of the same transaction (or a series of related transactions) for the same or essentially the same retail space are considered as one lease.
A retail plot is a real estate that you rent, or use as a tenant in the course of your own private retail business or public service.

Qualifying long-term real estate is non-residential real estate that is part of or is present on your retail property and will be returned to the landlord when the lease ends, unless otherwise stated in the lease agreement.

Normally, if you exchange real estate used for business or held as an investment only in exchange for other investment or business real estate of the same type, no profit or loss is recorded. This means that the profit is not taxable and the loss is not deductible. For more information, see Form 8824.

You must report this income whether or not it is reported to you on the information form. You are a direct seller if all of the following conditions are met. 1. You are engaged in one of the following commercial or business activities. 1. Selling or delivering consumer products at home or other locations other than a fixed retail establishment or to any buyer on a buy-sell or deposit-commission basis for the purpose of resale at home or other business locations other than a fixed retail establishment. 2. Providing or distributing shopping newspapers or news (including any services directly related to that commercial or business activity). 2. In principle, all payments you receive (whether paid in cash or not) for the services described above are directly related to sales or other output (including the performance of the service) rather than to working time. 3. Services that you perform under a written contract between you and the person to whom you provide the service, and the contract stipulates that you will not be considered an employee for federal tax purposes.

If you are a licensed real estate agent or direct seller, your income is declared on Schedule C if both of the following apply. In principle, all payments you receive for services as a real estate agent or direct seller are directly related to sales or output other than the number of hours worked. You perform the services under a written contract stating that you will not be considered an employee for federal tax purposes.

If you are a tenderer in options or commodities, your profits and losses from selling or investing in contracts under section 1256 (regulated futures, foreign exchange contracts, non-equity options, agent equity options and agent securities futures) or assets related to those contracts (such as shares used to secure options) are reported in Schedule C. For more information, please see sections 1256 and 1402(i) of the Act.

You are a securities or commodity investor if you are engaged in the business of buying and selling securities or commodities for your own account. As a securities or commodity trader (even if you make a market-valued option under section 475(f) as a securities or commodity trader), your profits or losses from dealing in securities or commodities are not reported in Schedule C. For more information on a securities or commodity investor, see Issue 550, Income and expenses of investment and Issue 429, Securities trader.
If the fees do not meet the above requirements, please declare them in line 8z of Table 1 (Form 1040).

Termination payments that you receive as a former self-employed insurance agent from an insurance company for services you have performed for that company are not declared in Schedule C if all of the following conditions are met. You have received payments after the agreement to perform services for the company has ended. You have not performed any services for the company after the agreement to perform services for the company has ended and before the end of the year in which you received the payment. You have signed a non-competitive agreement with the company for at least one year from the date of the termination of the agreement to perform services for the company. The amount of the payment depends primarily on the insurance contracts that you have sold or credited to your account in the last year of the agreement to perform services for the company or the extent to which those insurance contracts remain in effect for a period of time after the agreement to perform services for the company has ended or both. The amount of the payment does not depend on any extent of the period of performance of services or on the total income from services performed for the company (whether eligibility for payments depends on the period of performance of services or not).

Income paid by an insurance company to a retired self-employed insurance agent based on a percentage of the commissions received prior to retirement is reported in Schedule C. In addition, extension commissions as well as deferred commissions on sales obtained prior to retirement are also usually reported on Schedule C. However, extension commissions paid to the survivors of an insurance agent are not reported in Schedule C.
The fees you receive for services that you perform yourself as a notary are declared in Schedule C. These payments are not subject to self-employment tax (see Guidelines for Schedule SE (Form 1040)).

Civil servants generally do not declare what they earn while serving in office in Schedule C. This rule applies to payments that an elected tax collector receives from the state treasury on the basis of a fixed percentage of the amount of tax collected. Office includes any elected or appointed office of the United States or a territory of the United States, the District of Columbia, a state or its political subdivisions, or a wholly owned vehicle of any of these offices. Civil servants of the state or local government declare their fees in Schedule C if they are paid only on the basis of fees and if their services qualify for (but are not paid for by) social security under an interstate agreement.

Accounting for your income for income tax purposes sometimes differs from accounting for financial purposes. This section discusses some more common differences that may affect business transactions. Calculate your business income on the basis of a tax year and according to your usual accounting method (see Chapter 2). If selling products is an income-generating factor in your business, you usually need to use inventory to present your income clearly. Real estate contractors are not allowed to use inventory. For more information on inventory, please see Chapter 2.
All income you earn is subject to tax to you. You cannot avoid tax by paying your income to a third party.

You must use the method you have selected annually for all discounts on your purchases. If you use the second method, the balance in the account at the end of your tax year is business income. Under this method, you do not deduct any cash discounts you receive from the capital price of the goods sold. When you value end-of-period inventories, you cannot deduct the average discount or estimate received for goods available at the time of the end of the tax year from the price on the delivery invoice of those goods.

These are discounts from the listed or catalog price and are usually not recorded on the delivery invoice or charged to the customer. Do not enter these discounts in your accounting books. Instead, only use the actual amount as the capital price of the purchased goods. For more information, please see Commercial Discounts in chapter 6.

If the buyer of your property places part or all of the purchase price in a collateral depository, you will not count any part of that money into the total sales revenue until you actually or are deemed to have received it. However, after completion of the terms of the contract and collateral depository agreement, you will have taxable income, even if you have not accepted that money until the following year.
The special rules that apply to the accrual accounting method for advance payments received are discussed in Chapter 2 in the section on the accrual method.

If you receive insurance or a form of compensation for a loss due to accident or theft, you must deduct it from the loss when calculating your deduction. You cannot deduct the loss due to accident or theft that has been compensated for. For information on loss due to accident or theft, see Issue 547.

If you produce or purchase goods for sale, you may deduct the capital cost of sales from your aggregate revenue in Schedule C. However, to determine these costs, you must value your inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year. This section applies to you if you are a manufacturer, wholesaler or retailer or if you engage in any business activity that produces, buys or sells goods to generate income. This section does not apply to personal service businesses, such as doctors, lawyers, carpenters or painters. However, if you work in a personal service business establishment and also sell or charge for materials and supplies commonly used in your business, then this section applies to you. There is an exception for small business taxpayers who may change how you calculate the capital cost of sales for your business activity. For more information, please see Section 2..

If you are a merchant, initial inventory is the capital cost of the goods available at the beginning of the year that you will sell to customers. If you are a factory owner or manufacturer, initial inventory includes the total cost of raw materials, sold finished goods, finished goods, and the materials and materials used to produce the goods (see Inventory in chapter 2). The initial inventory will usually be the same as the final inventory of the previous year. You must explain any differences in a table attached to your tax return.

If you donate inventory (an asset that you sell in the course of your business), the amount you can claim as a charity deduction will be the lesser of its market value on the date you donate and its base value. The original price of the donated inventory is any cost incurred for the inventory in a previous year that otherwise would have been included in your initial inventory for the year of the donation. You must deduct the discount of your charity contribution from your initial inventory. It is not a part of your capital sales price. If the cost of the donated inventory is not included in your initial inventory, then the base value of the inventory is 0, and you cannot claim a charity deduction. Treat the cost of the inventory as you would normally do in your accounting method. For example, add the purchase price of the inventory purchased and donated in the same year to the sales capital price of that year. A special rule may apply for some charity gifting activities, such as food. See Issue 526, Charity Contributions.

The difference between the quoted price of goods and the actual price you have to pay for them is called the commercial discount. You must use the price you have to pay (not the quoted price) to determine the cost of your purchase. Please do not present the discount amount separately as an item in your total income. A car dealer must record the cost of a car in stock after deducting any manufacturer's refund that is a commercial discount.

Cash discounts are the amounts that your supplier allows you to deduct from your purchase invoice when you pay early. There are two accounting methods for cash discounts. You can either record them in a separate discount account or deduct them from the total purchase cost for the year. Whichever method you use, you must be consistent. If you want to change the method of calculating inventory costs, you must file Form 3115. For more information, please see Changing Accounting Methods in Chapter 2. If you record cash discounts in a separate account, you must include this balance in your business income at the end of the tax year. If you use this method, please do not deduct cash discounts from your capital sales.

If you withdraw goods for personal or family use, you must exclude this cost from the total cost of the goods you have purchased for sale. Do this by posting in your purchase or sale account the cost of the goods you withdraw for personal use. You must also include this amount in your withdrawal account. The withdrawal account is a separate account that you should keep to record the business income that you withdraw to pay for personal and family expenses. As mentioned above, you also use it to record withdrawals of goods for personal or family purposes. This account is also called a withdrawal account or personal account.

Labour costs are usually a part of the capital cost of sales, but this is only true in manufacturing or mining enterprises. Small merchants (wholesale, retail, etc.) usually have no labour costs that can be reasonably included in the capital cost of sales. In a manufacturing enterprise, labour costs are reasonably allocated to the capital cost of sales, including both the direct and indirect labour used to manufacture raw materials into a complete and sellable product.

Other labor costs not included in the capital price of the sales can be deducted from the sales cost or the management cost of the business. Typically, the only types of labor costs that can be reasonably included in your capital price of the sales are direct or indirect labor costs and some other costs that are considered as general costs that are reasonably included in the production process as discussed in Line 39, Other costs.

Materials and materials, such as hardware and chemicals, used in the production of goods are included in the cost of capital of the goods sold. Things not used in the production process are considered as late payment charges. You deduct them as a business expense when you use them. Business expenses are discussed in Chapter 8.
Below are examples of other costs incurred in the process of production or mining that you do not include in your capital price of sale.

The boxes and packaging that are a component of the product that is produced account for a portion of your capital cost of sale. If they are not a component of the product that is produced, then their cost is either the cost of transportation or the cost of sale.

The cost of transportation, express and road freight for the raw materials and materials you use in production as well as the goods you buy for sale are all part of the capital cost of the goods you sell.

General costs include costs such as rent, heating, lighting, electricity, insurance, depreciation, taxes, maintenance, labor and supervision. The general costs you pay as direct and necessary costs of the production operation are included in the capital price of your business.

Take the value of your end-of-year inventory (including the allocable parts of the cost of materials and materials, direct labor and general costs if applicable) and deduct it in line 40. Your end-of-year inventory is also called your end-of-year inventory. Your end-of-year inventory will usually become your start-of-year inventory in the following tax year.
When you take end-of-period inventory (end-of-year inventory) minus the cost of the capital goods available for sale, the sign of this calculation is your capital goods price in the tax year.

After you have calculated the combined revenue from your business activities (step 5) and the cost of capital of sale (step 6), you are ready to calculate your total profit. You must determine the combined profit before you can deduct any business costs. These costs are discussed in chapter 8.

Calculate your aggregate profit by calculating your net sales first. Calculate your net sales (row 3) in Table C by subtracting any returns and discounts (row 2) from your aggregate sales (row 1). Returns and discounts include cash or booked repayments you make to customers, refunds and discounts other than the actual sales price. Next, subtract the capital cost of the sales (row 4) from your net sales (row 3). The result is your aggregate profit from your business activities.

You do not have to calculate the cost of capital of sales if the sale of goods is not a factor in generating income for your business. Your aggregate profit is equal to your net sales (aggregate sales minus any refunds, rebate or other discounts). Most industries and businesses that sell services rather than products can calculate aggregate profit directly from net sales in this way.
An illustrative example of the gross profit portion in the income statement of a retail business shows how gross profit is calculated.

At the end of each business day, please ensure that your ledger is balanced with cash receipts and is actually recorded during the day. You may find it helpful to use a cash calculator to track receipts. You should also use a suitable billing system and maintain a separate bank account for your business.

Check to ensure that your documents correctly represent the amount of consumption tax collected. If state and local consumption tax is collected on you as a seller of goods or services from buyers, you must include the amount collected in the combined sales. If state and local taxes are collected on buyers and transferred to the state or local government, you usually do not count these as income, as they are not collected from the buyer.
Compare this number with the end of the year inventory of the previous year. The two numbers should usually be the same.

If you take any goods from the warehouse for your own personal use (for yourself, for your family or as a personal gift, etc.), please ensure that they are removed from the capital price of the goods. For details on how to adjust the capital price of the goods, see Unsold withdrawn goods in chapter 6.

Check to ensure that your inventory check procedures are complete. These procedures must ensure that all items have been counted into the inventory and that appropriate pricing techniques have been used. Use the inventory form and roll-up paper as the only evidence for your inventory. The inventory forms are available at office supplies stores. These forms have columns for recording the description, quantity, unit price and value of each item in the inventory. Each page has space to record who performed the check, who valued the items, who performed the quantity and unit price operations and who made the calculations. These forms will help you verify that the total cost of the inventory calculated is accurate. They will also provide you with a durable document to support its legal value. Inventory is discussed in chapter 2.

If you are a retail or wholesale business, you can check the accuracy of your total profit calculation. First, divide your total profit by your net sales. The percentage you get is a measure of the average difference between the capital cost of the sale and the sales price. Next, compare this percentage to your sales-to-capital difference policy. No or a small difference between these two percentages indicates that your total profit is accurate. A large difference between these percentages may indicate that you have not calculated correctly the sales sales, purchase costs, inventory or other cost items. You should identify the reason for the difference.

You run a retail business. On average, you set the selling price higher than the capital cost of the goods so that the total profit realized is 331/3% of the sales. Net sales (total sales minus returns and discounts) shown on your income statement is $300,000. Your capital cost of the goods sold is $200,000. This results in a total profit of $100,000 ($300,000 − $200,000). To check the accuracy of this year's result, you divide the total profit ($100,000) by net sales ($300,000). The result is 331/3% confirming that your percentage set of the difference between the selling price and the capital cost of 331/3% is correct.

If your business has income from a source other than its normal business activities, please enter that income in line 6 of Schedule C and add it to the total profit. The result is the total business income. Examples include income from interest-bearing checking accounts, income from scrap sale, income from certain tax credits and fuel tax refunds, as well as the amounts recovered from bad debt.

You can deduct expenses incurred in operating your business. These expenses are called business expenses. These are expenses that you do not have to capitalize or include in the capital value of your sales but can be deducted in the current year. To be deductible, a business expense must be a customary necessity. A common necessity is a common and accepted expense in your business. A necessary expense is an expense that is useful and appropriate to your business. An expense does not have to be mandatory to be considered necessary. For more information on the general rules for deducting business expenses, see section 162 and the regulations. If you have an expense of which part is for business activities and part for personal purposes, please separate the personal purposes portion from the business portion. The personal purposes portion is not deductible.

The SEP and SIMPLE programs as well as the eligible programs provide you and your employees with a tax-favorable way to save for retirement. You can deduct your own contributions to the program for your employees on line 19 of Schedule C. If you are a sole proprietorship, you can deduct your own contributions to the program for yourself on line 16 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). You can also deduct trustee fees if they are not counted against your contributions to the program. Income from contributions is usually tax-free until you or your employee receives distributions from the program. You can also request a tax credit if you initiate a designated benefit program or a qualified designated contribution program (including a 401(k) program), SIMPLE or SEP. For details on this tax credit and tax credits for automatic enrollment and spouse participation in the military, see Form 8881 and its separate instructions. Under some programs, employees may require you to contribute limited amounts of money that are part of the untaxable amount they pay to a program. These amounts (and income from them) are usually tax-free until your employee receives distributions from the program. For more information on small business retirement programs, see Form 560. Form 590-A, Contributing to a Personal Retirement Account (IRA), which discusses other tax-favorable ways to save for retirement.

Rent is any amount you pay for the use of an asset that you do not own. Normally, you can only deduct rent as a business expense if the rent is for an asset that you use in your business. If you own the asset or will receive ownership or title to it, you cannot deduct rent.

If you rent a house and use part of your own home as a business location, you can deduct the rent paid for that part. You must meet the requirements of using the house for business purposes. For more information, see Using the house for business purposes below.

Usually, rent paid in your business is deducted in the year that the amount is paid or accrued. If you pay rent in advance, you can only deduct the amount applicable to the use of your leased property in the tax year. You can only deduct the remaining part of your payment for the period that this amount applies.
You can deduct in Schedule C federal, state, local and other taxes on income earned from abroad that are directly attributable to your business activities.

You may deduct in Schedule C a type of state tax on gross income (as distinct from net income) directly attributable to your business activity. You may deduct other state and local income taxes in Schedule A (Form 1040) if you list your deductions. Please do not deduct federal income tax.

You can deduct social security, Medicare, and FUTA taxes that you have paid out of your own pocket as an employer. Labour taxes are discussed briefly in Chapter 1. You can also deduct payments that you have made as an employer to the state unemployment fund or to the state disability welfare fund. Please deduct these payments as tax.
You can deduct half of your self-employment tax on line 15 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).

You may deduct in Schedule C any tax imposed by the state or local government on personal property used in your business activities. You may also deduct the registration fee for the right of use of property within the scope of a state or local area.

You may deduct in Schedule C the real estate tax you pay on your business property. Deductible real estate tax is any state, local or foreign income tax applied to real estate that is allocated for public benefit in general. The tax authority must rate these taxes uniformly at the same rate for all real estate under its jurisdiction and the amount collected must be allocated for the general purposes of the community or government.

Please consider any consumption tax you pay for a service or for the purchase or use of a property as part of the cost of that service or property. If the service or cost or the use of the property is a deductible business expense, you may deduct the tax as part of that service or expense. If the property is a good purchased for resale, consumption tax is part of the cost of that good. If the property is depreciable, please add consumption tax to the base value to calculate the depreciation. For information on the base value of the property, see Form 551. No deduction of state and local consumption taxes charged to the buyer that you must collect and pay to the state or local government. These taxes are not included in the combined sales or total sales revenue.
You may deduct in Schedule C all taxes that are expenses normally required to carry out your business. The taxes are discussed briefly in Chapter 1.

Taxes on gasoline, diesel and other motor fuels that you use in your business are usually included as part of your fuel costs. Please do not deduct these taxes on a separate basis. You may be entitled to a tax credit or refund for federal taxes you have paid on fuel used for certain specific purposes. For more information, see Form 510.

Typically, the taxable place is the place where you do your daily business, regardless of where your family lives. The taxable place includes the entire city or neighbourhood where your business is based. See Issue 463 for more information. Below is a brief discussion of the expenses you can deduct.

Generally, you can deduct the amount you reimburse your employees for travel and meals. The amount of reimbursement you deduct and how you do this depends in part on whether you reimburse the expenses under a liability or non-liability program. For more details, see Issue 15. This issue explains liability programs as well as non-liability programs and tells you whether or not to report reimbursements on your employees' Form W-2.
You can deduct the cost of travel by air, train, bus or car between your home and the place of your business.

You can deduct the fare for these as well as other types of transportation when travelling between the airport or train station and your hotel, or between your hotel and your work location away from home by train.

You can deduct the costs of operating and maintaining a vehicle when travelling away for business purposes. You can deduct the actual cost or standard rate of payment per mile (discussed earlier in Car and Truck Charges), as well as highway and parking charges related to business. If you rent a car when travelling away for business purposes, you can only deduct the part of the cost used for business purposes.

To deduct expenses related to the part of your home used for business purposes, you must meet specific requirements. Even then, your deduction may be limited. If you want to qualify for expenses related to the use of your home for business purposes, you must meet the following criteria. 1. Your use of your home for business purposes must be: 1. Exclusive (however, see Exceptions to Exclusive Use below), 2. Regular and 3. Serving your business activities. 2. The part of your home used for business purposes must be: 1. Your main business location (defined below); 2. Where you meet or deal with patients, customers or consumers in the course of your normal business activities; or 3. A separate structure (not attached to your home) that you use in connection with your business activities.

To qualify for the exclusive use criterion, you must use a specific area of your home exclusively for your own business or commerce. The area used for business purposes may be a room or another clearly separated space. That space does not always have to be separated by a partition. You do not meet the requirements of the exclusive use criterion if you use the area not clearly for both business and private purposes.
For an explanation of these exceptions, see Issue 587, Home Use for Business Purposes.

To qualify for the regular use criterion, you must regularly use a particular area of the home for business purposes. You do not meet this criterion if the business use of that area is only occasional or incidental, even if you do not use that area for any other purpose.

If after considering your business locations, your home cannot be identified as your main business location, then you cannot deduct home office expenses. However, for other ways to qualify for home office expenses, see Form 587.
Please do not count in (2) above the deduction for half of your self-employed tax. Use Form 8829, Cost of using housing for business purposes to calculate your deduction.

The IRS provides a simplified method for determining your expenses for using your home for business purposes. The simplified method is an alternative method to calculating and proving actual expenses. In most cases, you will calculate your deduction by multiplying $5 by the size of the home used for business purposes that qualifies. The size you use to calculate your deduction is limited to 300 square feet. For more information, see the Guide to Schedule C.
For more information on the deduction of the cost of using a home for business purposes, see Publication 587.

Normally, you must capitalize the costs of acquiring or producing real or personal tangible property that is used in your commercial or business activities, such as buildings, equipment, or furniture. However, if you choose to use the minimum safe harbor rule for tangible assets, you may deduct the minimum amount paid to acquire or produce certain tangible assets if you deduct such amounts for financial accounting purposes or for the purpose of keeping books and records. If an appropriate financial statement is available, you may use this safe harbor rule to deduct payments for tangible assets up to $5,000 per item or receipt. If no financial statement is available, you may use the minimum safe harbor rule to deduct payments for tangible assets up to $2,500 per item or receipt. Qualifying amounts under this minimum safe harbor rule should be included as other expenses in Part V of Schedule C.
For details on the implementation of this option as well as the requirements for the use of the minimum safe harbor provisions for tangible assets, see the Regulations for Tangible Assets.

You can also deduct the following expenses. Advertising. Bank fees. Donations to business organizations. Educational expenses. Costs related to breakdowns. Interview fee allowances. Licensing fees and statutory fees. Moving machinery. Re-employment assistance services for employees. Fines and penalties you pay for late performance or non-performance of contracts. Repair and maintenance of real or personal property. Repayment of income. Materials and materials. Public utilities.

You can not usually deduct the following items as business expenses. Disclosure and repayment. Contributions to charity. Costs or losses from demolition. Fees of business, social, sports, lunch, sports, air and hotel. Entertainment expenses. Costs of improvement of real or personal real property. Improvement costs are the amounts paid for improvements to property, restoration of property or re-adaptation of property to suit new or different uses. Corridor campaign costs. Fines and penalties you have to pay to government or authorized bodies because you have violated the law. Personal, living and family expenses. Political contributions. Payments or settlements involving sexual harassment or abuse if the settlement or payment is in accordance with an undisclosed agreement. You can not deduct the legal fees associated with such settlement or payment.

If someone owes you money that you cannot recover, you have a bad debt. There are two types of bad debt — business bad debt and non-business bad debt. Business bad debt is generally a debt that comes from your business or business activities. You can deduct business bad debt as an expense on your business tax return.

A debt is closely related to your business if the main motive for incurring the debt is a business reason. Business bad debt is primarily the result of selling to customers. Business bad debt can also be the result of loans to suppliers, customers, employees or distributors. Goods and services for which customers have not paid are presented in your books as receivables or bills of exchange. If you cannot collect any part of these receivables or bills of exchange, the uncollectable part is business bad debt. You can deduct bad debt for these receivables and bills of exchange only if the amount owed is included in your total income for the year the deduction is requested or for a previous year.

If you request a deduction for a bad debt on your income tax return and then recover all or part of that debt, you may have to include all or part of the recovery in your total income. The amount you include is limited to the amount you actually deduct. However, you can exclude the deducted amount without reducing your tax. Report the recovery as "Other Income" on the appropriate form or business return. See Recoveries in Form 525 for more information.

If the bad debt allowance that increases the transfer NOL has not expired before the beginning of the tax year in which the repayment takes place, you treat the allowance as having reduced your tax. The bad debt allowance contributes to the NOL and reduces your tax in the year in which you transfer the NOL. For more information on NOL for individuals, see Issue 536. Also, see the Instructions for Form 1045 and the Instructions for Form 1139.
For more information on bad business debt, see section 166 and its provisions.

All other bad debt is non-business bad debt and is deducted as short-term capital loss on Form 8949 and Schedule D (Form 1040). For more information on non-business bad debt, see Section 166 and its provisions.
If you use the accrual accounting method, you will usually report income as it is earned. You can offset bad debt for an uncollectible receivable if you have added the uncollectible amount to income.
If you use the cash-in method, you usually report income when you receive payments. You cannot offset bad debt for unpaid debt and cannot track it if you have never included it in income.

If you sell your business but still retain receivables, these receivables are business receivables because they arise from your trade or business. If any receivables subsequently become worthless, the loss is still a bad business debt.

The characteristics of a loss from the debts of a business acquired from the deceased are determined in the same way as debts acquired when buying a business. The executor of the deceased's estate treats any loss from debts as a bad business debt if the debts are closely related to the trade or business of the deceased when they become worthless. Otherwise, a loss from these debts will become a non-business bad debt for the deceased's estate.
If you liquidate your business and some of the receivables you keep become worthless, they will be considered bad business debt.
If you borrow money to customers, suppliers, employees or distributors for business reasons and you cannot collect the loan after trying to do so, you have a bad business debt.

If a political party (or other organization that accepts contributions or spends money to influence elections) owes you money and the debt becomes worthless, you can only request a bad debt offset if all of the following requirements are met. 1. You use an accrual accounting method. 2. The debt arises from the sale of goods or services in the normal course of your trade or business. 3. More than 30% of your receivables accrued in the year of sale are from sales to political parties. 4. You have made significant and sustained efforts to collect the debt.
You cannot claim bad debt deduction for a loan you have made to a company if, based on the facts and circumstances, the loan was actually a contribution to the company's capital.

If your business partner goes bankrupt and one of your former partners becomes insolvent, you may have to pay more than the proportion of the partner's share of the debt. If you pay any part of the insolvent partner's share of the debt, you may request a bad debt deduction for the amount you paid as a portion of the insolvent partner's share.

If you guarantee a debt that later becomes worthless, the debt may qualify as bad business debt if all of the following requirements are met. You have guaranteed in the course of your business or business. You have a legal obligation to pay the debt. You have made the guarantee before the debt became worthless. You meet this requirement if you reasonably expect that you will not be required to pay the debt without full repayment from the borrower. You have received reasonable consideration to make the guarantee. You meet this requirement if you make the guarantee in the ordinary course of business or for good faith business purposes.
If you make a payment for a loan that you secure, you can deduct it in the year it is paid, unless you have a right against the borrower.

When you pay off a loan that you secure, you may have a right to substitute for the lender. The amount owed is then yours. If you have this right, or some other right to demand payment from the borrower, you cannot demand a deduction for bad debt until these rights become partly or completely worthless.
If two or more debtors jointly owe you money, the fact that you are unable to collect money from one debtor does not allow you to deduct a corresponding amount as bad debt.
If the mortgaged or pledged property is sold at a lower price than the debt, the unpaid, uncollectible balance of the debt is a bad debt.

A debt becomes null when there is no longer any chance that the amount owed will be paid. This can happen on or before the due date. To prove nullity, you only have to prove that you have taken reasonable steps to collect the debt but could not do so.

If you receive an asset to settle part of the debt, deduct the debt by the FMV of the asset, it becomes the original value of the asset. You can offset the remaining debt as a bad debt if and when it becomes worthless. If you then sell the asset at a higher price than its original value, any profit from the sale is due to the high valuation of the asset. It is not the recovery of a bad debt. For information on selling an asset, see Issue 544.

Normally, you must use a window-specific deletion method. However, you can use the experience/ non-accumulative method if you meet the requirements discussed below in the Experience/ non-accumulative method section.

If you use the specific depreciation method, you can deduct specific bad debt accounts that have become partly or completely worthless in the tax year. However, for partly worthless bad debt accounts, your deduction is limited to the amount you have included in your book in the year.

You can deduct specific bad debt that is partly uncollectible in the tax year. Your tax deduction is limited to the amount you write off in your book in the year. You do not have to write off and deduct your bad debt annually. You can delay the write-off until a year later. However, you cannot deduct any part of the debt after the year it becomes completely uncollectible. There are two rules concerning written-off debt to consider: Debt is substantially adjusted. An exception to the write-off rule exists for debts that have been substantially adjusted and the owner has recorded profit. For more information, see Rule 1.166-3(a)(3) Unpermitted deductions. Normally, you can request deduction of a portion of bad debt only in the year you write off your book. If, during the review, the IRS does not allow you to deduct and the debt becomes partly uncollectible in a subsequent tax year, you can deduct the amount you wrote off in that year plus the amount that was not allowed to be written off in the previous year. The write-off in the previous year, unless reversed on your book, meets the deduction requirement for the subsequent year.

If a debt becomes totally worthless in the current tax year, you can deduct the entire amount minus any amount deducted in the previous tax year when the debt was only partially worthless. You do not need to perform a real depreciation on your ledger to request bad debt deduction for a totally worthless debt. However, you may want to do so. If you do not do so and the IRS subsequently determines that the debt is only partially worthless, you will not be allowed to deduct for the debt in that tax year because the deduction of a partially worthless bad debt is limited to the amount actually calculated. See Partly Worthless Debt, above.

You may have more time to file your claim if you are unable to manage your financial issues due to a physical or mental disability. Such a disability requires proof of existence. For details and more information on filing a claim, see Form 556. Use one of the following templates to file your claim. For more information, see the instructions for the applicable templates. Table 8-1. Templates used to file claims

If you use a car or truck in your business, you may be eligible for deductions for the cost of operating and maintaining the vehicle. You may also be eligible for deductions for local transportation costs as well as other overnight work costs.

Local business transportation costs do not include costs incurred when travelling away from home overnight. These costs are deducted as travel costs and discussed later in the section Travel and Dining. However, if you use a car when travelling away from home overnight, please use the rules in this section to calculate the deduction of your car costs. Typically, the taxable place is your usual place of business, regardless of where your family is located. The taxable place includes the entire city or area in general where your business or organization is based.
Your workplace may be your home if you have an office in a building that qualifies as the main place of business. For more information, see Using your home for business purposes below.

You can use the standard rate per mile to calculate the deductible cost of travelling by your car, van, van or truck for business purposes. The standard rate per mile for business for the year 2024 is 67 cents per mile. If you choose to use the standard rate per mile for a year, you cannot deduct your actual costs for that year except for parking and highway fees related to business.

If you want to use the standard rate per mile for a car or truck that you own, you must choose to use that rate for the first year that the car can be used in your business. In the following years, you can choose to use the standard rate per mile or the actual cost. If you choose to use the standard rate per mile for a car that you rent, you must use it for the entire rental period (including renewals).

In addition to using the standard rate of payment per mile, you can deduct any parking fees and highway tolls related to your business. (The fee you pay for parking at work is not deductible as commuting costs between home and work.)

Generally, you can deduct the amounts you reimburse to your employees for car and truck expenses. The amount of reimbursement you deduct and how you do it depends in part on whether you reimburse the expenses under a liability or non-liability program. For more details, see Issue 15. This issue explains liability programs as well as non-liability programs and tells you whether or not to report reimbursements on your employees' Form W-2.

If an asset you purchase for use in your business is expected to last for more than one year, you usually cannot deduct the entire cost as a business expense in the year you purchase that asset. You must spread the cost over more than one tax year and deduct a portion of that cost each year in Schedule C. The method of deducting the value of this business asset is called depreciation. Below is a brief overview. You will find more information on depreciation in Issue 946.

You can write off an asset if it meets all of the following requirements. The asset must be owned by you. The asset must be used in business or held to generate income. You can never write off inventory (explained in chapter 2) because it is not held for use in your business. The asset must have a significantly extended useful life after the year it was put into use. The asset must have a determined useful life, meaning that it must be something that is susceptible to wear, decay, wear out, become obsolete or lose value due to natural causes. You can never write off the land value because the land is not worn out, worn out or used to the point of depletion. The asset is not a depreciated asset. This includes assets that are put into use and liquidated in the same year.

Normally, you do not deduct repair or maintenance costs if these costs do not improve your assets. Instead, you deduct these amounts on line 21 of Schedule C. Improvement costs are the amounts paid for improvements to the assets, restoration of the assets or work that makes your assets suitable for a new or different purpose.

You may choose to treat certain repairs or replacements in your business or business operations as depreciable improvements. This option can be made if you consider these amounts as long-term investment expenses on the books and records that are regularly used to calculate your income and expenses.

The method applied to the depreciation of most capital and business assets put into use after 1986 is called the Modified High Price Recovery System (MACRS). MACRS is discussed in detail in Issue 946.

You can choose to deduct a limited amount of the cost of an asset that is depreciable in the year you put it into service. This deduction is called a section 179 deduction. The maximum amount you can choose to deduct in 2024 is usually $1,220,000 (a higher limit applies to certain assets). This limit is usually deducted from the amount that remains when the cost of the asset is put into service in the tax year exceeds $3,050,000. The total amount of depreciation (including the section 179 deduction) that you can charge for a passenger motor vehicle used in your business and first put into service in 2024 is $12,400 ($20,400 if you include the special depreciation allowance for eligible passenger motor vehicles put into service in 2024). Special rules apply to trucks and vans. For more information, see Issue 946. This issue explains which assets qualify for deduction, what limits apply to the deduction, and when and how to recover the deduction. Your section 179 option for the cost of a sports utility vehicle (SUV) and some other types of vehicles is limited to $30,500. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 4562 or Issue 946.

Use Form 4562, Depreciation of Fixed Material Assets and Depreciation of Fixed Immaterial Assets, if you require any of the following. Depreciation for assets put into use in the current tax year. A deduction under section 179. Depreciation for any listed asset (regardless of when it was put into use).
You cannot deduct your own salary or any withdrawals from your business activities for personal purposes. As a sole proprietor, you are not an employee of the company.

Some of the ways you can pay your employees are listed below. Bonuses. Bonuses. Educational expenses. Additional benefits (discussed in the next section). Loans or advances that you do not expect the employee to repay if they are for personal services that have actually been performed. Property you transfer to an employee as a payment for services. Reimbursements for employee work costs. Sick pay. Leave pay.

Generally, you may deduct the cost of the ancillary benefits you provide in Schedule C regardless of what category these costs fall into. For example, if you allow employees to use a car or other property that you rent, please deduct the rent as a rental expense. If you own property, please include a deduction for the original or other basic value of that property as a deduction under section 179 or a deduction for depreciation. You may exclude from the employee's salary all or part of the ancillary benefits you provide. For more information on ancillary benefits and exclusions of benefits, see Form 15-B.

Generally, you can deduct the insurance purchases you make for the following types of insurance related to your business. 1. Fire, theft, flood, or similar insurance. 2. Credit insurance covers losses from bad business debt. 3. Health and collective illness insurance for employees, including long-term care insurance. 4. Liability insurance. 5. Occupational risk insurance covers your personal liability for professional negligence resulting in injury or damage to patients or customers. 6. Employee compensation insurance as provided by state law for any claims for compensation for work-related bodily injury or illness incurred by employees in your business, regardless of the fault that led to the accident. 7. Contributions to the state unemployment insurance fund are deductible in tax form. 8. Total insurance payments for general business expenses that you incur during a long period of injury due to illness or injury. 9. Auto insurance and other insurance for vehicles used in your business operations are deductible in tax form if they are considered taxable under state law. If you use a vehicle partly for personal purposes, please deduct only the part of the insurance purchases that corresponds to the use of the vehicle for business purposes. If you use the standard rate of payment per mile drive to calculate your car costs, you cannot deduct any auto insurance purchases. 10. Life insurance for employees if you are not directly or indirectly the recipient.

You cannot deduct insurance purchases for the following types of insurance. 1. Self-insured reserve funds. You cannot deduct the amounts entered into the reserves set up for the purpose of self-insurance. This applies even if you cannot receive business insurance for certain business risks. However, your actual losses may be deducted. For more information, see Issue 547. 2. Loss of income. You cannot deduct insurance purchases for a contract paying for lost personal income due to illness or injury. However, see item 8 in the previous list. 3. Certain life and annuity insurances. 1. For contracts issued before June 9, 1997, you cannot deduct insurance purchases for your life insurance contract or that of an employee or any person with financial interests in your business if you are the direct or indirect beneficiary of that contract. You are eligible to be among the beneficiaries of the contract if the contract holder is obliged to repay the loan from you with the amount received from the contract. A person with financial interests in your business if that person is the owner or co-owner of the business or has lent money to the business. 2. For contracts issued after June 8, 1997, you are generally not deductible for insurance purchases on any life insurance contract, mixed life insurance contract or annuity insurance contract if you are the direct or indirect beneficiary. The exclusion applies irrespective of the subject matter of the contract. 4. Loan-secured insurance. If you enter into a life insurance contract for yourself or another person with financial interests in the business.
You can deduct the amount paid for health and dental insurance as well as long-term care insurance that meets the standards for you and your family.

See Form 8962 and the specific instructions of the form and use Form 974 if the insurance program that is established, or is deemed to have been established, in your business is received through the Health Insurance Marketplace, and you are claiming a tax credit for the insurance fee.

You cannot deduct any expenses paid in advance, even if they have been paid in advance. This rule applies to any expenses paid in advance early enough to, in principle, create an asset with a significantly longer useful life beyond the end of the current tax year.

Some taxpayers are required to limit the deduction of their business interest expenses. See the Instructions for Form 8990 to determine whether you are required to limit your business interest expense deduction, who is required to file Form 8990 and how some businesses may choose not to limit their business interest expenses. You cannot deduct in Schedule C interest paid on personal loans. If the loan is partly for business purposes and partly for personal purposes, you must divide the interest between the two parts.

Additional items to consider are shown below. How to allocate interest between personal and business purposes. Limits on business interest. Time of interest deduction. Rules for loans with lower than market interest rates. (This is usually an interest-free loan or an interest-bearing loan with a lower rate than the current federal interest rate.)

Legal expenses and professional services expenses, such as accountants' fees, are expenses that are usually necessary for the operation of your business and are deductible in Schedule C. However, you cannot usually deduct legal expenses for the purchase of business assets. Add these fees to the base value of the assets. If the fees include payments for work of a personal nature (such as making a will), you can only deduct as business expenses the portion of the fees that relates to your business.

You may deduct in Form C the costs of preparing that part of the tax return relating to your business activities as a sole proprietor or legal employee. You may also deduct in Form C the amounts payable or incurred in resolving the tax deficiency that has been confirmed for your business as a sole proprietor or legal employee.

For tax purposes, a foreigner is an individual who is not a U.S. citizen. A foreigner is classified as a temporary resident alien and a permanent resident alien. This publication will help you determine your status and provide you with the information you need to file your U.S. tax return. A permanent resident alien is generally subject to tax on global income as a U.S. citizen. A temporary resident alien is subject to tax only on income from sources in the U.S. and on certain income related to the conduct of commercial or business activities in the U.S.
