Suspend part of the Income Tax Convention with the Soviet Union as it relates to Belarus. On December 17, 2024, the United States provided formal notice to the Republic of Belarus of the suspension of part of the Tax Convention with the Soviet Union as it relates to Belarus. The United States suspended the operation of paragraph 1, subparagraph (g), Article 3 of the Convention. The remaining provisions of the Convention will remain in effect. The suspension is effective on December 17, 2024 and will continue until December 31, 2026, or earlier if agreed by the two governments. Suspend part of the Income Tax Convention with Russia. On June 17, 2024, the United States provided formal notice to the Russian Federation of the suspension of part of the Convention with Russia. The United States suspended the operation of paragraph 4, Article 1, Articles 5 to 21, and Article 23 of the Convention, as well as the Agreement. The suspension is effective for both withholding taxes and other taxes on August 16, 2024 and will continue until both governments decide otherwise. Starting with payments made on or after August 16, 2024, discount agents are required to deduct at the statutory 30% discount rate on U.S. withholding income payments made to recipients who may previously qualify for treaty benefits under the U.S.-Russian income tax treaty. The option to treat spouse as a resident or dual resident of the United States. Forms 1040 and 1040-SR have added checkboxes in the section.

Foreign residents (and some permanent residents) from a country with which the United States has an income tax treaty may qualify for certain benefits. Most treaties require that a foreign resident be a permanent resident of the treaty country to qualify for the benefits in the five years following the date of entry into the treaty country. However, in the case of some students, interns, teachers or researchers, some treaties require that the foreign resident be a permanent resident of the treaty country only until the date of entry into the treaty country.

You can access the tax treaty table by visiting IRS.gov/TreatyTables. You can access the text of the U.S. Income Tax Treaty, Regulations and Tax Information Exchange Agreement (TIEA) that has recently been signed and the technical explanations of the customs treaty that accompany it when it is made public as well as in the U.S. The typical Income Tax Conference is at Home.Treasury.gov/Policy-Issues/Tax-Policy/International-Tax. Please note that the treaty and TIEA documents are posted on this website after signing and before ratification and entry into force. The full text of the personal income tax treaty is also available at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. For more information on tax treaties, visit IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Tax-Treaties. In general, you can arrange to be reduced or eliminated from retained taxes on wages and other income that qualifies for the tax treaty. See Income Entitled under Tax Treaty in Chapter 8.

Tax treaty income of a foreign resident is the total income on which tax is limited by the tax treaty. Treaty income includes dividends from sources in the United States subject to treaty tax rate not exceeding 15%. Non-treaty income is the total income of a foreign resident on which tax is not limited by the tax treaty in force. To determine tax on income subject to lower treaty tax rate, tax each income separately at the reduced rate applicable to that income under the treaty. To determine tax on non-treaty income, tax at a flat rate of 30% or a cumulative rate, depending on whether the income is actually related to a trade or business in the United States. Tax liability is the total amount of treaty income tax plus tax on non-treaty income, the tax liability cannot exceed the tax liability as if the tax treaty had not been in force.

The following sections briefly explain the tax treaty exemptions available for income from personal services, remittances, scholarships, research grants and interest income. The terms of the exemption requirements vary by tax treaty. For more information on the terms of specific tax treaties, download the full text of most U.S. tax treaties at IRS.gov/Business/International-Business/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. Technical explanations of many of these treaties are also available on that website. See also the 901 Form. Tax treaty entitlements also include income such as dividends, interest, rent, royalties, pensions and annuities. These types of income may be exempt from U.S. tax or be taxed at a reduced rate. For more information, see the 901 Form or the current tax treaty.

Under most income tax treaties, foreign residents from treaty countries and foreigners with dual status who are obliged to break the treaty bias (see Chapter 1) and are temporarily present in the United States to perform services may qualify for the exemption of some or all of their income from personal services from U.S. taxation if they meet the requirements of certain provisions in the treaty in force.
Some income tax treaties have other requirements such as different maximum periods of presence. For more information, see the 901 section.

Some income tax treaties have "independent personal services" clauses that allow residents of the treaty country to exempt income earned as independent contractors or self-employed individuals from U.S. taxation if they are present in the United States for a period of time not exceeding a certain number of days and if they do not have a permanent base in the United States.

Under many income tax treaties, a teacher or professor is a foreign resident who comes to the United States temporarily for the primary purpose of teaching at a university or other recognized educational institution and is not subject to U.S. income tax on teaching remuneration for the first two or three years after they arrive in the United States. Many treaties also allow tax exemption for research. Generally, a teacher or professor must be in the United States for the primary purpose of teaching, lecture, tutoring or participating in research. A significant portion of that person's time must be devoted to those duties. The typical duties of a teacher or professor include not only formal classroom work related to scheduled lectures, experiments or other activities involving students, but also presenting ideas in seminars or other informal groups and in common efforts in the laboratory. If you entered the United States as a foreign resident but are now a permanent resident, treaty tax exemption may still apply. See Students, Apprentices, Work Apprentices, Teachers, Professors and Researchers Becoming Permanent Residents later in Permanent Residents.

All treaties have provisions for income tax exemption for certain foreign government employees. However, there are differences between treaties as to who is eligible for this benefit. Under many treaties, a foreigner is a permanent resident of the United States who is not eligible. Under most treaties, a foreigner is not a citizen or subject of the foreign country who is not eligible. Foreign government employees should read the relevant treaties carefully to determine whether they are eligible for the benefit. Chapter 10 of this publication contains information on some foreign government employees.

Under some income tax treaties, students, apprentices and trainees are exempt from tax on money received from abroad for their studies and subsistence. In addition, under some treaties, scholarships and research grants and certain limited remuneration received by students, apprentices and trainees may be exempt from tax. If you have entered the United States as a temporary alien resident but are currently a permanent alien, the treaty exemption may still apply. See Student, Apprentice, Apprentice, Teacher, Professor and Researcher Becoming a Permanent Alien later in the section Permanent Alien.
Most treaties allow tax exemption on gains from the sale or exchange of personal property. Gains from the sale or exchange of real estate in the United States may be taxed.
A foreign resident may qualify for benefits under a tax treaty in the situations discussed below.

A foreign resident is not eligible for tax treaty benefits because most tax treaties have "saving clauses" to preserve or "save" the U.S. right to tax citizens and residents as if the tax treaty had not been in force. However, many tax treaties have exceptions to the saving clauses. This may allow a foreign resident to continue claiming tax treaty benefits. Some exceptions to the saving clauses apply to all foreign residents (e.g. under the U.S.-China treaty); other exceptions apply only to foreign residents who are not legal residents of the U.S. (green card holders). In some cases, you do not need to report income on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR because the income will be exempt from U.S. tax under the treaty. However, if the income has been declared as taxable income on Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099 or a return providing other information, you should report this income on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR (e.g. line 1a in the case of a salary or wages being reported in box 1 of Form W-2). Fill in the amount of income that the tax treaty benefits are required to cover (in parentheses) on Table 1 (Form 1040), line 8z. Enter "Exempt income," the name of the treaty country and the terms of the treaty allowing the exemption. For income reduced instead of exempt under the treaty, attach a report with Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR.

Under the income tax treaty between Canada and Germany, if a U.S. resident receives social security benefits from Canada or Germany, those benefits will be treated for purposes of U.S. income tax as if they were received under U.S. social security law. If you receive social security benefits from Canada or Germany, include them in line 1 of the Social Security Entitlement Benefits Calculation Table in the Instructions for Form 1040 to determine the taxable amount shown on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, line 6b. You do not have to file Form 8833 for these benefits.

Generally, you must be a student, apprentice, trainee, teacher, professor, or researcher who is a permanent alien to claim treaty tax exemption for deposits from abroad for study and living in the United States, scholarships, research grants, and salaries or other remuneration for personal services. After you become a permanent alien, you may no longer claim this treaty income tax exemption. However, if you enter the United States as a temporary alien but are currently a permanent alien for U.S. tax purposes, the treaty exemption will continue to apply if the treaty savings clause (explained in the previous section) is exempted and you do not meet the treaty exemption requirement (including any time limits on claiming treaty tax exemption, explained below). This is true even if you are a permanent alien who elects to file a tax return as explained in Chapter 1. If you qualify for the treaty savings clause exemption, you may avoid income tax deduction by providing the payer with a Form W-9 accompanied by the mandatory report as instructed in the Form W-9.

Many treaties limit the number of years you can claim tax exemption under the treaty. For students, trainees and apprentices, the limit is usually 4-5 years. For teachers, professors and researchers, the limit is usually 2-3 years. After you reach this limit, you can no longer claim tax exemption under the treaty. See the treaty or the 901 form for the time limits that apply.

In some cases, you do not need to report income on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR because the income will be exempt from U.S. tax under the treaty. However, if the income has been declared as taxable income on Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099 or other information-providing forms, you should report this income on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR (e.g. line 1a, the amount reported in box 1 of Form W-2). Fill in the amount that the tax treaty entitlement is required on Table 1 (Form 1040), line 8z. Enter "Exempt income," the name of the treaty country and the terms of the treaty allowing the exemption.

If you claim rights under a treaty that overrides or amends any provision of the Tax Code and by claiming these rights, the amount of tax you pay will or may be reduced, you must attach a completed Form 8833 with your tax return. See Exceptions below for the situations in which you do not have to file Form 8833.

You do not have to file Form 8833 for any of the following situations. 1. You request treaty deductions on interest, dividends, rent, royalties or other FDAP income, which is usually taxed at 30%. 2. You request treaty deductions or adjustments on income from personal services rendered to others, pensions, annuities, social security and other public pensions, or income of artists, athletes, students, businessmen or teachers. This includes taxable scholarships and research grants. 3. You request income tax deductions or adjustments under an International Social Security Agreement or Foreign Trade or Consular Treaty. 4. You are a partner in a partnership or a beneficiary of a legacy or trust and the partnership, legacy or trust declares the required information on the tax return. 5. The payment or income is required to be disclosed in a total amount not exceeding $10,000. 6. You are claiming treaty entitlements for money: 1. Declared to you on Form 1042-S; and 2. Received by you: 1. As a related party of the company declared within the meaning of section 6038A (regarding the return information on Form 5472 filed by a U.S. company owned 25% by a foreigner), or 2. As a beneficial owner of a direct account with a U.S. financial institution or a qualified intermediary organization or as a direct partner, beneficiary or owner of a treaty deduction foreign partnership or trust, from a U.S. financial institution.

Employees of an international organization may be exempt from tax on wages by a provision (if any) in the international agreement creating the international organization or by meeting the requirements for exemption of that wage under U.S. tax law. An "international" organization is an organization designated by the President of the United States through an Executive Order to qualify for the privileges, preferences and exemptions set forth in the International Organizations Exemption Act. The exemptions discussed in this chapter apply only to wages from official service rendered to a foreign government or international organization. Other income originating in the United States of the eligible exempted person may be taxed in full or benefit from tax exemptions under the terms of the applicable tax treaty. The appropriate treatment of such income (interest, dividends, etc.) is discussed earlier in this publication.

First, you should check the Vienna Convention tax exemption terms or the bilateral consular treaty (if any) to see if your salary qualifies for exemption from U.S. income tax under those terms. First, you should check the Vienna Convention tax exemption terms or the bilateral consular treaty (if any) to see if your salary qualifies for exemption from U.S. income tax under those terms. For more information on the Vienna Convention and the bilateral consular treaty, please email the Office of Foreign Affairs of the Department of State at OFMAssistants@state.gov.

If you are not eligible for tax exemption under the Vienna Convention or a bilateral consular treaty, but you are from a country that has a tax treaty with the United States, you should check the tax treaty for any provisions that exempt you from U.S. income tax. If you are a U.S. citizen or a permanently resident foreigner working for a foreign government in the United States, your salary is usually not exempt from tax. For more information, see Wages and Pensions Paid by a Foreign Government in Form 901.

Foreign government employees who do not qualify under the tax exemption provisions of one of the Vienna Conventions, bilateral consular treaties or tax treaties may be exempt from foreign government income tax if they meet the requirements for exemption from subsequent salary tax under U.S. tax law. The exemption under U.S. tax law only applies to current foreign government employees and does not apply to former employees. Pensions received by former foreign government employees living in the U.S. do not qualify for tax exemption are discussed here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. The rules in the Ordinance apply to determining whether you are an employee or an independent contractor. See Section 1779 and Section 15-A.. Unqualified salary is exempt from tax under U.S. tax law if you are employed by a "controlled commercial organization" or your services are primarily related to the business activities of the foreign government (in or outside the U.S. territory). A controlled commercial organization is an organization owned by 50% (0.50) or more of the foreign government and engaged in business activities within or outside the U.S. territory.

However, see Foreigners Maintaining Immigration Status (Legal Residents) in the following section for special rules that may affect eligibility for this tax exemption. To claim a tax exemption, you must prove that you meet both the requirements of U.S. tax law and the requirements of the U.S. tax code.

A State Department certificate (if available) is the easiest way to confirm that you meet the requirements for similar services and equivalent exemptions, but is not required to qualify for exemptions under U.S. tax law. To find out whether a certificate has been issued and whether it is currently valid and applicable to you, please email the Office of Foreign Affairs of the State Department at OFMAssistants@state.gov. In the absence of a valid certificate, you must provide other written evidence that you are performing services of a similar nature to those performed by U.S. government employees abroad and that the employer's foreign government is exempt from the equivalent tax on foreign government employees performing similar services in the country of origin.

There are many international organizational agreements that have provisions for exempting your salary from U.S. income tax. If you are working for an international organization in the United States, first determine whether the international organizational agreement where you work has such provisions and whether you qualify under those provisions. These provisions will usually not exempt U.S. citizens and permanent foreign residents from salary tax.

If the international agreement establishing the international organization where you work does not contain a tax exemption clause and you are not a U.S. citizen (or if you are a U.S. citizen but also a Filipino citizen) then you may be eligible for tax exemption on your salary under U.S. tax law. However, see Foreigners Maintaining Immigration Status (Legal Residents) below for special rules that may affect eligibility for this tax exemption. The exemption under U.S. tax law only applies to current employees of the foreign organization and does not apply to former employees. Pensions that former employees of the foreign organization living in the U.S. do not qualify for tax exemption are discussed here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. The rules in the Ordinance apply to determining whether you are an employee or an independent contractor. See Issue 1779 and Issue 15-A. To claim tax exemption, you must prove that you meet the requirements of the international organization treaty's tax exemption clause or U.S. tax law. You should know the tax exemption clause number of the international organization treaty (if any) and the Executive Order number designating the organization as an international organization.

If you sign a waiver under section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (USCIS Form I-508) to maintain your legal resident status (green card), you will no longer be eligible for tax exemption under U.S. tax law as of the date of filing the waiver. If you are a foreign government or international organization employee with a green card, to claim tax exemption under U.S. tax law, you must also provide written evidence from USCIS that you have not signed and filed a USCIS Form I-508.

Before leaving the United States, all foreigners (except those listed in Foreigners Do Not Need a Leave or Exit Permit) must have a compliance certificate. This document is also often referred to as a Leave or Exit Permit and is part of the income tax form you must file before leaving. You will receive a Leave or Exit Permit after filing either Form 1040-C or Form 2063. These forms are discussed in this chapter. To find out whether you need a Leave or Exit Permit, please first read Foreigners Do Not Need a Leave or Exit Permit, later. If you do not fall under one of the cases in that discussion, you must have a Leave or Exit Permit. Read Foreigners Do Not Need a Leave or Exit Permit, later.

If you fall under one of the following cases, you do not need a departure or exit permit before leaving the United States. If you fall under one of these cases and do not have a departure or exit permit, you must be able to support your tax exemption request with appropriate identification or a proxy for tax exemption.
The return must be filed at the IRS Taxpayer Assistance Center (TAC) office in the city of Lahore.

If you are an alien in either category (1) or (2) above, and you are a waiver applicant under section 247(b) of the Immigration and Naturalization Act, you must have a permit to leave or depart. This is true even if your income is exempt from U.S. taxation under an income tax treaty, consular agreement, or international agreement.

Students are foreign nationals, industrialists and trade guests, including their spouses and children, who enter the United States only on an "F-1," "F-2," "H-3," "H-4," "J-1," "J-2," or "Q" visa and who receive no income from sources in the United States while in the United States on such visas other than: Allowance to cover expenses related to study or training in the United States, such as travel, living and tuition costs; The value of any services or food and lodging related to such study or training; Income from employment authorized by USCIS; or Income from interest on deposits not actually connected with commercial or business activities in the United States. See Interest Income in Chapter 3.)

Students are foreign nationals, including their spouses and children, who enter the United States only on an "M-1" or "M-2" visa and who do not receive any income from sources in the United States while in the United States on those visas other than: Income from employment authorized by USCIS, or Income from interest on deposits not directly related to commercial or business activities in the United States. (See Interest Income in Chapter 3 only.)

Other foreigners who are temporarily present in the United States do not receive taxable income in the tax year up to and including the date of departure or in the previous tax year. If the IRS has reason to believe that the foreigner has received taxable income and the collection of income tax may be affected when they leave, the IRS may require the foreigner to apply for a permit to leave or to leave. This includes: 1. Military trainees are foreigners entering the United States for training under the auspices of the Department of Defense and those leaving the United States under an official military movement order; 2. Foreign visitors on a “B-1” or both “B-1” and “B-2” visa who do not stay in the United States or U.S. territories for more than 90 days in the tax year; 3. Foreign visitors on a “visa” B-2 for leisure purposes; 4. Foreign visitors transiting through the United States or any U.S. territory on a “C-1” visa or under a contract, such as a bond agreement, between a shipping company and the Secretary of Justice; and 5. Foreign visitors entering the United States on a cross-border ID card or without a passport, visa or cross-border ID card, if they are: 1. Visitors for leisure purposes, 2. Visitors on business purposes who do not stay in the United States or U.S. territories for more than 90 days in the tax year; or 3. Foreign visitors transiting through the United States or any U.S. territory.
A Canadian or Mexican resident is a foreigner who regularly travels between that country and the United States in search of employment and whose wages are subject to U.S. tax deductions.

If you do not fall under one of the cases listed in Foreigners Do Not Need a Permit to Leave or Depart, you must have a permit to leave or depart. To obtain a permit, file Form 1040-C or Form 2063 (whichever applies) at the TAC office where you reside before you leave the United States. See Forms to File below. You must also file all taxes listed as due on Form 1040-C and any taxes due in previous years. See Tax Refunds and Receiving Taxes below.

To apply for a compliance certificate, you must go to the TAC office at least two weeks before you leave the United States and file Form 2063 or Form 1040-C and any other outstanding mandatory tax returns. The certificate is issued no later than 30 days before you leave. If both you and your spouse are foreigners and both are leaving the United States, you must both go to the TAC office. Please note that all TAC offices operate on an appointment basis. You can call 844-545-5640 between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. local time to make an appointment. For more information about your local TAC office, visit IRS.gov/TAC.

The process of applying for a departure or exit permit will be expedited if you bring the following documents and documents related to your income and time of stay in the United States to the IRS office. Bring the following documents if applicable. 1. Passport and Foreigner Registration Card or Visa. 2. A copy of your U.S. income tax returns filed in the last two years. If you have been in the United States for less than two years, bring the income tax returns you have filed in that period. 3. Income tax returns paid on these returns. 4. Receipts, bank records, cancelled cheques and other documents proving deductions, business and dependent expenses declared on the tax return. 5. Statements from each employer stating the wages paid and taxes deducted from January 1 of the current year to the date of departure if you are an employee. If you are self-employed, you must bring income and expense returns up to the date of your planned departure. 6. Proof of tax payments estimated for the previous and current year. 7. Documentation showing any interest or losses from the sale of personal property and/or real estate, including capital property and goods. 8. Documentation related to scholarships or research grants, including the following: 1. Identification of the grant recipient, source and purpose of the grant. 2. Copy of the grant application and approval. 3. Statement of the amount paid and your obligations associated with the grant. 4. List of any previous grants. 9. Documentation stating that you are eligible for any special tax treaty benefits requested. 10. Documentation verifying the date of departure.

If you are required to apply for a departure or exit permit, you must file either Form 2063 or Form 1040-C. Both forms have a “compliance certificate” section. When the compliance certificate is signed by the representative of the Director of the Field Support Area, that certificate confirms that your U.S. tax obligations have been met according to the available information. A signed Form 1040-C copy of the certificate or a separate copy of Form 2063 is the departure or exit permit.

A foreigner who is one of these two subjects who has not filed income tax or has paid income tax in any taxable year must file and pay income tax before they are issued a permit to leave or depart on Form 2063. A permit to leave or depart separate from Form 2063 may be used for all departures in the current year. However, the IRS may cancel the permit to leave or depart for any subsequent departure if it considers that the collection of income tax is affected by the subsequent departure.

If you are required to file a departure or exit permit and do not qualify for Form 2063, you must file Form 1040-C. Normally, all income received or reasonably expected to be received in the tax year up to and including the date of departure must be declared on Form 1040-C and taxes payable. When you file any taxes by the deadline specified on Form 1040-C and you file all returns and all taxes in previous years, you will receive a departure or exit permit. However, the IRS may allow you to pay the bond in lieu of tax for a certain number of years. See Bond Guarantee Payments in the section below. A departure or exit permit is issued under the terms of this paragraph only for the specific departure for which the permit is issued.

If you provide the IRS with information that you intend to return to the United States and your departure does not impede income tax collection, you may obtain a departure or exit permit by filing Form 1040-C without paying the tax listed on it. However, you must file all outstanding income tax returns as requested and all income tax due by the date listed on this form. The Form 1040-C must include all income received and reasonably expected to be received during the year of departure. The departure or exit permit is issued and Form 1040 can be used for all departures in the current year. However, the IRS may cancel the departure or exit permit for any subsequent departures if the payment of income tax appears to be impeded.

A husband and wife who are both resident foreigners cannot file jointly. However, if both spouses are resident foreigners, they may file jointly on Form 1040-C if: Both spouses are expected to qualify for joint taxation at the end of their regular taxation year and the spouses' taxation years end at the same time.

You must pay all the taxes that are due on Form 1040-C at the time of filing, unless a bond is provided or the IRS is satisfied that your departure does not affect the collection of income tax. You must also pay taxes due in previous years. If taxes on Form 1040-C result in overpayment, you do not have to pay any taxes at the time of filing. However, the IRS cannot refund taxes at the time of departure. If you are due for a refund, you must file Form 1040-NR at the end of the tax year.

You are usually required to pay the tax due on Form 1040-C when you file this form. However, if you have filed all the tax due in previous years, you may provide a bond to secure payment instead of paying the income tax due on Form 1040-C or the tax return for the previous year if the filing period has not expired. The bond must be equal to the tax due plus interest as of the date of payment as specified by the IRS. You can get information on the bond and the guarantee from the TAC office.

Form 1040-C is not an annual U.S. income tax return. If an income tax return is not required by law, that tax return must be filed even if Form 1040-C has been filed. Chapters 5 and 7 discuss filing an annual U.S. income tax return. The tax paid with Form 1040-C must be considered as a credit for tax liability for the entire taxable year on your annual U.S. income tax return.

If you have a question about a tax issue, need assistance preparing a tax return, or want to download free publications, forms or guides, visit IRS.gov and find resources that can help you right away.

After you have received all your payroll and income statements (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.); unemployment benefit statements (by mail or in digital format) or other government payments (Form 1099-G); and copies of interest, dividends and pensions from banks and investment companies (Form 1099), you have a number of options for preparing and filing your tax return. You can prepare your tax return yourself. See if you qualify for free tax preparation or hire a tax expert to prepare your tax return for you.

Taxpayers who need information about the assistance services can call 833-690-0598. The Helpline can answer questions about current and future products and support services available through alternative means (phone, email, big print, audio, etc.). The Helpline does not have access to your IRS account. For help with tax law, tax refunds, or account-related issues, visit IRS.gov/LetUsHelp.
Visit IRS.gov/DisasterRelief to see available disaster relief.
Visit IRS.gov/Forms to view, download and print all the forms, guides and publications you need. You can also visit IRS.gov/OrderForms to order.

You will need an IRS Online Account (OLA) to complete the mobile-friendly forms that require a signature. You will have the option to submit the forms online or download a copy to send by mail. You will need scans of your documents to support the filing. Visit IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms for more information.

Download and view most popular tax publications and guides (including Guide to Form 1040) on mobile devices as eBooks at IRS.gov/eBooks. The IRS eBook has been tested using Apple's iBooks for iPad. Access IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. View how much you owe and break it down by tax year. View payment plan details or sign up for a new payment plan. Make payments, view 5-year payment history and all pending or scheduled payments. Access your tax file, including important data from your most recent tax return, your financial impact payments and records. View electronic copies of selected notifications from the IRS. Approve or reject proxy requests from tax professionals. Update your address or manage your favorite contact methods.

With an online account, you can access a variety of information to help you through the tax season. You can take a record, view your most recently filed tax return and receive your total adjusted income. Create or access your online account at IRS.gov/Account.
This function allows your hired professional to send a proxy request to the IRS OLA of an individual taxpayer. For more information, visit IRS.gov/TaxProAccount.

The safest and easiest way to receive your tax refund is to e-file and choose a direct deposit, which will transfer your refund directly to your financial account in a secure, electronic way. A direct deposit method also helps to avoid the possibility of lost, stolen, destroyed, or unsuccessful return of deposited checks to the IRS. Eight out of ten taxpayers choose a direct deposit method to receive their tax refund. If you do not have a bank account, visit IRS.gov/DirectDeposit for more information on where to find a bank or credit organization that can open an online account for you.

Your choices to prepare and file your tax return online or file it at your local community, if you qualify, include the following. Direct File. Direct File is a standard option for filing your federal personal income tax return online—free—directly and securely with the IRS. Direct File is an option for taxpayers in participating states who have a relatively simple tax return to declare certain types of income and claim certain tax credits and deductions. Although Direct File does not prepare state returns, if you live in a participating state, Direct File will guide you to a state-supported tool that you can use to prepare and file your state tax return for free. Visit IRS.gov/DirectFile for more information, program updates and FAQs. Free File. This program allows you to prepare and file your federal personal income tax return for free using software or the Free File self-complete form. However, state tax returns may not be available through Free File. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile to see if you qualify for the free federal online tax return options, electronic tax return and direct deposit or payment. VITA. The Voluntary Income Tax Assistance Program (VITA) provides free tax assistance for low- to medium-income, disabled and English-speaking taxpayers who need help preparing their own tax returns. Visit IRS.gov/VITA, download the free IRS2Go app or call 800-906-9887 for information on how to file.

The IRS does not proactively contact taxpayers via email, phone calls, text messages (including shortcut links) or social media channels to request the provision or verification of personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords, or similar information for credit cards, banks, or other financial accounts. Visit IRS.gov/IdentityTheft, the IRS's Identity Theft Center web page, for information about identity theft and data security protection for taxpayers, tax practitioners, and businesses. If you lose or get your Social Security number stolen or you suspect you are a victim of tax-related spoofing, you can learn what steps you should take. Get an Identity Protection PIN (IP PIN). An IP PIN is a six-digit number given to taxpayers to help prevent the misuse of their SSN in federal income tax fraud. When you have an IP PIN, it will prevent others from filing tax returns with your SSN. For more information, visit IRS.gov/IPPIN.

The IRS is unable to issue refunds before mid-February for returns that claim an EIC or an Additional Child Tax Credit (ACTC). This applies to the entire amount of the refund, not just the portion related to these tax credits.

U.S. tax payments must be filed with the IRS in U.S. dollars. Electronic assets are not accepted. Visit IRS.gov/Payments for information on how to make payments using any of the following options. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax amount directly from your account using a voucher or savings account free of charge for you. Debit card, credit card, or e-wallet: Choose an approved payment processor to pay online or over the phone. Electronic Bank Transfer: Schedule payments when filing federal taxes using tax filing software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System: Best choice for businesses. Registration is required. Check or money order: Mail your means of payment to the address listed in the notice or instructions. Cash: You can pay taxes in cash at a participating retail store. In-day transfer: You can make transfers within the same day from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution for availability, cost, and timeframe.

Visit IRS.gov/Payments for more information on the options available to you. File an online payment agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to settle your tax obligations in monthly instalments if you are currently unable to file all of your taxes. After completing the online process, you will be notified immediately whether your agreement is approved. Use the Settlement Offer Assessment Tool to see if you can settle your tax debt for less than the total amount you owe. For more information on the Settlement Offer program, please visit IRS.gov/OIC.

Visit IRS.gov/WMAR to track the status of your amended Form 1040-X. Please note that it may take up to 3 weeks from the date you filed your amended tax return for this information to appear on our system, and up to 16 weeks for processing.
Visit IRS.gov/Notices for more information on responding to an IRS notice or letter.

Please note that many questions can be answered on the IRS.gov website without the need for a TAC. Visit IRS.gov/LetUsHelp to see the topics that people ask the most. If you still need help, the TAC will assist you with your tax issues that cannot be resolved online or over the phone. Currently, all TACs offer pre-appointment services so that you can get the service you need without having to wait for long. Before you go, go to the IRS.gov/TACLocator page to find the nearest TAC and check the opening hours, services provided and appointments to choose from. Or on the IRS2Go app, under the Stay Connected tab, select the Contact Us option and click on “Local Offices”.

The Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS. The TAS helps taxpayers resolve problems with the IRS, makes administrative and legislative recommendations to prevent or remedy problems, and protects taxpayer rights. We strive to ensure that all taxpayers are treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We are your voice at the IRS.

TAS can help you solve problems that you cannot solve with the IRS yourself. Always try to solve your problem with the IRS first, but if you cannot, come to TAS. Our services are free. TAS supports all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, businesses and tax-exempt organizations. You may be eligible for TAS assistance if your IRS issue is causing you financial difficulties, if you have tried and failed to solve your issue with the IRS, or if you believe that the IRS system, processes or procedures are not working as expected. For assistance at any time on general tax topics, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov. This website can help you solve common tax issues and situations, such as what to do if you make a tax return error or if you receive a notice from the IRS. TAS works to solve large-scale (systemic) issues that affect many taxpayers. You can report systemic issues at www.IRS.gov/SAMS. (Be sure not to include any personally identifiable information.)

The Bill of Rights of the Taxpayer describes the ten basic rights that all taxpayers have when dealing with the IRS. Visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/Taxpayer-Rights to learn more about the rights, what they mean to you and how they apply to the specific situations that you may encounter with the IRS. The TAS strives to protect the rights of taxpayers and ensure that the IRS is administering tax laws in a fair and equitable manner.

Although the taxpayer always signs the return, you are ultimately responsible for providing all the information necessary for the taxpayer to prepare your return correctly and to ensure that all items declared on the return are accurate. Anyone who is paid to file a tax return for another person must have a thorough understanding of tax matters. For more information on choosing a taxpayer, see Choosing a taxpayer on IRS.gov.

The Department of Social Security (SSA) provides online services at SSA.gov/employer with fast, free and secure W-2 filing options for CPA, accountants, registered agents and those who process Form W-2, Payroll and Tax Report, and Form W-2c, Revised Payroll and Tax Report.

If you are a sole proprietorship, partnership, or S-corp, you can see your tax information stored in the IRS files and do more with a corporate tax account. Visit IRS.gov/BusinessAccount for more information.

Visit IRS.gov/SocialMedia to see the various social media tools that the IRS uses to share the latest information about tax changes, fraud warnings, innovations, products and services. At the IRS, privacy and security are our top priorities. We use these tools to share publicly available information with you. Please do not post your social security number or other sensitive information on social media sites. Always protect your identity when using any social media site. The following IRS YouTube channels have short informative videos on various tax-related topics in English, Spanish and ASL. Youtube.com/irsvideos. Youtube.com/irsvideosmultilingua. Youtube.com/irsvideosASL.

The IRS is committed to serving taxpayers with limited English proficiency (LEP) by providing OPI services. OPI services are a federally funded program and are provided at Taxpayer Assistance Centers (TACs), most IRS offices, and all VITA/TCE tax filing locations. OPI services are accessible in over 350 languages.

If you live outside the United States, you can call TAS at +15.15.56.46.827 or email tas.international@irs.gov. Your call will be automatically transferred to Hawaii or Puerto Rico depending on your location. If you choose Spanish, your call will be transferred to the Puerto Rico office for assistance. You can contact the Taxpayer Advocate Service at: Internal Revenue Service Taxpayer Advocate Service 48 Carr 165 Km. 1.2 City View Plaza II Bldg. Guaynabo, PR 00968-8000 You can call TAS at toll-free 877-777-4778. For more information about TAS and who to contact if you are outside the United States, visit TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/Get-Help/International/.
