First you should determine whether, for income tax purposes, you are a temporary foreign resident or a permanent foreign resident. If you are both a temporary and a permanent resident in the same year, you have dual status. See Foreigners with Dual Status later. See also Temporary spouses treated as permanent residents and some other special situations explained later in this chapter.
If you are a foreigner (not a U.S. citizen) then you will be considered a temporary alien, unless you meet one of the two tests mentioned in the Permanent Alien section below.

You are a U.S. resident for tax purposes if you meet the Green Card or Significant Presence test in 2024 (from January 1 to December 31). Even if you do not meet either of these tests, you can still choose to be treated as a U.S. resident for a portion of the year. See Choosing the first year in the Dual-status aliens section, later.

You are a permanent resident for tax purposes if you are a legal permanent resident of the United States at any time in 2023. (However, see Aliens with Dual Status later.) This is called the green card challenge. You are a legal permanent resident of the United States at any time if you are granted the privilege, under immigration law, to permanently reside in the United States as an immigrant. You usually have this status if the United States Immigration and Citizenship Service (USCIS) (or its predecessor organization) has issued you a Form I-551, Permanent Resident Card, also known as a green card. You will continue to have this challenge residency status, unless that status is revoked or administratively or judicially determined to have been waived.

The residency status is deemed to have been withdrawn if the U.S. Government issues a final administrative or judicial order requiring removal or deportation. The final judicial order is an order that you cannot appeal to a higher court.

When filing by mail, you must send a letter of assurance, request a return receipt (or equivalent document in another country) and keep a copy and proof of the document being sent and received. Until you have proof that the letter has been received, you remain a foreign resident for tax purposes, even if USCIS does not recognize the validity of your green card because it has been over 10 years or you have not been in the United States for a period of time. If USCIS or a U.S. consular official makes this decision, your residency status will be deemed to have been waived when the final administrative order for waiver is issued. If you have the right to appeal to a federal court of competent jurisdiction, you are required to have a final judicial order. Under U.S. immigration law, a legal permanent resident is required to file tax returns as a permanent resident and failure to do so may be deemed to have waived the status and may result in the loss of permanent resident status. Long-term residents (LTRs) may no longer be legal permanent residents and may be subject to special declaration and tax regulations. See Tax waivers in chapter 4.

You will be a permanent resident for tax purposes if you meet the significant presence test in 2023. To meet this test, you must be present in the United States for at least: 1.31 days in 2024; and 2.183 days in the three years 2024, 2023, and 2022, including: 1. all the days you are present in 2024, and 2.1/3 of the days you are present in 2023, and 3.1/6 of the days you are present in 2022.

When calculating days in the United States, you can only exclude days when you compete in a sporting event. You cannot exclude days when you are in the United States to train for the event, to do advertising or other activities related to the event or to travel between events. If you qualify to be excluded from days when you are present as a professional athlete, you must file a completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See Form 8843 in the next section.

Attach Form 8843 to your 2024 income tax return. If you are not required to file a tax return, please send Form 8843 to the following address. Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file Form 8843 no later than the due date for Form 1040-NR. The due date is discussed in Chapter 7. If you are required to file Form 8843 and you fail to file Form 8843 on time, you cannot exclude the days you are in the United States as a professional athlete or due to a health condition that occurred while you were in the United States. This does not apply if you can prove by clear and convincing evidence that you have taken reasonable action to understand the filing requirements and the important steps to comply with those requirements.

Excludes days you are in the United States for less than 24 hours and transiting between two locations outside the United States. You are considered a transit person if you engage in activities associated with completing your journey to a foreign destination. For example: if you are travelling between U.S. airports to change planes on your way to a foreign destination, you are considered a transit person. However, you will not be considered a transit person if you attend a business meeting while in the United States. This is true even if the meeting is already held at the airport.

Excluded are the days you are temporarily present in the United States as a regular crew member of a foreign vessel (ship or vessel) engaged in transportation between the United States and a foreign country or territory of the United States. However, this exception does not apply if you engage in any trade or business in the United States on those days.

Excludes days you intend to leave but cannot leave the United States due to a health condition or a problem that occurred while you were in the United States. Whether you intend to leave the United States on a specific date is determined based on facts and circumstances. For example: you may determine that you intend to leave if the purpose of your trip to the United States can be accomplished within a period of time that is not long enough for you to qualify for the significant presence test. However, if you need a long period of time to accomplish the purpose of your trip and that period of time would qualify you for the significant presence test, you will not be able to set up an intention to leave the United States before the end of that extended period of time. In the case of an individual who is deemed mentally incapable, evidence of the intention to leave the United States can be determined by analyzing the pattern of behavior of that individual before he or she is deemed mentally incapable. If you qualify for exclusion excluding the days of presence due to a health condition, you must file a completed Form 8843 with the IRS. However, you still remain in the United States after a reasonable period of time to arrange for departure. You have returned to the United States to treat a health condition that arose during your previous stay. This condition existed before you arrived in the United States and you are aware of the problem. It does not matter whether you need treatment for the problem when you enter the United States.
The specific rules that apply to each of these four visa types (including any rules on how long you will be an exempt individual) are discussed in the next section.

A foreign government-related individual is an individual (or an immediate family member of an individual) who is temporarily present in the United States: As a full-time employee of an international organization, For diplomatic purposes or For visa purposes (not a visa for legal permanent residence) who is designated by the Secretary of the Treasury as a representative for full-time diplomatic or consular status.

If you are present in the United States under an "A-3" or "G-5" visa as an individual employee, servant or helper of a foreign government or an employee of an international organization, you will not be considered an individual associated with a foreign government and all days you are present in the United States will be counted for the purposes of the significant presence test.

The employer is a foreigner including an office or place of business of a U.S. corporation in a foreign country or U.S. territory. If you qualify for the exclusion except for days of presence as a teacher or apprentice, you must file a completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See Form 8843 for more information.
If you qualify for the exclusion of days attended as a student, you must file Form 8843 with the IRS. See Form 8843 in the next section.

Even if you meet the significant presence test, you can still be considered a resident alien if you: Are present in the United States for less than 183 days in a year, Maintain a foreign place of choice for tax purposes in the year, and Have a closer connection in the year with a foreign country that you have a place of choice for tax purposes than with the United States (unless you have a closer relationship with two foreign countries, discussed in the next section).

You can prove that you have a closer connection to two (but not more than two) foreign countries if you meet all of the following conditions. You have maintained a tax choice starting from the first day of the year in a foreign country. You have changed your tax choice in the year to a second foreign country. You continue to maintain a tax choice in the second foreign country for the remainder of the year. You have a closer connection to each foreign country than to the United States for the period you maintain a tax choice in that foreign country. You are taxable as a permanent resident under the tax laws of the foreign country for the entire year or as a permanent resident in both foreign countries for the period you maintain a tax choice in each foreign country.

The tax place of choice is the common area of the main place of business, place of work or place of residence, regardless of where you maintain your family home. The tax place of choice is where you work permanently or indefinitely as an employee or self-employed individual. If you do not have a main place of business or regularly due to the nature of your work, the tax place of choice is where you usually live. If your case does not fall into one of these categories, you are considered a mobile person and the tax place of choice is wherever you work. To determine whether you have a closer connection to a foreign country, your tax place of choice must also exist throughout the current year and be in the same foreign country that you declare to have a closer connection to.

It does not matter whether your permanent home is a house, an apartment or a furnished room. It does not matter whether you rent or own the house. However, it is important that your home is available at all times, continuously and not only for short-term stays.

The steps to change your status to a permanent resident include but are not limited to the submission of the following forms. Form I-508, Request for Waiver of Certain Rights, Privileges and Exemptions. Form I-485, Application for Registration of Permanent Residence or Adjustment of Status. Form I-130, Application for the Sponsorship of a Foreign National. Form I-140, Application for Immigration for a Foreign Worker. Form ETA-9089, Application for Confirmation of Permanent Employment, Appendix A, and Final Decision. Form DS-230, Application for Immigration Visa and Registration of a Foreign National.

You must attach a completed Form 8840 with your income tax return to declare that you have a closer connection to a foreign country or countries. If you do not have to file a tax return, please send the form to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file Form 8840 no later than the due date of Form 1040-NR. The due date is discussed later in Chapter 7. If you do not file Form 8840 on time, you cannot declare that you have a closer connection to a foreign country or countries. This does not apply if you can prove by clear evidence and convincingly that you have taken reasonable action to understand the filing requirements and the important steps to comply with those requirements.

Dual-status resident. The rules set out here for determining whether you are a U.S. resident do not override the definitions of residency status under the tax treaty. If you are a dual-status taxpayer, you can still claim entitlements under the income tax treaty. A dual-status taxpayer is a resident of both the U.S. and another country under the tax laws of each country. The income tax treaty between the two countries must have provisions governing the resolution of conflicting residency claims (the exception rule). If you are considered a tax treaty resident, you will be considered a temporary resident foreigner for U.S. income tax purposes. For purposes other than taxation, you will be considered a U.S. resident. For example: the rules discussed here do not affect the length of time you reside, as discussed in Dual-status foreigner later.

If you are a dual-status taxpayer and claim a treaty entitlement, you must file a tax return using Form 1040-NR attached to Form 8833 and be assessed as a foreign resident. A dual-status taxpayer may also qualify for assistance from the appropriate U.S. authority. See Taxpayer Procedure 2015-40, 2015-35 I.R.B. 236, available at IRS.gov/irb/2015-35_IRB#RP-2015-40 or later. See Treaty Entitlement Requirements in Chapter 9 for more information on treaty entitlement.

Students who are temporary foreign residents from Barbados and Jamaica, as well as apprentices from Jamaica, may qualify to vote in an election to be treated as a permanent foreign resident for U.S. tax purposes under the U.S. income tax treaty signed with those countries. See Form 901 for more information. If you qualify to apply this option, you can do so by filing Form 1040 and appending a signed declaration of option to your tax return. The rules on permanent foreign residents discussed in this form apply to you. After making an option, that option will be applied as long as you still qualify and you must seek permission from the appropriate U.S. authority to terminate that option.

You may be both a temporary resident and a permanent resident in the same tax year. This is usually the year you arrive or leave the United States. A dual-resident foreigner should refer to Chapter 6 for information on filing a tax return in the dual-resident tax year.

If you are a U.S. resident in the year, but you were not a U.S. resident at any time in the previous year, then you are only a U.S. resident for a period of time in the year beginning on the day you began residing. You are a foreign resident for a period of time in the year before that date if you are a foreign resident for a period of time in the year before that date.

See Closer connections to a foreign country in the previous section. To determine whether you can exclude up to 10 days, the following rules will apply. You can exclude days from multiple periods of presence, as long as the total number of days in all periods does not exceed 10 days. You cannot exclude any days in a consecutive period of presence if you cannot exclude all days in that period. Although you can exclude up to 10 days of presence when determining the date you began residence, you must include those days when determining whether you meet the test of significant presence.

Attach the mandatory return to your income tax return. If you are not required to file a return, please send it to the following address. Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file your return on or before the due date of Form 1040-NR. The due date is discussed in Chapter 7. If you do not file the mandatory return as explained above, you cannot claim that you have a closer connection to a foreign country or countries. Therefore, the first day of your residence will be the first day you are in the United States. This does not apply if you can prove by clear evidence and convincingly that you have taken reasonable action to understand the filing requirements and the important steps to comply with those requirements.

If you meet the Green Card test at any time during the year but do not meet the significant presence test for that year then your date of commencement of residence will be the first day in the year that you are present in the United States as a legal permanent resident. If you meet both the significant presence test and the Green Card test then your date of commencement of residence will be before the first day in the year that you are present in the United States as a legal permanent resident either under the significant presence test or under the legal permanent resident test.

If you were a U.S. resident at any time in the previous year and you are a U.S. resident at any time in the current year, you will be considered a U.S. resident at the beginning of the current year. This applies whether you are a permanent resident under the Significant Presence Test or the Green Card Test.

When calculating the number of absence days in (1) and (2) above, the days you are in the United States under any of the exceptions discussed in the previous section on Days of Presence in the United States are not counted. If you choose the first year, then the date you begin residence in 2024 will be the first day of the earliest 31-day period (as set out in (1) above) that you use to qualify for this option. You are considered a U.S. resident for the remainder of the year. If you are present for more than 31 days and meet the condition (2) above in each of those periods, then the date you begin residence will be the first day of the first 31-day period. If you are present for more than 31 days but meet the condition (2) above only in the next 31-day period, then the date you begin residence will be the first day of the next 31-day period.

You cannot file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR or a report until you meet the significant presence challenge for 2025. If you do not meet this challenge for 2024 as of April 15, 2025, you may request an extension of the filing period for Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR in 2021 for a reasonable period of time after you meet that challenge. To request an extension of the filing period until October 15, 2025, use Form 4868. When you file the extension, you must pay the anticipated tax due for 2024, which is calculated as if you were a non-resident foreigner for the entire year. You can use Form 1040-NR to calculate the tax. Enter the tax on Form 4868. If you fail to pay the tax on time, you will be liable to interest on any outstanding tax on the due date of your regular tax return and you may be penalized for late filing. After making the choice for the first year, you cannot withdraw the choice without the consent of the IRS. If you do not follow the procedure discussed here to make the choice for the first year, you will be considered a non-resident foreigner for the entire year 2024. However, this does not apply if you can demonstrate with clear and convincing evidence that you have taken reasonable action to understand the filing requirements and the important steps to comply with those requirements.
This includes situations where both you and your spouse are foreign residents at the beginning of the tax year and both are foreign residents at the end of the tax year.

You usually make this choice when filing your general tax return. However, you can also make this choice by filing Form 1040-X, the Amendment to the U.S. Income Tax Return for Individuals. Attach either Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and enter "Amended" at the top of the amended return. If you make the choice to file with the amended return, you and your spouse must also amend any returns you may have filed after the year you make the choice. You usually have to file the amended general tax return within 3 years of the date you filed your initial U.S. income tax return or 2 years of the date you paid income tax for that year, whichever is later.

If you are a U.S. resident in 2024 but not a U.S. resident at any time in 2025, you will no longer be a U.S. resident on the date you end your residency status. The date you end your residency status is December 31, 2024, unless you qualify for an earlier date, as discussed in the following section.

You can only use this date if for the remainder of 2024, your chosen place of taxation is in a foreign country and you have a closer connection with that foreign country. See Closer connection with a foreign country in the previous section.

If you are a U.S. resident under the significant presence test and you qualify for the earlier end of residence date, you can exclude up to 10 days of presence in the U.S. to determine the date of your end of residence. To determine whether you can exclude the maximum of 10 days, the following rules will apply. You can exclude days from multiple periods of presence, provided that the total number of days in all periods does not exceed 10 days. You cannot exclude any days in a consecutive period of presence if you cannot exclude all days in that period. Although you can exclude up to 10 days of presence when determining the date of your end of residence, you must include those days when determining whether you meet the significant presence test.

If you are a U.S. resident at any time in 2025 and a permanent resident at any time in 2024, you will be considered a permanent resident until the end of 2024. This applies whether or not you have a closer connection with a foreign country than with the United States in 2024 and whether or not you are a permanent resident under the Significant Presence Test or the Green Card Test.

Attach the mandatory report to your income tax return. If you are not required to file a tax return, please send the report to the following address. Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file the report on or before the due date of Form 1040-NR. The due date is discussed in Section 7. If you do not file the mandatory report as explained above, you cannot claim that you have a closer connection to a foreign country or countries. This does not apply if you can prove by clear evidence and convincingly that you have taken reasonable action to understand the filing requirements and the important steps to comply with those requirements.

If at the end of the tax year you are married and your spouse is a U.S. citizen or a permanent foreign resident and the other spouse is a temporary foreign resident, you can choose to treat the temporary spouse as a U.S. resident. This includes situations where the spouse is a foreign resident at the beginning of the tax year, but the foreign resident is permanent at the end of the year and the other spouse is a temporary foreign resident at the end of the year. If you make this choice, you and your spouse will be treated as residents for the entire tax year. Both you and your spouse cannot file under any tax treaty and are not U.S. residents. Both are taxed on income from all sources worldwide. You must file a joint income tax return for the selected year, but you and your spouse can file joint or separate taxes in subsequent years. If you file jointly under this rule, the special guidelines and restrictions for dual status taxpayers in Chapter 6 do not apply to you.
Also check the box and enter their names if you and your spouse have opted to be considered permanent residents in the previous year and the option is still valid.

You usually make this choice when filing a general tax return. However, you can also make this choice by filing an amended return on Form 1040-X. Attach Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and enter "Amended" at the top of the amended return. If you make the choice to file an amended return, you and your spouse must also amend any returns you may have filed after the year you make the choice. You usually have to file an amended general tax return within 3 years of the date you filed your first U.S. income tax return or 2 years of the date you paid your income tax for that year, whichever is later.

The option is considered as a foreign resident will be suspended for any tax year (after the tax year chosen) if both spouses are not U.S. citizens or foreign residents at any time in the tax year. This means that each spouse must file a separate tax return as a foreign resident in that year if either of them meets the requirements for filing a foreign resident tax return discussed in section 7.

After making the choice, the choice is considered to be permanent for all subsequent years, unless it is suspended (as explained in the previous section of Pausing Choices) or terminated in one of the following ways. If the choice is terminated in one of the following ways, neither spouse can make the choice in any subsequent tax year. 1. Withdrawal. One of the spouses may withdraw the choice for any tax year, provided that he/she withdraws the choice before the tax return due date for that tax year. The spouse who withdraws the choice must attach a signed statement stating that the choice is being withdrawn. The statement must contain the name, address and TIN of each spouse. (If a spouse is deceased, include the name and address of the withdrawing spouse for the deceased spouse.) The statement must also list any state, foreign country and territory that applies common property law where the spouse resides or where real estate is owned by one of the spouses. File the statement as follows. 1. If the spouse withdraws the choice, please attach the statement to the tax return for the first year in which the withdrawal of the choice applies. 2. If the spouse does not file a tax return, but files a tax return (e.g. to get a refund), attach the statement to the tax return. 3. If the spouse withdraws the choice, does not file a tax return and does not file a tax refund request, send the statement to the Tax Service Center where you filed the tax return.

If you are a foreign resident in the United States and have been a true resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you will be taxed, with some exceptions, as a U.S. resident foreigner. For more information, see True Residents of American Samoa or Puerto Rico in Chapter 5. If you are a foreign resident from American Samoa or Puerto Rico who has not been a true resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you will be taxed as a foreign resident. A foreign resident who has only been a true resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico will be taxed as a foreign resident if he or she has been a true resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year.
After you have determined your foreigner status, you must determine your source of income. This section will help you determine the many sources of income that you may receive in the tax year.

Foreign residents' income is generally taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens. If you are a foreign resident, you must declare all interest, dividends, salaries or other remuneration for services, income from rental property or royalties and other types of income on your U.S. tax return. You must declare these amounts of money whether they come from sources within or outside the United States.

Foreign residents are only taxed on income from sources in the United States and certain income related to the conduct of commercial or business activities in the United States (see Chapter 4). The general rules for determining income from sources in the United States that apply to most foreign residents are presented in Table 2-1. The following discussion includes the general rules as well as exceptions to these rules. Not all items of income from sources in the United States are taxable. Chapter 3.

Real estate is land, buildings, and anything built, developed on, or attached to land. Total income from United States sources includes income from profits, profits, and income from the sale or other disposition of real estate in the United States.

Income from the sale of the products of any farm, mine, oil or gas well, other natural resource or timber in the United States and sold abroad or located abroad and sold in the United States, originates in part in the United States. For information on determining that part, see Regulation 1.863-1(b).

Personal property is property such as machinery, equipment or furniture, not real estate. Profits or losses from the sale or exchange of personal property are usually derived from the United States if you have your main place of business in the United States. If you do not have your main place of business in the United States, the profits or losses are usually deemed to come from sources outside the United States.

The taxable place of choice is the general area of the principal place of business, place of work or place of residence, regardless of where you maintain your family home. The taxable place of choice is where you work permanently or indefinitely as an employee or self-employed individual. If you do not have a principal place of business or regularly due to the nature of your work, the taxable place of choice is where you usually live. If you do not fall into either of these categories, you are considered a mobile person and the taxable place of choice is wherever you work.

Inventory assets are personal assets that are stored or mainly held for sale to customers in the normal course of trade or business. Income from the sale of inventory that you purchase originates at the place where the asset is sold. This is usually where the ownership of the asset is transferred to the buyer. For example: income from the sale of inventory in the United States is income originating in the United States, whether you purchase the asset in the United States or abroad. Income from the sale of inventory that you produce in the United States and sell outside the United States (or vice versa) originates at the place where that asset is produced. This rule applies even if your chosen place of taxation is not in the United States.

To determine the origin of any interest from the sale of personal property that is to be depreciated, you must first calculate the interest that does not exceed the total depreciation adjustment of that property. You allocate this interest to U.S. sources based on the ratio of U.S. depreciation adjustment to total depreciation adjustment. The remainder of this interest is considered to come from sources outside the U.S. For this purpose, "U.S. depreciation adjustments" are depreciation adjustments to the property base allowed when calculating taxable income from U.S. sources. However, if the property is used primarily in the U.S. in the tax year, all depreciation adjustments allowed in that year are considered to be U.S. depreciation adjustments. However, there are some exceptions for transportation, communications and other property used internationally. Interest from the sale of property that is to be depreciated is greater than the total depreciation adjustment on that property originated as if the property were inventory, as discussed above. Losses have the same origin as the source of depreciation adjustment. However, if the property is used primarily in the U.S., all loss will reduce the income originating in the U.S. The original price of the property usually means the cost (the amount of money plus the fair market value of the property or other services) of the property you acquired. Depreciation is the amount of money that is discounted to recover the full cost or other cost of the commercial or business property. The amount of money you can deduct depends on the original price of the property, the time you started using the property, and the time of cost recovery.

Intangible assets include patents, copyrights, secret processes or formulas, commercial advantages, trademarks, trade names, or other similar assets. Profits from the sale of intangible assets may be distributed or amortized, up to the previously permitted deduction of the deduction rate, from the same source as the source of the original deduction. This is similar to the rule on the source of income from the sale of assets must be amortized. See Amortized assets in the previous section for details on how to apply this rule. Profits in excess of the deductions of the deduction rate originate in the country where the assets are used if the income from the sale of the assets depends on the productivity, use, or transfer of that asset. If the income does not depend on the productivity, use, or transfer of the assets, then the income will originate in your chosen taxation place (discussed in the previous section). If payments for the commercial advantages do not depend on the productivity, use, or transfer, then they originate in the country where the commercial advantage is created.

Regardless of any of the above rules, if you do not have a tax-eligible place in the United States, but you maintain an office or other fixed place of business in the United States, then consider income from any sale of personal property (including inventory) as attributable to that office or place of business. However, this rule does not apply to the sale of inventory for use, transfer or consumption outside the United States if the other office or fixed place of business outside the United States was substantially involved in the sale. If you have a tax-eligible place in the United States but maintain an office or other fixed place of business outside the United States, then income from the sale of personal property, other than inventory, depreciable assets or intangible assets, may be considered as income originating in the United States from that foreign office or place of business. Income is considered to originate in the United States if income tax is less than 10% of the sales income paid to a foreign country. This rule also applies to losses if that foreign country applies less than 10% income tax on profitable sales.

The place of payment or the method of payment does not play an important role in determining the source of income. The payment of interest in lieu of the transfer of securities in securities lending or repurchase transactions is made in the same manner as the interest on the securities transferred.

Income from interest originating in the United States does not include the following categories. 1. Interest paid by a foreign resident or domestic corporation on obligations made before August 10, 2010, if in the three-year period ending in the taxation year of the payer before the payment of interest there is at least 80% (0.80) of the total income of the taxpayer: 1. From sources outside the United States and 2. Allocated to the business or business of an individual or corporation in a foreign country or territory of the United States. However, interest will be treated as income from interest originating in the United States if one of the following applies. 1. The recipient of the interest relates to the foreign resident or domestic corporation. See section 954(d)(3) for the definition of “related person.” 2. The terms of this obligation are substantially adjusted after August 9, 2010. Any extension of the obligation is considered a substantial adjustment. 2. Interest paid by a foreign branch of a domestic corporation or domestic partnership on deposit accounts or withdrawable accounts at a cooperative savings bank, cooperative bank, credit union, loan and construction union and other savings and lending organizations or similar associations under federal or state law if such association is able to deduct interest paid or recorded. 3. Interest on deposits at a foreign branch of a domestic corporation or domestic partnership, but only if that branch is a commercial banking enterprise.

In most cases, dividend income received from domestic companies is income originating in the United States. Dividend income from foreign companies is usually income originating abroad. Exceptions to the second rule are discussed in the following section. Substitute dividend payments to the transferor of securities in securities lending or repurchase transactions have the same origin as the distribution of the transferred securities.

The dividend equivalent payment includes any total amount of money referring to dividends originating in the United States and used to calculate any actual amount of money transferred to or from the taxpayer under the contract, if the taxpayer is a buyer in the contract. Thus, the taxpayer may be considered to have received a payment equivalent to dividends even if they paid net or did not pay any amount of money because the actual amount of money was zero. In 2024, the NPC or ELI will typically be a specific NPC or ELI if the contract is a derivative product transaction without optional functionality and has a delta of one. Generally, the delta is the ratio of change in the fair market value of the NPC or ELI to a small change in the fair market value of the number of shares referred to under the contract. Generally, the dividend equivalent of a specific NPC or ELI is the amount of dividend per share multiplied by the number of shares referred to under the contract multiplied by the delta of the contract. Special rules apply to complex contracts. See paragraph 1.871-15 in Regulations and Notices 2024–44 (or subsequent), for more information.

All salaries and any other allowances from services performed in the United States are considered to originate in the United States. The only exception to this rule is discussed in Employees of foreign individuals, organizations or offices in the section below in Employees in the section above. If you are an employee and receive employment allowances or personal services performed both within and outside the United States then special rules will apply when determining the source of allowances. Allowances (except for some allowances) are based on time. Some allowances (such as housing and education) are based on geography. Or you may be given an alternate basis to determine the source of allowances. See Alternative Bases in the section below.

Some companies that sell products through multi-level marketing, such as top-level distributors who sponsor down-level distributors, will be paid by the company based on some of the activities of that down-level distributor. Generally, depending on the practice, the payments of the multi-level marketing company to independent (not employee) distributors (top-level distributors) based on sales or purchases of those they sponsor (lower-level distributors) will generate income from performing personal services when recruiting, training and supporting lower-level distributors. That income is usually based on where the top-level distributor performs services and depending on the practice, can be considered as a multi-year subsidy, in which the source of income is determined over the period of time that the subsidy is allocated.

If you are a self-employed person, you will determine the source of your income from labour or personal services from self-employment on the basis that best reflects that appropriate source of income in the realities and circumstances of your particular case. In many cases, the realities and circumstances will require a time-based allocation, which is explained in the next section.

Multi-year pay sources are usually determined based on the time period during which the pay is distributed. A multi-year pay source is a pay that is included in your income for one taxable year, but can be extended to a period of two taxable years or more. You determine the period of time during which the pay is distributed based on the facts and circumstances of your case. For example: pay related to a period of several years can be extended to the entire multi-year period. Pay considered to originate in the United States is calculated by multiplying the total multi-year pay by a fraction. The decimal of that fraction is the number of days (or units of time less than one day, if deemed appropriate) that you worked or performed personal services in the United States related to the project. The decimal of that fraction is the number of days (or units of time less than one day, if deemed appropriate) that you worked or performed personal services in the United States related to the project.
The amount of the allowance must be reasonable and you must prove it by documentation or full evidence.

The above allowances, except for tax refunds and wages paid for dangerous or difficult assignments, originate based on your main workplace. The main workplace is usually where you spend most of your time working. This can be your office, factory, store, shops or other location. If there is no place where you spend most of your time working, then your main workplace is where your work is concentrated, such as where you report on work or are required to "base" your work. If you have more than one job at any given time, your main workplace depends on the facts of each case. The most important factors to consider are: The total amount of time you work at each place, The amount of work you do at each place, and How much money you earn at each place.

The source of the educational allowance for dependents is determined based on your main place of employment. Educational allowance only includes the following educational expenses at a primary or secondary school. Tuition, fees, tuition, services for students with special needs, books, supplies and other equipment. Rooms, tables and uniforms requested or provided by the school in connection with enrollment or attendance.

The source of local commuting allowance is determined based on your main place of work. Local commuting allowance is the amount of money you receive as local commuting allowance for you or your spouse or dependent at your main place of work. The amount considered as local commuting allowance is limited to the actual cost incurred for local commuting and the reasonable rental value of any means provided by your employer that are used primarily by you, your spouse or dependent for local commuting. Actual costs do not include the cost (including interest) of any means purchased by you or on your behalf.
The source of the surcharge on the tax refund is determined based on the tax territory in which you receive the refund.

The source of refund for commuting costs is usually based on your new main place of work. However, this source is determined based on the old main place of work if you provide sufficient evidence that that determination is more appropriate in the facts and circumstances of your case. Full evidence usually requires an agreement between you and your employer or a statement of company policy, summarized in a document before the move and signed or made to cause you or other employees to move to another country. The statement or agreement must state that the employer will reimburse you for the commuting costs to return to your old main place of work, whether or not you continue to work for the employer after returning to that location. This may include a number of conditions under which the entitlement to refund is determined, provided that those conditions set out identifiable criteria and can only be implemented before or after you move to your old main place of work.

If you are an employee, you may determine the source of compensation on an alternative basis if you confirm to the satisfaction of the IRS that, in the facts and circumstances of your case, this alternative basis determines the source of compensation more reasonably than the time or geographic basis. If you use an alternative basis, you must keep (and be available for review) records to record the reasons why the alternative basis determines the source of compensation more reasonably. In addition, if your total compensation from all sources is $250,000 or more, check the "Yes" box on both questions on line K of the Schedule OI (Form 1040-NR) and attach a reporting text with your tax return showing all of the following. 1. Your name and SSN (entered at the head of the report). 2. The specific income from the specific salary or allowance you are using as the substitute basis. 3. For each item in (2), the alternative basis used to allocate the income source. 4. For each item in (2), the calculation shows how the substitute allocation is calculated. 5. Comparison of U.S. and foreign compensation originating on both the alternative basis and the time or geographic basis discussed above.

Income from transportation is income from the operation of a ship or aircraft or the provision of services directly related to the operation of any ship or aircraft. This is true whether the ship or aircraft is owned or leased. The term "ship or aircraft" includes any equipment used in connection with a ship or aircraft. All income from transportation that begins and ends in the United States will be considered to originate in the United States. If the transportation begins or ends in the United States, 50% of the income from transportation will be considered to originate in the United States. For income from transportation from personal services, 50% of the income is income originating in the United States if the transportation is carried out between the United States and a U.S. territory. For foreign residents, this applies only to income originating from or related to an aircraft. For information on how to tax income from transportation originating in the United States, see chapter 4.

In general, the source of scholarships, research grants, prizes and rewards is the place of residence of the taxpayer, regardless of who actually disburses the funds. However, see Activities that are performed outside the United States in the section below. For example: payments for research or study activities in the United States are made by the United States, a U.S. resident is not a domestic business or company originating in the United States. Similar payments from a foreign government or foreign company are payments from a foreign source, although some amounts may be disbursed through an agent in the United States. Payments are made by an organization designated as a public international organization under the Exemption Act for International Organizations of Foreign Origin.

Scholarships, research grants, awards and achievement awards that are received by foreign residents for activities that are or will be carried out outside the United States have a non-U.S. origin. This rule does not apply to payments in the form of scholarships or other remuneration for services. See Personal services in the previous section for the rules on the source of income that apply.

If you receive a pension from a domestic trust fund for services performed both within and outside the United States, part of the pension payments are from U.S. sources. That part is the allocation of income from the salary program and the employer's contribution for services performed in the United States. This applies whether or not the distribution is performed under a qualifying stock reward, pension, profit-sharing or annuity program (whether funded or not). If you perform services in a U.S. employee role, you may receive a distribution from the U.S. Government under a program such as the Civil Service Pension System, which is considered a qualifying pension program. Income originating in the United States is the amount of other taxable distributions that may be attributed to the total basic salary paid by the U.S. Government in addition to tax-exempt payments for services performed outside the United States.

If you are required to file a U.S. federal income tax return, you may benefit from some special disaster-related rules on the use of pension funds. For more information, see Form 590-B. Also, visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.

Special rules govern the tax-effective withdrawal and refund of funds to certain pension plans (including IRAs) for taxpayers who have suffered financial damages from certain major disasters. For information on reporting qualified disaster distributions and refunds, see Form 8915-F, Distribution and Refund to Qualified Disaster Pension Plans, and the guidelines.

Income from the United States includes rents and royalties received in the taxable year from property in the United States or from any rights in such property. Income from the United States also includes rents or royalties for use or privileges of use in the United States, intangible assets such as patents, copyrights, secret processes and formulas, commercial advantages, trademarks, trade licences and similar assets.
In these cases, you and your spouse must declare the joint income of the spouses, as explained in the section below.

The income earned by the spouse, other than income from trade or business activities and income from the share of the partner in the joint venture, will be considered as the income of the spouse performing income-generating services.The spouse must declare all of these on their own tax returns.

Income from business activities, other than income from the share of the partner in the joint venture, will be considered as income of the spouse engaged in commercial or business activities. That spouse must declare all of this on their own tax returns.
Income (or loss) from the share of the shareholder in the joint venture will be treated as that shareholder's income (or loss). That shareholder must declare all of this on their own tax returns.

Income from a spouse's separate property (not earned income, income from trade or business activities or income from a share of dividends in a joint venture) will be considered as that spouse's income. That spouse must declare all of these on their separate tax returns. Use the appropriate common property law to determine what is considered as separate property.
All other common income is deemed to have been provided under the current common property law.

Resident and non-resident foreigners are entitled to total income deductions if they meet certain conditions. The total income deduction is usually income you receive that is not included in your U.S. income and is not subject to U.S. taxation. This section covers some of the more common deductions that apply to resident and non-resident foreigners.
Resident foreigners may exclude the following items from their total income.

If you are present in one or more foreign countries for at least 330 days in any period of 12 consecutive months, you may qualify for the exclusion of foreign income. The amount of the exclusion in 2024 is $126,500. In addition, you may be able to exclude or deduct some foreign housing expenses. You may also be eligible if you are a genuine resident of a foreign country and you are a citizen or national of a country with which the United States has an income tax treaty. For more information, see Issue 54.
A resident foreigner may exempt the following items from total income.

Income from interest not related to a trade or business in the United States will be exempt from income tax if such income comes from: Deposits (including deposit certificates) with persons in banking enterprises; Deposits or withdrawable accounts at mutual savings banks, cooperative banks, credit unions, domestic lending and building associations, and other savings organizations that are classified and supervised as savings and lending or similar associations under federal or state law (if such associations may deduct interest paid or recorded); and Money held by an insurance company under an agreement to pay interest arising from such money.

Interest on bonds issued by a state or political subdivision, District of Columbia, or U.S. territory is usually not included in income. However, interest on certain privately operated bonds, spread bonds, and some unregistered bonds are included in income.

Interest and OIDs that qualify as investment interest will not be subject to withholding tax under Chapter 3 (of the Tax Code) in sections 1441-1443. However, that interest may be deducted if it is a deductible payment and does not apply the withholding tax exemption under Chapter 4 (of the Tax Code) in sections 1471-1474. For more information, see the discussion of investment interest in Withholding on Specific Income in Issue 515. To qualify as investment interest, interest must be paid on bonds issued after July 18, 1984. Otherwise, interest will be deducted. For bonds issued after March 18, 2012, investment interest does not include interest paid on unregistered debt. Prior to March 19, 2012, investment interest includes interest on a number of registered and unregistered (anonymous) bonds if the bond meets the requirements set out below.

Interest on investments does not include interest reserves. Interest reserves are in one of the following cases. 1. Interest is determined by reference to: Any receipts, proceeds of sales or other cash flows of the debtor or a related person; Income or profits of the debtor or a related person; Any change in the value of any assets of the debtor or a related person; or Any dividends, contributions to a joint venture or similar payments of the debtor or a related person. For exceptions, see section 871(h)(4)(C). 2. Any other kind of interest reserves as may be determined by the Minister of Finance in regulations.
The following dividend income is exempt from tax at a rate of 30%.

The 30% tax rate is not applied to U.S.-originated dividends you receive from a foreign company. See the Exceptions in the Dividend section in Chapter 2 for how to calculate U.S.-originated dividends. This exemption does not apply to equivalent dividend payments.

The 30% tax rate is not applied to dividends related to interest from U.S. sources that you receive from mutual funds or other regulated investment companies (RICs). The mutual funds will specify in a document which dividends are dividends related to interest.

The 30% tax deduction is not applied to certain short-term dividends from U.S. sources that you receive from mutual funds or RICs. The mutual funds will specify in a document which dividends are short-term dividends. This tax deduction does not apply if you are present in the U.S. for 183 days or more in the tax year.
If you are paid by a foreign employer, then income originating in the United States may be exempt from U.S. tax, but only if you meet one of the conditions discussed in the next section.

If you do not meet all three conditions, then your income from personal services performed in the United States is income originating in the United States and subject to the rules in Chapter 4. If you are paid for these services more than $3,000, then the entire amount is income from a trade or business in the United States. To determine whether you are paid more than $3,000, do not include any money you receive from your employer for advances or reimbursements for travel expenses, if you are required and have settled with your employer for those expenses. If the advances or reimbursements exceed your expenses, count the excess amount into your payment for these services. A "day" means a calendar day at any time you are physically present in the United States.

Remuneration for services performed by a foreign resident in connection with the temporary presence of that individual in the United States as a permanent crew member of a foreign vessel (e.g., ship or ferry) engaged in transportation between the United States and a foreign country or territory of the United States is not income originating in the United States and is exempt from U.S. taxation. This exemption does not apply to remuneration for services performed on a foreign aircraft unless the remuneration is paid in the United States.

Students or exchange guests who are present in the United States as foreign temporary residents under an "F," "J," "M," or "Q" visa may exclude wages from total income received from a foreign employer. This group includes students, scholarship recipients, apprentices, teachers, professors, research assistants, experts or leaders in the field of knowledge or professional skills, or persons of similar description. This group also includes the spouse and minor children of the foreigner if they accompany the foreigner or come to join the foreigner. Foreigners who are present in the United States as temporary residents under a "J" visa include foreigners who enter the United States as exchange guests under the Cooperative Education and Cultural Exchange Act of 1961.
The term "foreign employer" does not include a foreign government. Payments from foreign governments are exempt from U.S. income tax.
If you are unsure whether the anniversary comes from a qualifying anniversary program or a qualifying trust fund, ask the payer.

Any income exempt from U.S. tax by treaty to which the United States is a party will be exempt from total income. However, income that is only limited by treaty taxation will be included in total income. See Chapter 9.
You can exclude from your total income winnings from legal bets made outside the United States in a general group of bets related to a horse race or dog race that is live in the United States.

If you have sold your main home, you can exclude up to $250,000 of the profit from the sale of the home. If you are married and file jointly, you can exclude up to $500,000. For information on this exemption, see Form 523. This exemption does not apply if you comply with the rules on taxation of withdrawal of citizenship discussed in Section 4.

If you are a candidate for a degree program, you may exclude some or all of the amount received as a qualifying scholarship from your income. The rules discussed here apply to both permanent and temporary foreigners. If a temporary foreigner receives a scholarship from outside the United States, he or she is not subject to U.S. taxation. See Scholarships, Grants, Awards and Rewards in chapter 2 to determine whether your scholarship is from the United States. A scholarship or research grant is only excluded from your income if: 1. You are a candidate for a degree program at an eligible educational institution and 2. You use the scholarship or research grant to pay for your qualifying education.

You are an applicant for a degree program if you: 1. attend a primary or secondary school or a post-secondary or university program; or 2. attend a recognized educational institution entitled to provide: 1. a program that can accept full credits for a bachelor's degree or higher or 2. a training program that prepares students for employment in a recognized profession.

However, for these items to become eligible educational expenses, the scholarship or research grant provisions cannot provide for the use of the scholarship or research grant for other purposes such as accommodation or provide for the non-use of the scholarship or research grant to cover tuition or course-related expenses.
This is true even if you have to pay fees to an educational institution as a condition of enrollment or attendance. The amount of scholarship or research grant used to pay for these costs is taxable.
The amount of scholarship used to pay for any non-eligible expenses is taxable, even if the expense is a fee to be paid to the educational institution as a condition of enrolment or attendance.

You cannot deduct from your income a portion of a scholarship, research grant or tuition rebate representing payment for past, present or future teaching, research or other services. This is true even if all applicants to a degree program have to perform services as a condition of receiving a degree.

Resident and non-resident foreigners are taxed in many different ways. Resident foreigners are usually taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens. Temporary resident foreigners are taxed based on the source of income and whether the income is actually related to a business or business activity in the United States. The following discussion will help you determine whether income received in the tax year is actually related to a business or business activity in the United States and if so, how that income is taxed.

Foreign residents are generally taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens. This means that their income from elsewhere in the world is subject to U.S. taxation and must be declared on a U.S. tax return. Foreign residents are subject to the cumulative tax rate applicable to U.S. citizens. For more information, see the Tax Schedule or the Tax Calculation Schedule in the Guide to Form 1040 for U.S. citizens.

The difference between these two types is that actual income, after allowable deductions, is subject to a cumulative rate of taxation. This is the same rate as applied to U.S. citizens and residents. Non-actual income is subject to a flat rate of 30% (or lower by treaty). If you were a former U.S. citizen or a permanent resident foreigner, these rules may not apply. See Taxation of Nationality later in this chapter.

Generally, you must engage in a trade or business in the tax year in order to consider the income received in that year as being actually connected to that trade or business. Whether you engage in a trade or business in the United States depends on the nature of your activity. The following discussion will help you determine whether you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States.

If you perform personal services in the United States at any time during the tax year, you are generally considered to be engaged in a commercial or business activity in the United States. Remuneration paid by a foreign employer to a resident foreigner will not be included in total income. For more information, see Services rendered to a foreign employer in Chapter 3.
Here are some other examples of engaging in a commercial activity or business in the United States.

If you are temporarily present in the United States as a non-resident under an “F,” “J,” “M,” or “Q” visa and are not engaged in a trade or business, you will be deemed to have engaged in a trade or business in the United States if you have taxable income from a scholarship or research grant referred to in section 1441(b). The taxable portion of any scholarship or research grant that is income originating in the United States will be deemed to be in actual connection with a trade or business in the United States.
If you own and operate a business selling services, products or goods in the United States, with certain exceptions, you have engaged in a commercial or business activity in the United States.

If you are a member of a partnership that at any time in the tax year you engage in a trade or business in the United States, you are deemed to have engaged in a trade or business in the United States.
If you are a beneficiary of a real estate or trust fund engaged in a trade or business in the United States, you are considered to have engaged in the same trade or business.

If your sole business in the United States is trading in shares, securities or commodities (including risk insurance transactions) through a U.S. resident broker or other agent, you are not engaging in trading or business in the United States. For stock or securities transactions, this applies to any foreign resident, including stock and securities dealers or brokers. For commodities transactions, this applies to commodities that are normally traded on an organized commodity exchange and the transactions are normally carried out at that exchange. This discussion does not apply if you have an office or other fixed place of business in the United States at any time during the tax year through which you carry out stock, securities or commodity transactions.

You are not engaged in a trade or business in the United States if trading in stocks, securities or commodities on a private account is your sole business in the United States. This applies even if the trade takes place while you are in the United States or is performed by your employee or broker or other agent. This does not apply to trading on a private account if you are a stock, securities or commodity trader. However, this does not necessarily mean that as a trader, you are considered to have engaged in a trade or business in the United States. Determine this based on the facts and circumstances of each case or by the rules set out above in Trading in Stocks, Securities and Commodities.

If you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States, then all income, profits or losses in the taxable year that you receive from sources in the United States (other than investment income) are considered to be actual related income. This applies whether or not there is any connection between the income and the trade or business being conducted in the United States in the taxable year. Two tests, discussed in Investment Income later, determine whether certain investment income (such as interest, dividends and royalties) is considered to be related to that business. In some limited cases, certain types of income from a foreign country may be considered to be related to the trade or business in the United States. For a discussion of these rules, see Foreign Income later.

Use the two tests mentioned below to determine whether an income originating in the United States falls into one of the three above categories and received in the taxable year is actually related to a trade or business activity in the United States. If the tests indicate that the income is actually related, you must include it in the other actual related income. If the income is not actually related, you must include it in all other income discussed in The 30% tax rate later in this chapter.
In general, the shares of a company are not considered assets used in or held for the purpose of trading or doing business in the United States.
Under this test, if commercial or business activity in the United States is a significant factor in generating income, then that income is considered to be physically connected.

You are usually engaged in a U.S. business or trade when you perform personal services in the United States. Income from personal services in the taxable year in which you engage in a U.S. business or trade is actually connected to your U.S. business or trade. Income received in a year other than the year you perform the service is also considered to be actually connected if it is actually connected if received in the year you perform the service. Income from personal services includes wages, salaries, royalties, fees, service allowances, allowances and employee bonuses. Income may be paid to you in the form of cash, services or property. If you engage in a U.S. business or trade only because you perform personal services in the U.S. in the taxable year, income and profits from property, as well as profits and losses from the sale or exchange of capital property, are usually not actually connected to your U.S. business or trade. However, if there is a direct economic relationship between your holding of property and the business or trade in order to perform personal services, then income, profits or losses are actually connected.

If you have performed personal services in the United States after 1986 and in the subsequent tax year you receive a pension or retirement benefit attributable to those services while you are a foreign resident, then those distributions are actual combined income to the extent that they are attributable to contributions. This is true whether or not you engaged in commercial or business activities in the United States in the year you received your pension or retirement benefit.

"Fixed place of business" is usually a place, location, structure, or other similar facility through which you engage in a commercial or business activity. "Regular scheduled transportation" means a ship or aircraft that follows a published schedule with repeated trips or flights at regular intervals between the same points in the trips or flights that begin or end in the United States. This definition applies to both scheduled air transportation and charter air transportation. If you do not meet both of the above conditions, your income will not be effectively connected and will be subject to tax at the rate of 4%. See Transportation Tax later in this chapter.

All profits or losses originating in the United States from the operations of a U.S. enterprise are income that is actually connected to the business or business activity in the United States. For example, profits from the sale of U.S. inventory purchased in this country or abroad are actually connected to the business or business activity income. A portion of profits or losses originating in the United States from the operations of a joint venture engaged in the business or business activity in the United States is also actually connected to the business or business activity in the United States.

Profits and losses from the sale or exchange of benefits from real estate in the United States (whether they are capital assets or not) are taxed as if you were engaged in a trade or business in the United States. You must treat the profits or losses as being in fact connected to that trade or business.

It is any interest in real estate in the United States or the U.S. Virgin Islands or any interest (other than as a debtor) in a domestic corporation that owns real estate in the United States. Real estate includes the following items. 1. Land and uncovered natural products of the land such as crops and timber, mines, wells and other natural mines. 2. Renovations on land such as buildings, other fixed structures and accompanying structural components. 3. Personal property attached to the use of real estate such as equipment used in agriculture, mining, forestry or construction or property used in accommodation or office rental, unless the personal property: 1. Has been transferred more than one year before or after the transfer of the real estate, or 2. Has been sold separately to persons not related to the seller or buyer of the real estate.
If you deal with income from real estate in the United States, the buyer may be required to deduct tax. See the discussion of Deductible Tax on Real Estate Sales in Chapter 8.

U.S. real estate gains do not include a class of shares of a company that is regularly traded on the stock market, unless you hold more than 5% of the fair market value of that class of shares (or more than 10% of those shares in the case of a real estate investment trust (REIT)).

In most cases, any distributions from a QIE to a foreign resident, foreign company or other QIE that can be attributed to the QIE's profits from the sale or exchange of interests in real estate in the United States will be treated as profits recognized by the foreign resident, foreign company or other QIE from the sale or exchange of interests in real estate in the United States. Some exceptions apply to the rule of determining income in the separate list for distributions under QIE. Distributions from a QIE relating to stocks that are regularly traded on the stock market already in the United States are not considered as profits from the sale or exchange of interests in real estate in the United States if the shareholder owns less than 5% of those shares (or less than 10% of those shares in the case of a REIT) at any time during the period of 1 year ending on the date of distribution. Distributions made by a REIT are generally not considered as profits from the sale or exchange of interests in real estate in the United States if the shareholder is a qualifying shareholder (as referred to in section 897(k)(3))). Distributions that you do not consider as profits from the sale or exchange of interests in real estate in the United States may be included in total income as regular dividends.
The treatment of shares in a REIT held directly (or indirectly through one or more joint ventures) by a qualifying shareholder will not be treated as an interest in real estate in the United States.

In order to determine whether a QIE is controlled in the United States, the following rules will apply. 1. A person holding less than 5% of any shares of a QIE, which are regularly traded on a stock market that is located in the United States at all times during the time of examination, will be considered a U.S. citizen, unless QIE knows that person is not a U.S. citizen. 2. Any shares in a QIE held by another QIE will be considered to be held by a foreigner if: 1. Any other kind of shares of a QIE are regularly traded on an existing stock market, or 2.

If this occurs, you will be considered to have made a profit from the sale or exchange of interests in U.S. real estate with an amount of money in the form of distributions being treated as dividends. This also applies to any alternative income payments. A transaction will not be considered to be an actual sale if: You actually receive distributions from a QIE controlled in the country related to the interests being processed or repurchased in the transaction or You process any class of shares in the QIE that are regularly traded on the stock market already in the U.S. but only if you do not own more than 5% of that class of shares at any time during the 1 year period ending on the date of the distribution.
There may be a minimum tax on net income from the processing of real estate benefits in the United States.

If you are a foreign partner directly or indirectly in the United States or a joint venture engaged (or deemed to have engaged) in a trade or business in the United States and you directly or indirectly deal with that interest, then the profit or loss from dealing with that interest may affect your federal tax liability. Under section 864(c)(8), your profit or loss from the sale, exchange or other dealing of that interest is deemed to be actually connected to the trade or business in the United States (“actual exchange interest” or “actual exchange loss”). However, the actual exchange profit or loss will be limited to your distribution of the actual exchange profit or loss where the joint venture sells all assets at fair market value as of the date of dealing. Section 864(c)(8) applies to sales, exchanges or other transfers occurring on or after November 27, 2017. The final provisions in section 864(c)(8) were enacted on November 6, 2020, applying to transfers occurring on or after December 26, 2018. See provisions in section 1.864(c)(8)-1(j).

Any income from a foreign country that is equivalent to any of the incomes presented above is considered to be effectively connected with a commercial or business activity in the United States. For example: interests originating from a foreign country and dividend equivalents are considered to be effectively connected income in the United States if the income originates from the banking, financial or similar business activity of a foreigner in the United States.

Income you receive in the tax year that is actually related to a U.S. business or business activity, after any allowable deductions, will be taxed at the rate applicable to U.S. citizens and residents. In general, you can only receive actual income from a U.S. business or business activity if you are a foreign resident who is engaged in a U.S. business or business activity in the tax year. However, if you receive payments from the sale or exchange of property, the provision of services, or any other transaction in the tax year in which you are not involved in a U.S. business or business activity, but those payments would be considered actual income from a U.S. business or business activity in the year in which the transaction occurred or you provided the services, they are treated as actual income from a U.S. business or business activity in the tax year in which you received them.
You can choose to treat all income from real estate as real estate income. See Income from real estate later in this chapter.

The 30% tax rate (or lower by treaty) applies only to certain incomes or interests originating in the United States when those incomes or interests are not in fact connected to a trade or business in the United States.

The 30% tax rate (or a lower rate as agreed upon by treaty) applies to all fixed, determineable, annual, or periodic dividends, interest, or income originating in the United States. Fixed income is when paid in known amounts of money. Income can be determined whenever there is a basis for determining the amount payable. Income can be periodic if paid occasionally. Income does not have to be paid annually or periodically. Income can be determined or periodic even if the period of payment increases or decreases. The amounts considered fixed or determined income are interest (other than OID), dividends, dividend equivalent payments (defined in Chapter 2), rents, royalties, annuities, wages, and other remuneration. Dividend or substitute interest payments received in securities lending transactions or repurchase transactions are treated as money received on transferred securities. Other income such as royalties may also be subject to tax. If you are unsure whether income is taxable or not..

Generally, foreign residents are subject to a 30% tax rate on total U.S. wager winnings if the income is not actually related to a U.S. business or business activity and is not treaty-exempt. However, there is no tax on non-business wager income that a foreign resident wins from playing blackjack, baccarat, craps, roulette or big 6 wheel in the U.S. A foreign resident is taxed at a progressive rate on net income from U.S. wager winnings that are actually related to a U.S. business or business activity. This income is exempt under some tax treaties. See Table 1 in the Tax Treaty Tables at IRS.gov/TreatyTables, for a list of tax treaties that exempt wager winnings from U.S. tax. For more information, see Form 915.

A temporary foreign resident must deduct 85% of U.S. social security benefits (and the equivalent social security portion of the Tier 1 railway pension benefit) from FDAP income originating in the United States. Social security benefits include retirement benefits, survivor benefits, and monthly disability benefits. This income is exempt under some tax treaties. See Table 1 in the Tax Treaty Tables, available at IRS.gov/TreatyTables for a list of tax treaties that exempt U.S. social security benefits from U.S. taxation. For more information, see Form 915.

The income in (1) is not subject to 30% (or lower by treaty) if you choose to treat the income as actually connected with a trade or business in the United States. See Income from Real Estate in the following section.

If you have not engaged in a trade or business in the United States and have not established a taxable year for a period of time, then your taxable year will be the calendar year in view of the 183-day rule. In addition, you must file your tax return annually. If you are in the United States for less than 183 days in the taxable year, interest (other than those listed in the previous section) is tax-exempt, unless the interest is actually associated with a trade or business in the United States in your taxable year.
Declare profits and losses from the sale or exchange of capital assets not actually connected to a U.S. trade or business on separate Schedule D (Form 1040) or Form 4797 or both.
