If you have income from real estate located in the United States in which you have a right of ownership or interest and keep it to generate income, you can choose to treat all of that real estate income as income actually related to a U.S. business or business activity. This option applies to all income from real estate in the United States and kept to generate income and also applies to all income from any interest in that property. Income includes income from rent, royalties from mines, oil or gas wells or other natural resources. Income from the sale or exchange of domestic timber, coal or iron ore that produces economic benefits is kept. You can only make this option for real estate income that is not actually related to a U.S. business or business activity. If you make this option, you can file real estate income deductions and only net income from your real estate is taxed. This option does not treat foreign residents who do not engage in a U.S. business or business activity as having engaged in a U.S. business or business activity during the year.
This option remains in effect for all subsequent tax years, unless you withdraw your choice at any time.

You can withdraw your option without the IRS's approval by filing Form 1040-X in the year you made the option and in subsequent tax years. You must file Form 1040-X within 3 years of the date of your tax return or 2 years of the date of your taxation, whichever is later. If this period expires in the year of the option, you cannot withdraw your option for that year. However, you can only withdraw your option for subsequent taxation years if you have the approval of the IRS. For more information on how to obtain the approval of the IRS, see section 1.871-10(a)(2)) of the Regulations.

The 4% tax rate applies to total transportation income from the United States. This only includes transportation income that is considered to originate in the United States if the transportation activity begins or ends in the United States. For transportation income derived from personal services, the transportation activity must take place between the United States and a U.S. territory. For personal services provided by a foreign resident, this applies only to income derived from or related to aircraft.

Under this special rule, you are liable to tax on your total income derived from the United States and your actual income at the progressive rate applicable to individuals (with any allowable deductions) during the period you are a foreign resident, unless you are liable to a higher rate of tax under section 871 (the general rules for the taxation of income of foreign residents, discussed in the previous section) after calculating any treaty benefits in force. For more information on how to calculate the special tax, see Taxation of Citizenship Renunciation in the following section.

If you are liable for this tax for any year during your time as a foreign resident, you must file Form 1040-NR for that year. The tax return will be due no later than the due date (including extensions) for filing the U.S. income tax return for the year you become a U.S. resident. If you have filed a tax return for that period, you must file an adjusted tax return. You must attach a statement to your tax return identifying the origin of all U.S. and foreign income and the amounts of income that comply with this special rule.

The following section describes the rules for giving up citizenship under section 877A, which apply to individuals who gave up citizenship on or after June 17, 2008. See giving up citizenship after June 16, 2008 in the following section. If you gave up citizenship before June 17, 2008, refer to giving up citizenship after June 3, 2004 and before June 17, 2008 in Chapter 4 of Issue 519 of 2018 and the Guide to Form 519 of 2018. If you give up citizenship or end your long-term resident status after June 3, 2004 and before June 17, 2008, you will still be considered a U.S. citizen or U.S. resident for tax purposes until you notify the Department of State or the Department of Homeland Security (if any) of your giving up citizenship and file Form 8854 with the IRS.

You are an LTR if you have been a legal resident of the United States for at least eight of the last 15 taxable years ending in the year of your cessation of residence. To determine whether you meet the eight-year requirement, please exclude any years you have been considered a resident of a foreign country under a tax treaty and have not waived treaty rights.
The day you renounce citizenship is the day you renounce U.S. citizenship (in the case of a former citizen) or end your long-term residency (in the case of a former U.S. resident).

You must file Form 8854 for the first time in the year you relinquish your U.S. citizenship or end your long-term residency, even if you are not a relinquisher paying a move tax on all your property in the last year. In addition, you must file Form 8854 every year after you relinquish your citizenship if you are a relinquisher paying a move tax on all your property in the last year and you: 1.

You are deemed to have terminated your long-term resident status on the earliest of the following dates. 1. The date you voluntarily relinquish your legal permanent status by filing a DHS Form I-407 to a U.S. consular or immigration officer. 2. The date you are required to comply with the final executive order in which you relinquish your legal permanent status (or, if that order has been appealed, the date of the final judicial order relating to that administrative order). 3. The date you are required to comply with the final executive order for deportation from the U.S. under the Immigration and Nationality Act. 4. If you are a resident of both the U.S. and a country with which the U.S. has an income tax treaty, the date you begin to be treated as a resident of that country under the terms of the treaty and notify the IRS of that treatment on Form 8833 and Form 8854. See the Impact of Tax Treaties in Chapter 1 for more information on dual statuses.

If you renounce your citizenship after June 16, 2008, you are considered to have renounced your citizenship and the rules for renounced citizenship under section 877A will apply if you meet any of the following conditions. 1. Your average annual net income tax in the 5 years ending prior to the date of renounced citizenship or termination of residential status is more than $201,000 if you renounce your citizenship or terminate your residential status in 2024. 2.

If you are a U.S. citizen who renounced his or her citizenship after March 18, 2010, you may be eligible for some relief procedures that are provided as an alternative to the tax compliance certification process.

Some dual citizens and minors (defined in the next section) are not subject to the tax on withdrawal of citizenship even if they meet (1) or (2) above. However, they must still provide the certification as required in (3) above.

You may qualify for the above exceptions if both of the following requirements apply. At birth, you are a U.S. citizen and a citizen of another country and from the date of renunciation, you continue to be a citizen of that other country and taxable as a permanent resident of that other country. You have been a U.S. resident for no more than 10 years in the 15-year tax period ending in the tax year in which the renunciation occurred. To determine your status as a resident of the United States, use the significant presence test described in Chapter 1.

You may qualify for the exemptions set out in the previous section if you meet both of the following requirements. You renounced your citizenship before the age of 18½. You have been a U.S. resident for more than 10 taxable years prior to renouncement. To determine your residency status in the U.S., use the significant presence test discussed in chapter 1.

In the year you renounce your citizenship, you are liable to income tax on net unrealized profits (or losses) on the property as if that property had been sold at fair market value on the day before the day you renounce your citizenship (“market-adjusted tax”). This applies to most types of property rights that you hold on the day you renounce your citizenship or end your residence. However, see Exceptions in the next section. Interest from treaty sales must be calculated in the taxable year of the treaty sale. Other U.S. tax laws do not apply. Losses from treaty sales must be calculated to the extent prescribed by U.S. tax law. However, section 1091 (regarding the non-permission of losses from fraudulent sale of shares and securities) does not apply. The net profits that you must include in your income are reduced by $866,000 if you renounce your citizenship or end your residence in 2024.

Instead, items (1) and (3) may be deducted at source. In the case of item (2), you are deemed to have received the present value of the accrued profits from this date prior to the date you relinquish your citizenship. In the case of item (4), you are deemed to have distributed all interest in the item on this date prior to the date you relinquish your citizenship. See Notice 2009-85 and the Guide to Form 8854 for more information.

After you have determined your foreigner status, your source of income, if any, and how that income is taxed in the United States, the next step is to calculate your tax. The information in this chapter is not complete for permanent aliens because it is for temporary aliens. Permanent aliens should obtain the publications, forms, and instructions for U.S. citizens because the information on filing taxes for permanent aliens is usually the same as for U.S. citizens. If you are both a temporary alien and a permanent alien in the same tax year, see Chapter 6 for a discussion of dual citizenship.

A temporary alien may claim some of the same item deductions as a permanent alien. However, a temporary alien may only claim item deductions if they have actual income related to a trade or business activity in the United States. There may be limitations affecting the item deductions you may claim on Schedule A. See the Guide to Schedule A (Form 1040) or the Guide to Schedule A (Form 1040–NR), Item Deductions in the Guide to Form 1040-NR.

You can claim the same item-by-item deductions as a U.S. citizen by using Form A (Form 1040). See the Instructions for Form A (Form 1040) for more information. If you do not enter item-by-item deductions, you can request the standard deduction for your specific tax status. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 1040.

You may deduct some item-by-item deductions if you receive income that is actually related to a U.S. business or business activity. In general, you may only deduct deductions and losses that are reasonably allocated to the actual income that is actually related to a U.S. business or business activity. You cannot deduct deductions and/or losses related to tax-exempt income or income that is not actually related to a U.S. business or business activity. However, you may deduct certain charitable contributions and losses from damages and theft even if they are not related to actual income that is actually related to a U.S. business or business activity. Use Form A (Form 1040-NR) to claim item-by-item deductions. See the Instructions for Form 1040-NR for more information.
Resident foreigners cannot claim the standard deduction. However, there is a special rule, discussed in the next section, for certain resident foreigners from India.
See the Guide to Form 4684 for more information on qualifying disaster relief. To determine whether you have been affected by a major federally declared disaster, visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.

Special rules apply to students and business trainees who qualify for the benefit under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Income Tax Treaty. You can claim the standard deduction, provided you do not claim item-by-item deductions. Use Table 5-1 to calculate the standard deduction in 2023. If you are married and your spouse files a tax return and records item-by-item deductions, you are not eligible for the standard deduction.

If you are a qualifying student or business trainee entitled under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Income Tax Treaty and are affected by a number of major disasters declared by the U.S. government in 2024 (see IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief and FEMA.gov/Disasters), you may elect to increase the standard deduction by the loss from qualifying personal injury related to disasters on your 2023 tax return.

You can deduct state and local income tax on actual income related to your business or commerce in the United States. Your deduction is limited to a total of $10,000 ($5,000 if you are married and file separately). If you have received a tax refund or tax reduction in 2024 that was paid in the previous year, please do not deduct that amount from your deduction. Instead, you must deduct the refund or reduction from your income if you have deducted taxes in the previous year and the deduction has reduced your tax. See Recoveries in Issue 525 for details on how to calculate the amount that is deducted from your income.

You may deduct charitable contributions or gifts to eligible organizations under certain limits. Eligible organizations include organizations of a religious, charitable, educational, scientific or literary nature or those that work to prevent cruelty to children or animals. Some organizations that promote national or international amateur sports competitions are also eligible. For more information on deducting charitable contributions, see Gifts to U.S. Charities in the Guide to Schedule A (Form 1040–NR), Deducting Items in the Guide to Form 1040–NR.

Contributions made directly to a foreign organization will not be deductible. However, you may deduct contributions made to a U.S. organization that transfers money to a foreign charity if the U.S. organization manages the use of the funds or the foreign organization is only a governing branch of the U.S. organization. Depending on a number of limited income tax treaties, you may qualify for deductions for contributions made to a foreign charity. See Issue 526 for details.

You can deduct losses from damage and theft on your tax return. You can only deduct losses from injury or theft outside of business if the loss is attributed to a federally declared natural disaster. If the loss from injury or theft is attributed to a federally declared natural disaster, you can deduct the loss even if your property is not related to a business or business activity in the United States. The property can be property for personal use or property generating income not related to a business or business activity in the United States. The property must be located in the United States at the time of the business or theft. You can deduct the loss from theft in the year the loss is discovered. Use Form 4684 and the instructions for calculating losses from damage and theft to be deducted. For more information, see Issue 547.
For more information, see the instructions for line 7 in the Guide to Schedule A (Form 1040–NR), Deductions by Item in the Guide to Form 1040–NR. See also Issue 529.
This section of the discussion covers tax credits and payments for permanently resident foreigners, followed by a discussion of tax credits and payments for temporary resident foreigners.
Foreign residents often request tax credits and declare tax payments, including savings, using the same rules as U.S. citizens. Below are some tax credits you may request.

You may claim a tax credit under certain limitations that apply to income tax paid or accumulated to a foreign country on income earned abroad. You cannot claim that tax credits paid or accumulated on income earned abroad are excluded. To claim an income tax credit paid or accumulated to a foreign country, you usually have to file Form 1116 together with Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. For more information, see Issue 514.

You can receive this tax credit if you pay someone to care for a qualifying dependent child under the age of 13 or a dependent or disabled spouse so that you can work or seek employment. For more information, see Form 2441 and Form 503.

You may be eligible for these tax credits if you have paid qualified educational expenses for yourself, your spouse, or dependents. There are two types of educational tax credits: the American Opportunity Tax Credit and the Lifetime Education Tax Credit. You cannot claim these types of tax credits if you are married and file separately. Use Form 8863 to calculate your tax credit. For more information, see Form 970. Foreign Residents, see Educational Tax Credit in Foreign Residents below.

You may qualify for this tax credit (also known as a saver's tax credit) if you have made qualifying contributions to an employer-funded pension plan or IRA in 2023. Use Form 8880 and the guidelines for calculating the tax credit. For more information on the rules for claiming the tax credit, see Form 590-A.

Adopted children are always considered as your natural children. Adopted children are children whose legal adoption you have accepted. If you do not have a valid SSN (or ITIN) issued on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including extensions), you cannot claim a child tax credit for this child but you can claim a tax credit for other dependents for this child. See Tax Credit for Other Dependent Persons below. Use Form 8812 (Form 1040) and the instructions for calculating the tax credit.

The tax credit for other dependents will apply to those who have dependents who do not qualify for the child tax credit. The eligible dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national or a U.S. resident alien and must have an SSN, ITIN or ATIN issued on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including extensions).

You may qualify for a tax credit of up to $16,810 for the qualifying costs paid to adopt an eligible child. This amount may be considered when adopting a child with special needs, whether you have qualifying costs or not. To claim an adoption tax credit, file Form 8839 with Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR.

The EIC or Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) is a right for working people with low to medium incomes. To qualify for the EIC, you must earn income from working for someone or running or owning a business or farm and meet the basic rules. In addition, you must meet other rules for workers without qualifying children or with children who meet all the qualifying child rules. The EIC reduces the tax you owe and may refund it to you. For more information, see IRS.gov/EIC. If you (and your spouse if filing jointly) do not have an SSN issued on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including renewals), you cannot file the EIC on the original or amendment tax return. Also, if the child does not have an SSN issued on or before the tax return due date (including renewals), you cannot claim that child as eligible for the EIC on the original or amendment tax return. If the Social Security card has a note stating “Not Valid for Employment” and a code issued to allow you (or your eligible spouse or child) to receive federally funded benefits, you cannot claim the EIC. An example of federally funded benefits is Medicaid. If the card has this note and the individual’s immigration status has changed to the extent that the individual is now a U.S. citizen or legal resident, ask the SSA to issue a new Social Security card without the note. To find out if you are eligible for the EIC, visit IRS.gov/EITCAssistant.
You can request some tax credits similar to those of a resident foreigner. You can also declare some taxes that have been paid, considered paid or deducted from income.
Only allow tax credits if you receive actual interchange income. You can request some tax credits below.

If you receive income from a foreign country that is actually related to a business or business activity in the United States, you may claim a credit for income tax paid or accumulated in any foreign country or U.S. territory on that income. If you do not have income from a foreign country that is actually related to a business or business activity in the United States, you cannot claim a U.S. tax credit for taxes paid or accumulated in a foreign country or U.S. territory. You cannot receive any tax credit that a foreign country or U.S. territory imposes on income from the United States if those taxes are only applied because you are a citizen or resident of that foreign country or territory. If you claim a tax credit on income earned from a foreign country, you usually have to file a tax return with Form 1116. See Form 514 for more information.

You may receive this tax credit if you pay money to someone to care for a qualifying child who is a dependent under the age of 13 or a disabled dependent or a disabled spouse so that you can work or seek employment. For definitions of these terms, see Form 503. Married foreign residents can only claim the tax credit if they elect to file jointly with a U.S. citizen or a U.S. resident spouse as discussed in How to make an election in Chapter 1 or if they qualify as married individuals living separately (see Joint Return Test in Form 503). The amount of money paid for the care of a qualifying child and dependent in any tax year cannot exceed the income earned from the U.S. in that tax year. Income from employment is usually wages, salaries and professional services fees for personal services performed. For more information, see Form 503.
Further information on the tax credit for eligible educational expenses of students in the first four years of college is available at IRS.gov/AOTC.

Adopted children are always considered as your natural children. Adopted children are children whose legal adoption you have accepted. If you do not have a valid SSN (or ITIN) issued on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including extensions), you cannot claim a child tax credit for this child but you can claim a tax credit for other dependents for this child. See Tax Credit for Other Dependent Persons below. Use Form 8812 (Form 1040) and the instructions for calculating the tax credit.

A dependent who is not eligible for a child tax credit may still qualify for a tax credit for other dependents. This is a non-refundable tax credit of $500 per qualifying person. The eligible dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national or a U.S. resident alien. See the Instructions for Form 1040-NR. To claim a tax credit for other dependents, the dependent must have an SSN, ITIN or ATIN issued on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including extensions). Only foreign residents who are U.S. citizens; permanent residents of Canada, Mexico or South Korea; or students and business trainees from India who qualify for the benefits under Article 21(2) of the income tax treaty signed with India may claim a tax credit for other dependents.

You may qualify for a tax credit of up to $16,810 when you have paid eligible costs for a qualifying child. This amount may be allowed for adopting a child with special needs, regardless of whether you have eligible costs. To claim a tax credit for an adopted child, file Form 8839 together with Form 1040-NR. A married foreign resident may only claim a tax credit if they elect to file jointly with a spouse who is a citizen or a resident, discussed in the section A spouse who is a resident in Chapter 1, or if they qualify as married individuals living apart (see Married Persons Not Filing Jointly in the Guide to Form 8839).
If you paid the minimum substitute tax in the previous year, use Form 8801 and the instructions to find out if you qualify for this tax credit.

If you are a foreign resident at any time of the year, you usually cannot claim an EIC. However, if you have married and elected to file jointly with a spouse who is a U.S. citizen or resident discussed in Spouse as a temporary resident is considered a resident in Chapter 1, you may qualify for this tax credit. If you and your spouse do not have an SSN issued on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including renewals), you cannot claim an EIC on the original tax return or the 2024 adjusted tax return. Furthermore, if a child does not have an SSN issued on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including renewals), you cannot claim that child as an eligible child when calculating the EIC on the original or adjusted 2024 tax return. If your Social Security card has a note stating “Not Valid for Employment” and the number was issued to allow you (or your eligible spouse or child) to receive federally sponsored benefits, you cannot claim an EIC. An example of a federally sponsored benefit is Medicaid. If the card has this note and the individual’s immigration status has changed to currently be a U.S. citizen or legal resident, request the SSA to issue a new Social Security card without the note. See Issue 596 for more information on this tax credit.
You can report the tax deducted in the year as a payment of U.S. tax. You can claim the deductible on lines 25a-25g of Form 1040-NR. The deductible will reduce the tax you owe on Form 1040-NR.

Any federal income tax deducted from your salary in the tax year when you were a resident alien is considered a payment of your U.S. income tax debt in the same year. You can file deducted income tax whether or not you engaged in a trade or business in the U.S. in the year and the salary (or any other income) was related to a trade or business in the U.S.

If you have two or more employers, you may request a deduction of your U.S. income tax debt for deducted social security taxes in excess of the mandatory maximum. See Social Security and Medicare Taxes in Chapter 8 for more information.

Employers are responsible for withholding 0.9% (0.009) additional Medicare tax on Medicare wages or Red River Retirement Tax (RRTA) compensation paid to you in excess of $200,000 in 2024. If you do not owe additional Medicare tax, you can request a deduction of any additional Medicare tax that has been deducted from the total tax debt on your tax return by filing Form 8959.

If you are a shareholder of a mutual fund (or other RIC) or REIT, you can request a tax deduction for the part paid by the company on the undistributed long-term interest. You will receive information on Form 2439, which you must attach to your tax return.

You may declare as payment any withholding tax on investment activity and FDAP income paid to you. Fixed or determined income includes interest, dividends, rent and royalties that you do not declare as actual interim income. Wages or salaries may be fixed or determined income but usually depend on the deduction discussed above. Tax on fixed or determined income is deductible at 30% or less under the treaty.

If you are a foreign member of a limited liability company, that company will deduct ECTI from the limited liability company. The limited liability company will provide you with a report on Form 8805 stating the deducted tax. A public limited liability company may deduct the deductible tax on the actual distribution of the actual combined income. In this case, the limited liability company will provide you with a report on Form 1042-S. The deductible tax is the payment on line 25e or line 25g of Form 1040-NR if deemed appropriate.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in the United States or a joint venture that engages (or is considered to engage) in a trade or business in the United States and you directly or indirectly transfer that interest for profit, then for transfers after 2017, the transferee will generally deduct and pay tax on your behalf in the amount of 10% of the proceeds from the sale. The deduction and payment rules for this amount are similar to the sale of interests in real estate in the United States. You will receive Form 8288-A reflecting the deduction that you can file on line 25f of Form 1040-NR as a tax credit that you owe when you collect the dividends. You can provide some information to the transferee to reduce or eliminate the deduction. For example: if the non-recognized clause in the Tax Code applies to all the proceeds from the transfer transaction, the transferee does not need to deduct if you give notice describing the application of the non-recognized clause. If you are a non-deductible transferee under section 1446(f)(4), the joint venture may deduct the deduction in the distributions for you. T.D. 9926 (85 FR 76910), published on November 30, 2020 (as amended by 86 FR 13191), includes final provisions (defining section 1446(f)) relating to the deduction and return required by section 1446(f) for transfers of interest in certain interests of the joint venture, including the retention requirement for the transfer of interests in the joint venture.

You can declare a deferred tax payment related to a transfer of interest in real estate in the United States (or income deemed to have originated from a transfer of interest in real estate in the United States). See Real Estate Profits or Losses in chapter 4. The buyer will provide you with a deferred tax payment report on Form 8288-A. The deferred tax payment is declared on line 25f of Form 1040-NR.

When you fill in your tax return, be careful when filling in the amount of deducted tax that appears on your information documents. The following table lists some of the most common information documents and indicates where you can find the deducted tax.

If you are a temporary alien resident who is a resident of American Samoa or a resident of Puerto Rico in fact for the entire tax year, you are usually taxed as a permanent alien. You should file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and report all income from sources in and outside the United States. However, you may exclude income discussed in the following paragraphs. However, for tax purposes, in addition to filing income, you will be treated as a temporary alien. For example: you are not eligible for the standard deduction, you cannot file a general tax return, and you cannot file a dependent unless the person is a U.S. citizen or national. There are also limitations on deductions and tax credits allowed. See Foreign Resident in Deductions, Individual Deductions, and Tax Credits and Payments in this chapter.

If you are a real Puerto Rican resident for the whole year, you can exclude all income from sources in the Puerto Rican territory (except for payments for services performed as an employee of the United States or any U.S. agency) from your total income. If you report your income annually and have no deductible salary in 2024, please file your tax return and pay your taxes by June 16, 2025. You must also make your first estimated tax payment in 2025 by June 16, 2025. You cannot file general income tax or pay general estimated tax. However, if you are married to a U.S. citizen or resident, see Your spouse is a temporary resident in Chapter 1. If your salary is deductible, your U.S. income tax return will be due by April 15, 2025. You must also make your first estimated tax payment in 2025 by April 15, 2025. For information on deductible and estimated taxes, see Chapter 8.

If you are a genuine resident of American Samoa for the whole year, you may exclude all income from sources in the territory of American Samoa (except for payments for services performed as an employee of the United States Government or any agency of the United States Government). Employees of the Government of American Samoa are not considered as employees of the United States Government or any agency of the United States Government for tax exemption purposes. For more information on this exemption, see Form 4563 and Form 570.

You must calculate your income and file your tax returns on the basis of the annual accounting period called the tax year. If you have not set a fiscal year, your tax year will be a solar calendar year. A solar calendar year is 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have set a normal fiscal year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December or a year with 52-53 weeks) and are considered a U.S. resident in any year, you will be considered a U.S. resident at any time in the fiscal year that falls into that year.

A tax identification number (TIN) is provided on tax returns, reports, and other tax documents. For individuals, this is the Social Security Number (SSN). If you do not have and are not eligible for an SSN, you must file for an International Tax Identification Number (ITIN). An employer tax identification number (EIN) is required if you are engaged in a trade or business as a sole proprietorship and have a qualifying employee or retirement program. You must provide a TIN if you are: A foreign national who has actual income connected with the conduct of a trade or business in the United States at any time during the year; A foreign national who has an office or place of business in the United States at any time during the year; A temporary resident spouse who is considered a resident, as discussed in Chapter 1; or Any other foreign national who files a tax return, adjusted tax return, or claims a tax refund (but not an information return).

In general, you can get an SSN if you have been legally admitted to the United States as a permanent resident or under other immigration forms that allow you to work in the United States. If you do not have an SSN, contact the Department of Social Security (SSA) to find out if you qualify for an SSN. For more information, visit SSA.gov or call 800-772-1213 (for deaf or hard of hearing, call TTY, 800-325-0778).

If you have an F-1, M-1 or J-1 visa, see SSA Publication 05-10181, available at SSA.gov/Pubs/10181.html for more information on the types of documents you must provide to prove your immigration status.

If you already have an ITIN, fill in the ITIN anywhere the SSN is required on your tax return. If you do not have an ITIN and are not eligible for an SSN, you must file for an ITIN. For details on how to do this, see the Form W-7 and instructions. If you are eligible for an ITIN and your application is complete, you will usually receive a TIN designation letter from the IRS within 7 weeks. If you have not received an ITIN or other letter within 7 weeks of filing, call the IRS toll-free number at 800-829-1040 to request the status of your application if you are in the U.S. territory. If you are outside the U.S. territory, call 267-941-1000 (not a toll-free number). The ITIN is for tax purposes only. This does not entitle you to social security benefits or change your employment or immigration status under U.S. law. In addition to the requirement for foreigners to provide an ITIN and not eligible for an SSN, you must file a Form W-7 for your spouse or dependent who is a foreigner and is eligible for tax benefits but not eligible for an SSN. More information on obtaining an ITIN is available in the W-7 Guide and at IRS.gov/ITIN.

Some ITINs need to be renewed. If you have not used your ITIN on a federal tax return at least once for the tax year 2021, 2022, or 2023, it will expire on December 31, 2024, and must be renewed if you need to file a federal tax return for the tax year 2024. You do not need to renew your ITIN if you do not need to file a federal tax return. To renew your ITIN, see the W-7 form and instructions at IRS.gov/FormW7. For more information, visit IRS.gov/ITIN. An ITIN issued before 2013 has expired and must be renewed if you need to file for the tax year 2024. If you have previously filed for an extension and this application has been approved, you do not need to renew unless you have not used your ITIN on a federal tax return at least once for the tax year 2021, 2022, or 2023.
Individuals can use the SSN (or ITIN) for personal tax and the EIN for business tax. For more information on the EIN, visit IRS.gov/EIN.

Taxes depend on your tax status. Tax status is important in determining whether you are entitled to certain deductions and tax credits. The rules for determining tax status are different for permanent and temporary residents.
Foreign residents may use the same tax status as U.S. citizens. See the instructions for our form or Form 501 for more information on tax status.

In general, you can only file as a spouse filing jointly if both you and your spouse are U.S. citizens or foreign residents for the entire tax year or if you are a temporary resident spouse considered a resident as discussed in Chapter 1.

If your spouse dies in 2022 or 2023 and you do not remarry before the end of 2024, you may qualify to file as the remaining eligible spouse and use the common tax rate. This only applies if you filed jointly with your spouse in the year they died. For more information on the tax status of the remaining eligible spouse, see Qualifying Surviving Spouse in the Filing Status in the Guide to Form 1040 in 2024.

You may qualify as a householder if you are unmarried or considered unmarried on the last day of the year and you pay more than half of the cost of maintaining your home and one eligible person. You must be a foreign resident for the entire tax year. For this purpose, you will be considered unmarried if your spouse is a foreign resident at any time of the year and the spouse does not choose to be considered a resident, as discussed in chapter 1 in The temporary spouse is considered a resident.
If you are a resident alien filing Form 1040-NR then you may use one of the tax returning capacities discussed in the following section.

A foreign resident who is married to a person who is not a U.S. citizen or resident usually has to use the Tax Schedule or the Tax Estimate column to file separately when determining the amount of tax on income that is actually associated with a trade or business activity in the United States.

A married foreign resident is not usually eligible to use the Single Tax Schedule or Single Tax Calculator. However, you may file as a single person if you live away from your spouse for the last 6 months of the year and you are a married Canadian, Mexican or Korean citizen or you are a married U.S. citizen. See the Instructions for Form 1040-NR to see if you are eligible.

Individuals, although not U.S. citizens, who have a duty to the government to the United States, are considered U.S. citizens. In addition, U.S. citizenship also includes American Samoa and the residents of the Northern Mariana Islands who have chosen to become U.S. citizens instead of U.S. citizens.

If your spouse dies in 2022 or 2023 and you do not remarry before the end of 2024, you may qualify as a qualifying surviving spouse and use the general tax rate. For more information on the qualifying surviving spouse's tax status, see Qualifying Surviving Spouse in the Filing Status section of the 2024 Form 1040-NR Guide.

You cannot file as a householder if you are a foreign resident at any time in the tax year. However, if you are married, your spouse may qualify as a householder if: Your spouse has been a foreign resident or a U.S. citizen for the entire tax year; You choose not to be treated as a foreign resident; and Your spouse meets the other requirements for this tax status, as discussed in the previous section on Foreign Residents.

A resident foreigner's real estate or trust using Form 1040-NR must use the W-Rate Schedule in the Guide to Form 1040-NR when determining tax on income actually associated with business or trade activities in the United States.

A temporary resident foreigner who is a genuine resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year and who is also a temporary worker in the United States should see the section on the genuine residents of American Samoa or Puerto Rico at the end of this chapter for information on the special rules for such a person.

You must declare each taxable income according to the rules in Chapters 2, 3 and 4. For foreign residents, this includes income originating both within and outside the United States. For temporary residents, this includes both income actually related to a trade or business in the United States (subject to progressive taxation) and income originating from the United States that is not actually related to a trade or business in the United States (subject to a fixed rate of 30% or less, if treaty-based).

Resident and non-resident foreigners can claim similar deductions on their U.S. tax returns. However, non-resident foreigners can usually only claim deductions related to income actually linked to a trade or business activity in the United States.

You can claim the same deductions as a U.S. citizen if you are a permanent alien for the entire tax year. See the discussion in Temporary aliens later on, where some of the same rules and principles apply to you, especially as a temporary alien. You should see the Guide to Form 1040 for more information on how to claim the deductions that are allowed.

You may claim deductions for the purpose of calculating your actual combined income (ECTI). In general, you cannot claim deductions for income that is not actually related to your business activity in the United States. Except for some individual deductions discussed in the next section, you can only claim deductions to the extent that they relate to your actual combined income.

You may deduct all expenses that are required by custom in a U.S. business or business activity to the extent that they relate to the actual income associated with that business or business activity. For more information on other business expenses, see the Guide to Business Expenses Resources.

If you paid interest in 2024 on a qualifying student loan, you may be eligible for a deduction of up to $2,500 of interest paid. In general, you may claim a deduction if you meet all the requirements. This deduction is made on line 21 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) with your Form 1040-NR. To calculate the deduction, see the Instructions for Form 1040-NR. For more information, see Issue 970.

If you have actual income associated with a trade or business in the United States, you may deduct up to 20% of your qualifying business income from trade or business, plus 20% of qualifying REIT dividends and income from a qualifying public limited company (PTP). For more information, see Line 13a in the Guide to Form 1040-NR. For more information on deducting qualifying business income, see Form 8995, Form 8995-A and related returns, as well as instructions for the related forms and returns.

You can deduct losses arising from transactions you engage in for profit and not for reimbursement, etc., to the extent that they relate to actual income connected with the activity of trading or doing business in the United States.

If you are a qualifying educator in 2024, you may deduct as an income adjustment up to $300 of unrefundable qualifying expenses you paid or incurred in 2024 for professional development courses, books, supplies (not including materials for health or physical education courses), computer equipment (including related software and services), and other additional equipment and materials you use in class. For more information, see the tax return guide. Eligible expenses include payments or expenses incurred in 2024 for protective equipment, disinfectants, and other items used to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

If you have made contributions to a traditional IRA in 2024, you may be eligible for an IRA deduction. However, to do so, you must have an actual taxable remuneration associated with a commercial or business activity in the United States. An IRA deduction will be sent to you by June 2, 2025, stating all contributions to a traditional IRA in 2024. If you receive a retirement plan (qualifying salary, profit sharing (including 401(k)), annuity, SEP, SIMPLE, etc.) at work or through self-employment, the IRA deduction may be reduced or eliminated. However, you may still make contributions to a traditional IRA even if you cannot deduct them. If you make non-deductible contributions to a traditional IRA in 2024, you may report them on Form 8606. For more information, see Form 590-A.

Only deduct travel costs if you are a member of the United States Armed Forces on duty and travel on command due to a long-term change of location. For more information, see Issue 3. If you qualify, use Form 3903 to calculate the amount to be deducted.

Excludes the value of transport and storage services from income provided by the government due to long-term change of stationing. Similarly, excludes income received as relocation allowance, temporary accommodation expenses, temporary accommodation allowance or housing allowance upon arrival. For more information, see Issue 3.

If you are self-employed, you may deduct contributions to SEP, SIMPLE, or a qualifying retirement program to provide statutory retirement benefits for yourself and your employees (if any). To contribute under the self-deductible, you must have net income from self-employment that is actually associated with a trade or business activity in the United States. See Form 560 for more information.

You must calculate the total actual interest income you received or were credited to the account during the year. This amount is not reduced by any penalty you pay for early withdrawals from a fixed-term savings account. However, if the actual interest income is from commercial or business activities in the United States during the year, you may deduct on line 18 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) the early withdrawal penalty that the banking institution applies. Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR.

You must provide the SSN (or ITIN) of any dependents you enter in the Dependents section of your 1040-NR. If you do not provide an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN in the Dependents section of your tax return, or if you provide an incorrect number, some tax benefits may not be granted. See Identification Numbers in the previous section.

If you are a foreign resident, a qualifying dependent is either a qualifying child or a qualifying person. A child must meet five criteria to be a qualifying child. A person must meet five criteria to be a qualifying person. For more information, see the Guide to Form 1040. If you do not provide a SSN, ITIN, or ATIN in the Dependents section of your tax return, or if you provide an incorrect number, some tax benefits may not be granted. See Identification Numbers in the previous section..

If you are a Mexican or Canadian citizen or a U.S. citizen, you can declare each of your dependents to meet certain criteria. Mexican or Canadian citizen or U.S. citizen must use the same rules as U.S. citizens to determine who is a dependent. See the 501(c)(3) section for these rules.

Foreign residents who are Korean residents (not employees of the Korean government) may declare their children as eligible dependents. In addition to using the same rules as U.S. citizens to determine who is a dependent, under the income tax treaty signed with South Korea, the child must live with the foreign resident in the United States at some point during the tax year if the foreign resident is a resident of the United States.
Students and business trainees eligible for the benefit under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Income Tax Treaty may declare dependents if they meet the same rules as U.S. citizens.

You have a tax year with dual status when you are both a permanent resident and a temporary resident foreigner in the same year. Dual status does not refer to your nationality; dual status only refers to your tax-related residency status in the United States. When determining your U.S. income tax liability in a tax year with dual status, several different rules apply at one time of the year you are a U.S. resident and at another time of the year you are a temporary resident. The most common tax years with dual status are the year of entry and the year of exit. See Foreigners with Dual Status in Chapter 1. If you have married and chosen to be a temporary resident spouse treated as a permanent resident as explained in Chapter 1, the rules in this chapter do not apply to you in that year.

If you are a foreign resident on the last day of the tax year and file your income tax annually, you must file no later than April 15 of the year following the end of your tax year (but see MODE, in the section below). If you file your income tax non-annually, or file your tax return no later than the 15th of the fourth month following the end of your tax year, in both cases, file your tax return to this address for foreigners with dual citizenship listed on the back of the Instructions for Form 1040. If you are a foreign resident on the last day of the tax year and file your income tax annually, you must file your tax return no later than April 15 of the year following the end of your tax year if you receive a deductible salary. If you file your income tax non-annually, file your tax return no later than the 15th of the fourth month following the end of your tax year. If you do not receive a deductible salary and file your income tax annually, you must file your tax return no later than June 15 of the year following the end of your tax year. If you file your income tax non-annually, file your tax return no later than June 15 of the month following the end of your tax year. In all cases, send your tax return by mail to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 If you send a payment, send your tax return by mail to: Internal Revenue Service P.O. Box 1303 Charlotte, NC 28201-1303 If the normal tax return due date is Saturday, C

You must file your tax returns for the annual accounting period called the tax year. If you have not set a fiscal year, your tax year will be a solar calendar year. A solar calendar year is 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have set a normal fiscal year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December or a year with 52-53 weeks) and are considered a U.S. resident in any year, you will be considered a U.S. resident at any time in the fiscal year that falls into that year.

At any time of the year you are a foreign resident, you are subject to income tax from all sources. Income from sources outside the United States is taxed if you receive it as a foreign resident. Income is taxed even if you earn it as a foreign resident or if you become a foreign resident after receiving it and before the end of the year. At any time of the year you are a foreign resident, you are subject to income tax from sources in the United States and certain income from foreign sources is considered to be actually connected to a business or business activity in the United States. The rule of treating income from foreign sources as actually connected is discussed in Chapter 4 in Income from abroad. Income from sources outside the United States is not taxed if you receive it as a foreign resident. This income is not taxed even if you earn it as a foreign resident or if you become a foreign resident or a U.S. citizen after receiving it and before the end of the year. Income from sources in the United States is taxed whether you receive it as a foreign resident or as a foreign resident, unless exempt under the Tax Code or the terms of the tax treaty. Generally, the terms of the tax treaty only apply to a time of the year you are not a resident. However, in some cases, the terms of the tax treaty may apply when you are a foreign resident. See Chapter 9 for more information. When determining which income is subject to U.S. tax, you must consider exemptions under U.S. tax law, as well as reduced and exempt rates under tax treaties between the United States and certain foreign countries. For more information, see the section on taxation of income from foreign sources.
The following restrictions will apply if you are filing for the tax year with dual status.
You cannot use the standard deductions allowed on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. However, you can enter any deductions allowed as individual deductions.
You cannot use the Tax Table or Tax Calculation Table columns for the host bytes.
You cannot file a general tax return. However, see Selecting the Status of a Permanent Resident Alien in Aliens with Dual Status in chapter 1.

See the Instructions for Form 1040-NR to see if you qualify. U.S. citizens are individuals, although not U.S. citizens with a duty to the government to the United States. U.S. citizens include American Samoa and residents of the Northern Mariana Islands who choose to become U.S. citizens instead of U.S. citizens.

As a dual-status taxpayer, you may declare a dependent on your tax return. In general, a dependent is a qualifying child or qualifying person. You may be entitled to additional deductions and tax credits if you have a qualifying dependent. See the Instructions for Form 1040 or the Instructions for Form 1040-NR for more information. If you are a U.S. citizen or a resident of Canada or Mexico, you may declare a dependent under the same conditions as a U.S. citizen. If you are a resident of the U.S. or India, see Chapter 5.
When you calculate U.S. tax for a dual-status year, you have to follow several different rules for a time of the year when you are a resident and a time of the year when you are not a resident.

All income during your residence and all income actually related to a U.S. business or business activity during your non-residence, after any allowable deductions, will be added up and taxed at the rate applicable to U.S. citizens and residents. Income not actually related to a U.S. business or business activity during your non-residence is subject to a flat rate of 30% or less under the treaty. You do not receive any deductions for this income unless you have a taxable income of more than $100,000 or $100,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000

At any time of the year you are a temporary alien, 85% of the U.S. social security benefits (and the equivalent part of the Tier 1 railway pension benefit) you receive are taxable at 30%, unless you are exempt or taxed at a lower rate under a treaty. See Taxation at 30% in chapter 4. At any time of the year you are a permanent alien, a portion of the social security and an equivalent portion of the Tier 1 railway pension benefit will be subject to cumulative taxation if your total adjusted income plus half of this benefit exceeds a certain base amount. Use the Social Security Benefits Calculation Table in the Form 1040 Guide to help you determine the taxable portion of the U.S. social security and Tier 1 railway pension benefit equivalent at any time of the year you are a permanent alien. If you receive U.S. social security benefits while you are a temporary alien, the SSA will send you Form SSA-1042S stating your combined entitlements for the year and the deducted tax. You will not receive a separate report on the entitlements received during the time you reside and not reside in the U.S. So it is important that you keep a careful record of these amounts. You need this information to fill in your tax return correctly and calculate your tax liability. If you receive a railway pension benefit while you are a temporary alien, the U.S. Railway Pension Board (RRB) will send you Form RRB-1042S, Return for Recipient as a Temporary Alien from the Railway Pension Board and/or Form RRB-1099-R, Annual or Retirement from the Railroad Pension Board.
This section of the discussion refers to tax credits and payments to foreigners with dual status.

As a dual-status foreigner, you can usually claim tax credits using the same rules as a resident foreigner. There are some restrictions that may apply. These restrictions are discussed here, along with a brief explanation of the tax credits that are usually requested by individuals. You cannot claim an educational tax credit, an EIC, or a tax credit for seniors or disabled persons, unless you are married and you choose to be treated as a resident for the entire year 2024 by filing jointly with your spouse who is a U.S. citizen or resident, discussed in section 1.

If you have paid or are liable to pay income tax to a foreign country on income from foreign sources, you may request a foreign tax credit. If you request a foreign tax credit, you will usually have to file Form 1116 with your income tax return. For more information, please see the Instructions for Form 1116 and Form 514.

You may qualify for this tax credit if you pay money to someone to care for a qualifying dependent child under the age of 13 or a disabled dependent or a disabled spouse, so that you can work or seek employment. A married foreigner with dual status can only claim the tax credit if they choose to file the tax return discussed in Chapter 1 or if they qualify as married individuals living separately. The eligible child and dependent care expenses in any tax year cannot exceed the income earned in that tax year. For more information, see Form 503 and Form 2441.

Adopted children are always considered as your natural children. Adopted children are children whose legal adoption you have accepted. If you do not have a valid SSN (or ITIN) issued on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including extensions), you cannot claim a child tax credit for the child but you can claim a tax credit for other dependents for this child. See Tax Credit for Other Dependent Persons below. Use Form 8812 (Form 1040) and the instructions to calculate the tax credit.

The tax credit for other dependents will apply to those who have dependents who do not qualify for the child tax credit. The eligible dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national or a U.S. resident alien and must have an SSN, ITIN or ATIN issued on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including extensions).

You may qualify for a tax credit of up to $16,810 for qualifying expenses paid to adopt an eligible child. This amount may be allowed for adopting a child with special needs, whether you have qualifying expenses or not. To claim the tax credit for adopting a child, file Form 8839 with your U.S. income tax return. A married foreigner with dual citizenship can only claim the tax credit if they choose the option The spouse is a temporary resident as discussed in Chapter 1 or if they qualify as married individuals living separately (see Married Persons Not Filing Jointly in the Guide to Form 8839).

You can also declare that the payment of U.S. income tax owed has been filed, considered to have been paid, or has been deducted from your income. These options include: Tax deducted from salary earned in the United States, Tax deducted at source from various incomes originating in the United States other than salary, Estimated tax filed with Form 1040-ES or Form 1040-ES (NR), and Tax paid with Form 1040-C at the time of departure from the United States.
The U.S. income tax return you must file as a dual-citizen alien depends on whether you are a resident alien or a temporary resident alien at the end of the taxation year.

You must file a Form 1040 or a Form 1040-SR if you are a dual-citizen taxpayer who has become a resident in the year and is a U.S. resident on the last day of the taxation year. Write "Dual-Status Return" at the top of the form. Attach a statement to your tax return to state the income for a period of the year you are not a resident. You can use the Form 1040-NR as a statement. However, make sure that you write "Dual-Status Statement" at the top of the statement.

You must file Form 1040-NR if you are a dual-citizen taxpayer who renounces your US residency status during the year and are not a U.S. resident on the last day of the tax year. Enter "Dual-Status Return" at the top of the return. Attach a statement with your tax return to show your income at any time during the year you are a resident. You can use either Form 1040 or Form 1040-NR as your return. However, make sure you check the "Dual-Status Statement" at the top. If you renounce your citizenship or end your residency status in 2024, you may have to file a renouncer's statement (Form 8854) with your tax return. For more information, see Tax renouncement in chapter 4.

Any report must have your name, address and taxpayer identification number on it. You do not need to sign the separate report or the list that accompanies the tax return because your signature on the tax return also applies to the report and the list.
The tax return to be filed, the time and place of filing that tax return, depending on your status at the end of the tax year as a resident alien or a temporary resident alien.

A foreign resident must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR at the address listed in the Instructions for Form 1040. The due date for filing and paying all taxes due is April 15 of the year following the year you file (but see TIP before). Under U.S. immigration law, a legal resident must file tax returns as a permanent resident. If they do not do so, they may be deemed to have renounced their status and may lose their permanent status.

You may be granted an automatic 6-month extension (October 15 for annual taxpayers) if you file Form 4868 not later than the tax filing deadline. For more information, see Form 4868. The automatic 6-month extension will not extend your tax filing period. If you do not pay your tax by the initial tax filing deadline, you will owe interest on the outstanding tax and may be fined. You are automatically granted an extension until June 15 if your main place of business and home are outside the United States and Puerto Rico on April 15. If you need more time at the end of the 2-month period, you may be granted an additional 4-month extension until October 15 if you file Form 4868 not later than June 15. In addition to the 6-month extension, an overseas taxpayer (defined in the Guide to Form 4868) may request an extension to file his tax return for any additional two months (December 15 for annual taxpayers). To request an extension, you must write to the IRS explaining why you need the additional two months. Write before the extended deadline (October 15 for annual taxpayers) to the following address. Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 You will not receive any notice from the IRS, unless your request is denied for non-deadline. The optional 2-month extension does not apply to taxpayers who have received an extension to file Form 2350 (for U.S. citizens and non-residents).

You must also file a tax return if you want to: Claim a refund of deducted or overpaid tax or Claim a deduction or credit. For example, if you do not have a business in the United States but have income from real estate that you choose to treat as Actual Intermediate Income (discussed in Chapter 4), you must file an accurate tax return on time to receive any deductions allowed for that income. For information about which items are due, see When to file for deductions and credits in the Time to file section below.

Even if you have left the United States and filed a Form 1040-C on departure, you still have to file a U.S. income tax return annually. If you are married and both you and your spouse have to file a tax return, each of you must file a separate tax return.

If a foreigner owns all of the domestic DE, the domestic DE will be treated as a separate domestic company from the owner (a foreigner) for the purposes of the restrictions of section 6038A applicable to the 25% foreign-owned domestic company. A foreign-owned domestic DE must file the appropriate Form 1120 together with Form 5472 before the due date (including extensions). The only information to be filled in to Form 1120 is the name and address of the foreign-owned domestic DE and the sections B and E in the first part. A foreign-owned domestic DE may have been required to report prior to 2017 if the entity has engaged in commercial or other activities requiring reporting. See the Guide to Form 5472 for information on how to combine it with the domestic DE filing. Also note that because the domestic DE is usually a transparent legal entity, the foreigner will fill in (or continue to calculate) any taxes required by the domestic DE on Form 1040-NR.

If you are an employee and receive a U.S. income tax deduction, you will usually file your tax return by the 15th of the fourth month following the end of your tax year. In 2024, the latest date to file your tax return is April 15, 2025. If you are not an employee receiving a U.S. income tax deduction, you must file your tax return by the 15th of the sixth month following the end of your tax year. In 2024, the latest date to file your tax return is June 16, 2025.

If you are unable to file your tax return on the due date, file Form 4868 or use one of the electronic tax returning options explained in the Instructions for Form 4868. In 2024, this period will be extended to 15 October 2025. If your normal due date is 16 June 2025, then this date will be extended to 15 December 2025. You must apply for the extension before the regular tax return due date. The automatic 6-month extension will not extend your tax payment period. If you do not pay your tax by the original due date of the return, you will owe interest on the unpaid tax and may be fined. See Form 4868.

The tax exemption for subsequent credits is not affected by this time rule. Tax credits have been discounted. Special consumption tax credits on certain purposes use of gasoline and special fuels. Tax credits paid by a mutual fund (or other RIC) or REIT on long-term undistributed interest.

If your activities in the United States are restricted and you do not believe that you have a total income that is actually related to your commercial or business activities in the United States during the year, you may file a protective tax return (Form 1040-NR) no later than the due date explained above. By filing a protective tax return, you will protect your right to benefit from deductions and tax credits in the event that some or all of your income is later determined to be related. You do not have to declare any related income or any deductions on the protective tax return, but you must state the reason for filing a protective tax return. If you believe that some of your activities result in related income, file a tax return reporting that income and the related deductions before the normal due date. To protect your right to claim deductions or tax credits from other activities, attach a statement to that tax return, explaining that you want to protect your right to claim deductions and tax credits if it is later determined that other activities generate related income. You can do the same thing if you believe that you are not owed U.S. tax under a U.S. tax treaty. Make sure that you also complete section L on the Schedule OI (Form 1040-NR).

The IRS may exempt you from filing if you determine that based on the facts and circumstances, you have acted reasonably and in good faith in not filing a U.S. income tax return (including a protective tax return) and you cooperate with the IRS in determining your U.S. income tax liability for the tax year in which you did not file.

If you do not attach a payment, file Form 1040-NR at the following address. Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215. If you attach a payment, send the tax return by mail to: Internal Revenue Service P.O. Box 1303 Charlotte, NC 28201-1303

Declare all income from U.S. sources, as well as income from other sources, when you file your tax return. For information on filing a U.S. Virgin Islands tax return, contact the U.S. Virgin Islands Revenue Office. If you are a U.S. Virgin Islands resident for the entire tax year and work temporarily in the U.S., you must pay income tax to the U.S. Virgin Islands and file your income tax return at the following address. Virgin Islands Bureau of Internal Revenue 6115 Estate Smith Bay Suite 225 St. Thomas, VI 00802. Chapter 8 discusses deductions from U.S. Virgin Islands residents' wages.

If you are a genuine resident of Guam or CNMI for the entire tax year, you must file and pay any taxes due to Guam or CNMI. Report all income, including income from the United States, on your tax return. There is no need to file a separate U.S. income tax return. A genuine resident of Guam must file a Guam tax return at the following address. Department of Revenue and Taxation Government of Guam P.O. Box 23607 Barrigada, GU 96921. A genuine resident of CNMI should file a CNMI tax return at the following address. Saipan Central Office Division of Revenue and Taxation P.O. Box 5234 CHRB Saipan, MP 96950. If you are not a genuine resident of Guam or CNMI, see Form 570 for information on where to file your tax return.

If you notice changes in your income, deductions or tax credits after filing your tax return by mail, file Form 1040-X. Also use Form 1040-X if you should have filed Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR instead of Form 1040-NR or vice versa. If you amend Form 1040-NR or file an amended tax return, enter "Amended" at the top and attach the amended return (Form 1040, Form 1040-SR or Form 1040-NR) with Form 1040-X. Normally, the amended return requesting tax refund must be filed within 3 years of the tax return date or within 2 years of the tax payment date, whichever is later. Tax returns filed before the final due date are deemed to have been filed on the due date.
You may be required to file a return providing information to declare some foreign income or assets or currency transactions.
FinCEN Form 105 is mandatory under 31 U.S.C. 5316 and the regulations of the Treasury Department (31 CFR, chapter X).
The form is available at FinCEN.gov/resources/filing-information. For more information on the BSA's E-Filing, see the E-Filing section at BSAefiling.fincen.treas.gov/main.html.

You must file Form 8938 if the total value of those assets exceeds the applicable threshold (the "reporting threshold"). The reporting threshold varies depending on whether you live in the United States, are married, or file income tax jointly with your spouse. Foreign financial assets are designated as any financial account maintained by a foreign financial institution and to the extent retained for the investment of any shares, securities or any other interest in a foreign corporation and any financial instrument or contract with a non-U.S. issuer or partner. You may be liable to a penalty if you are required to file Form 8938 but do not file it or if you report a tax deduction for any transactions involving unreported foreign financial assets. You can find out more about filing Form 8938 in the Guide to Form 8938.

If you fail to file a tax return and pay your taxes by the due date, you may be liable to a fine. You may also be liable to a fine if you declare a significant tax deficiency, file a false tax return, or fail to provide your TIN. If you provide fraudulent information on your tax return, you may be liable to a civil fine for fraud.

If you fail to file your return by the due date (including extensions), you may be liable to a penalty for not filing. The penalty is based on the amount of tax not paid in advance (except for extensions). The penalty is usually 5% for each month or part of the month if you fail to file your return, but not more than 25%.

If an item on the return could be considered tax avoidance, you will not be entitled to a tax reduction when fully disclosed. However, there is a minor reduction for a significant jurisdictional viewpoint, but only when you reasonably believe that tax treatment may be appropriate.

Whether or not there is substantial jurisdiction over the tax treatment of an item depends on the facts and circumstances. Court rulings, Treasury Department regulations, tax rulings, tax procedures, notices and declarations issued by the IRS and published in the Tax Newsletter relating to the same or similar cases as yours will be considered.

To disclose all relevant information about the tax treatment of an item, use Form 8275, Disclosure Report. You must also have a reasonable basis for treating that item as you did. In the case of a significant tax reduction, only items that meet the requirements of Tax Procedure 2024–44, available at IRS.gov/irb/2024-52_IRB#REV-PROC-2024-44 (or subsequent version) are considered to have been fully disclosed on your tax return. Tax Procedure 2024–44 does not consider the effectiveness of changes in tax law in tax years beginning after December 31, 2024. If a line in this tax procedure is affected by such change and additional returns are required, the taxpayer may be required to file Form 8275 or Form 8275-R, Disclosure Report under Regulations until other regulations or guidance are issued to comply with that regulation. A complete and accurate tax view on the UTP Form (Form 1120), Uncertain Tax View Report for the appropriate year, will be considered as if the corporation had filed Form 8275 or Form 8275-R. However, filing Form 8275 or Form 8275-R will not be considered as if the corporation had filed the UTP Form (Form 1120). Use Form 8275-R to disclose items or views that are not in accordance with the regulations.
For more information on undisclosed foreign financial assets, see section 6662(j) or the Guide to Form 8938.

You will not be liable to pay a penalty if you give a good (reasonable) reason for the way you handled an item. You also have to prove that you acted in good faith. This does not apply to an uneconomic transaction.

You may be liable to a penalty if you file an incorrect tax refund or tax credit claim. The penalty is equal to 20% of the amount not allowed in the claim, unless you can prove that you have a reasonable reason for filing the claim. However, any amount not allowed due to an uneconomic transaction will not be considered as being reasonably justified. The penalty will not be calculated on any part of the amount not allowed in the claim that is subject to a penalty related to accuracy or fraud.

You may be liable to a $5,000 fine if you file a false tax return or other false filing content. A false tax return is a return that does not contain enough information to determine the exact amount of tax you have declared or that contains information that clearly indicates that the amount of tax you have declared is fundamentally inaccurate. For more information about false tax returns and false tax return content and a list of views that have been determined to be false, visit IRS.gov/irb/2010-17_IRB#NOT-2010-33 (or later versions). You will be liable to a fine if you file this type of tax return based on a false position or in an attempt to delay or interfere with the administration of federal tax laws. This includes changing or highlighting the language printed above the blank space provided for your signature. This penalty is added to any other penalties imposed by law.
If there is any tax outstanding on your return due to fraud, a penalty of 75% of the outstanding tax will be added to your tax return.

If you fail to provide the SSN or ITIN or someone else's SSN or ITIN as requested on a tax return, report or other document, you may be fined $50 for each failure. You may also be fined $50 if you fail to provide the SSN or ITIN of someone else as requested on a tax return, report or other document. For example: if you have an interest-bearing bank account, you must provide the SSN or ITIN to the bank. This number must be entered on Form 1099-INT or other statements that the bank sends to you. If you fail to provide the SSN or ITIN to the bank, you will be fined $50. (You may also be subject to income tax deductions). You will not have to pay the fine if you can prove that the failure was due to a reasonable reason and was not intentionally omitted.
If you fail to file your tax return due to fraud, you will be fined 15% for each month or part of the month you file late, up to a maximum of 75%.
If you file your tax return more than 60 days after the due date or the extended due date, the minimum penalty will be the smaller of $510 or 100% of the outstanding tax.

You will be liable to pay a non-payment penalty of ½ of 1% (0.005) of the outstanding tax for each month or part of the month, following the due date of the tax. This penalty does not apply during the automatic 6-month extension of the tax filing period if you have paid at least 90% of your actual tax debt on or before the due date of the tax and paid the amount owed when you file the tax return. The monthly non-payment penalty is half the normal 1/4% penalty (0.0025 instead of ½% (0.005)) if a instalment agreement is in effect in that month. You have to file your tax return before the due date (including extension) to qualify for this penalty. If a notice of intention to impose tax is issued, the penalty will increase to 1% at the beginning of the first month beginning at least 10 days after the date of the notice. If a notice and request for immediate payment is issued, the penalty will increase to 1% at the beginning of the first month beginning after the date of the notice and request. This penalty will not exceed 25% of the outstanding tax. You will not have to pay the penalty if you can prove that you have a reasonable reason for not paying tax on time.

If both the non-filing penalty and the non-payment penalty (discussed in the previous section) apply in any month, the 5% (or 15%) non-filing penalty will be reduced by the non-payment penalty. However, if you file more than 60 days after the due date or the extended due date, the minimum penalty will be less than $510 or 100% of the outstanding tax.

The penalty is 20% of the short payment. The penalty is 40% of any short payment related to an undisclosed non-economic transaction or an undisclosed foreign financial asset transaction. The penalty will not be calculated on any short payment penalized by fraud, discussed in the next section.

The term "negligent" includes not making reasonable efforts to comply with tax law or not taking reasonable care in preparing a tax return. Negligent action also includes not keeping books and records complete. You will not be liable for penalties for negligence if you have a reasonable basis for the position you assume or if you can give a reasonable reason and act in good faith. The term "negligent" includes any careless, imprudent or intentionally negligent conduct.

You can avoid penalties for ignoring rules or regulations if you disclose on your return a view that has at least one reasonable basis. See the Disclosure Report section below. This exception will not apply to an amount that could be considered tax evasion. Furthermore, this exception will not apply if you do not keep complete records and books or reasonably justify the amounts.

You may be criminally prosecuted (put on trial) for acts such as: 1. tax evasion; 2. deliberate failure to file tax returns, provide information or pay any taxes when due; 3. fraud or false declaration; or 4. fraudulent tax preparation and filing.

This chapter discusses how to pay U.S. income tax when you earn or receive income during the year. Generally, federal income tax is an amount that is payable immediately. There are two ways to pay it immediately. 1. Deduction. If you are an employee, your employer can deduct income tax from your salary.
