Taxes can also be deducted from a number of other incomes — including pensions, bonuses, royalties, and gambling winnings. In each case, the amount deducted will be paid to the U.S. Treasury in your name. 2. Estimated tax. If you do not pay taxes through deduction or fail to file enough tax in this way, you may have to pay estimated tax. Private business people usually pay tax in this way. You may have to pay estimated tax if you receive income such as dividends, interest, rent, and royalties. Estimated tax is used to pay income tax, self-employment tax, and minimum substitute tax.

You must inform your employer that you are a resident or a resident alien so that they can deduct the correct amount of tax from your salary. If you are a resident alien under the rules discussed in Chapter 1, you must file a Form W-9 or equivalent report to your employer. If you are a resident alien under those rules, you must provide your employer with a Form 8233 or a Form W-8BEN, confirming that you are a foreigner or a Form W-4, confirming that your salary is subject to cumulative deduction at the same rate as a resident alien or U.S. citizen. If you are a resident alien and receive income other than wages (such as dividends and royalties) from sources in the United States, file a Form W-9 or equivalent report to the deduction agent (usually the income payer) so that they do not deduct income tax at the 30% rate (or lower, as per the treaty). If you receive this type of income as a resident alien, file a Form W-8BEN to the deduction agent so that they deduct income tax at the 30% rate (or lower, as per the treaty). However, if the income is actually related to a trade or business in the United States, file a Form W-8ECI.

The following discussion generally applies only to foreign residents. Taxes are deductible for foreign residents in the same way as for U.S. citizens. Salaries and other remuneration paid to foreign residents for services performed as employees are generally subject to cumulative deduction at the same rate as for foreign residents and U.S. citizens. Therefore, your remuneration, unless excluded from the term "salaries" by law or exempt by treaty, is subject to cumulative deduction.

If you are an employee and receive a cumulatively deductible salary, you will need to complete a Form W-4. At the same time, complete a Form W-4 to receive scholarships or research grants within the scope of the current payment for past, present or future services and you do not claim a treaty deduction on Form 8233 (discussed later in Income Eligible under Tax Treaties). These are services that you perform as an employee and are a condition for receiving scholarships or research grants (or a reduction in tuition fees). Foreign residents must comply with the special guidelines in Notice 1392 when completing a Form W-4 for remuneration paid as an employee performing personal services to dependents in the United States. Remuneration for personal services is made on behalf of others and includes payments such as wages, salaries, fees, bonuses, royalties, scholarships, research grants and similar indications of the amount paid to employees. To see whether you need to increase or decrease the deduction, use the IRS Tax Deduction Estimator. See Scholarship and Research Grant Deductions below for information on how to complete a Form W-4 if you receive scholarships or research grants originating from the United States that are not payments for services.
If you qualify for the benefit under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Income Tax Treaty, you may request an additional deduction to the standard deduction rate.

If you are a home-based employee, your employer is not required to deduct income tax. However, you may voluntarily agree to deduct income tax by filing a W-4 form to your employer. This agreement takes effect when your employer accepts the contract by starting the deduction. You or your employer can terminate the contract by giving written notice to the other party.

If you are an H-2A agricultural worker, your employer is not required to deduct income tax. However, your employer will only deduct income tax if you and your employer agree to deduct it. In that case, you must provide your employer with a completed W-4. You can find more information about non-deductible tax at IRS.gov/ForeignAgriculturalWorkers.

Salaries exempt from U.S. income tax under income tax treaties are usually exempt from retention tax. For information on how to claim a retention tax exemption, see Income entitled under tax treaties in the section below. Salaries paid to foreigners who are residents of American Samoa, Canada, Mexico, Puerto Rico or the U.S. Virgin Islands may be exempt from retention tax. The following paragraphs explain this exemption.
The report can be in any form, but must be dated and signed by the employee and include a statement that the report is made under penalty of falsehood.

If you are an employee who is a temporary foreign resident and a permanent resident of U.S. Samoa or Puerto Rico then wages in services performed in U.S. Samoa or Puerto Rico are generally not deductible, unless you are an employee of the United States or any U.S. agency in the United States in American Samoa or Puerto Rico.

A foreigner who is a temporary resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands is not actually deductible from U.S. tax on income earned while working temporarily in the U.S. This is because the person pays U.S. Virgin Islands income tax. To avoid being subject to withholding tax on income earned in the U.S., U.S. Virgin Islands residents should write to their employers stating that they are not a permanent resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands and that they are not expected to pay U.S. Virgin Islands tax on their entire income.

If you receive a pension payment from the United States, the payment is usually subject to a 30% deduction (or lower by treaty). However, you may be deductible at a cumulative rate on the part of the pension that arises from the performance of services in the United States after 1986. You must complete a Form W-8BEN or Form 8233 and then file it with the deduction agent or payer before the income is paid or credited to you.

The bounty you receive during the year for services performed in the United States is subject to U.S. income tax. It is counted as taxable income. In addition, the bounty you receive while working for an employer, up to $20 per month, is subject to cumulative deduction tax.

If there is no employee-employer relationship between you and the person you provide services to, your salary is subject to a 30% deduction rate (or lower by treaty). However, if you engage in commercial or business activities in the United States during the tax year, your salary for personal services as an independent contractor (independent personal services) may be exempt from all or part of the deduction if you reach an agreement with the IRS on the amount of the mandatory deduction. The agreement you reach with the IRS concerning the retention of your salary for independent personal services is effective for the agreed payment after all parties agree. You must agree to file a due income tax return for the current tax year.

If you are an entertainer or athlete performing or participating in sports events in the United States as a temporary resident foreigner, you may complete a CWA and then file it with the IRS for a deduction of withholding tax, provided that certain requirements are met. In all cases, the deduction agreement will not reduce the deductions to less than the estimated income tax payable. Use Form 13930 to file a CWA for an entertainer or athlete who is a temporary resident foreigner with a total annual income in the United States of at least $10,000. Form 13930 can be faxed to 866–715–1507 or mailed to the following address. Central Withholding Agreement Program Internal Revenue Service 25520 Commercentre Dr. Lake Forest, CA 92630–8884 We have temporarily waived the income requirement for the form used to file a CWA. Form 13930-A is currently unavailable. When the exemption is in effect, individuals with incomes below $10,000 can file a CWA using Form 13930, Guide to Filing a Consolidated Withholding Agreement. For more information on how to file a CWA, see Form 13930. For more information, visit IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Central-Withholding-Agreements.. The CWA application must be received by the IRS at least 45 days before the agreement takes effect to ensure it is completed before the first trip or event begins and must contain all the proofs specified in the guide. If not, you may file a CWA with the IRS.

If the IRS is satisfied with the information, the IRS will determine your anticipated income tax amount for the taxation year on the total actual income associated with your business or commerce in the United States. Business expenses required by law may be calculated if proven in a manner satisfactory to the Commissioner or the Commissioner's representative. The Commissioner or the Commissioner's representative will send you a letter sent directly to the depository agent, stating the final remuneration payment that is exempt from deduction and the amount that may be paid to you as a result of the exemption. You must provide two copies of the letter to the depository agent and also attach a copy of the letter to your income tax return for the taxation year in which the exemption is effective. For more information, see Form 515.

If you are a distributor of a multi-tier marketing company that is subject to a mistaken deduction, file a U.S. income tax return (Form 1040-NR or Form 1120-F) or, if you have filed a tax return, request a tax refund (Form 1040-X or Form 1120-F amended) to recover the amount that was mistakenly deducted. You must also attach to your U.S. income tax return or information supporting the tax refund request the following items, but not limited to them. A copy of your Form W-2, Form 1042-S or Form 1099 to prove the deduction. The report must explain why your income was declared on your Form W-2, Form 1042-S or Form 1099 as not subject to U.S. tax. The report lists all the days you entered and left the United States in the taxable year. If the remuneration is a remuneration for several years, the report must list all the days you entered and left the United States in each taxable year in which the remuneration was allocated. A copy of any documents or records showing the number of days you were in the United States in the years mentioned. The report must provide (a) the number of days (or units of time less than one day if applicable) that the personal services were performed in the United States in connection with the recruitment, training and support of lower-tier distributors; and (b) the total number of days (or units of time less than one day if applicable) that the personal services were performed globally in connection with the recruitment, training and support of lower-tier distributors. Any related documents or records

Social security benefits paid to lawful permanent residents (green card holders) are not subject to a 30% deduction. For the purposes of calculating U.S. income tax, green card holders remain permanent aliens until their legal permanent status under immigration law is revoked or determined to have been administratively or judicially waived. See Green Card Challenge in Chapter 1. If you are a green card holder and a deduction is made for a wrongful deduction of social security benefits because you have an address abroad, the IRS will refund the deduction. To receive a refund, you must file a Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. A signed statement including the following statements must be attached to the tax return: "The SSA should not have withheld income tax from my social security benefits because I am a lawful U.S. permanent resident and my green card has been neither revoked nor administratively or judicially determined to have been abandoned. I am filing a U.S. income tax return for the tax year as a resident alien reporting all of my worldwide income. I have not claimed benefits for the tax year under an income tax treaty as the resident of a country other than the United States. I am filing a U.S. income tax return for the tax year as a resident alien."

Other income subject to a 30% (or lower by treaty) deduction usually includes fixed or identifiable income, such as interest (other than interest on investments), dividends, pensions, annuities and income from sale and barter, discussed in chapter 4.
The special rules on deductions on income in joint ventures, scholarships and research student grants will be explained in a later section.

If you are a foreign partner in a U.S. or foreign limited liability company, that limited liability company will deduct the retained tax on the actual taxable share of the ECTI from the partnership. The partnership may reduce the retained tax on your ECTI share by considering some deductions at the partner level. Generally, you must file Form 8804-C for this purpose. For more information, see the Guide to Form 8804-C. The retained tax rate on the actual share of the ECTI is usually the highest tax rate specified in paragraph 1 (37%). However, the partnership may deduct at the highest rate applicable to a specific type of income that can be allocated to you if you have provided the partnership with the appropriate documentation. Long-term capital interest is an example of a specific type of income that applies the highest rate of tax. The deductible tax request in the form of a tax credit on your Form 1040-NR in 2024. The partnership will provide you with a report on Form 8805 stating the retained tax. The public limited liability company will deduct the actual distributions of the actual share of the ECTI. In this case, the partnership will provide you with a report on Form 1042-S.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in the United States or a foreign partner engaged (or considered to be engaged) in a commercial or business activity in the United States and you transfer that interest directly or indirectly for profit, then for transfer transactions that occur after 2017, the transferee will typically deduct and pay to the IRS on your behalf tax amounts equal to 10% of the amount received from the sale transaction. The deduction and payment rules for this amount are similar to the rules for selling interests in real estate in the United States. You will receive Form 8288-A reflecting the amount of the deduction that you can report on line 25f of Form 1040-NR as a credit for the tax you owe on the profit. You can provide some information to the transferee to reduce or eliminate the deduction. For example: if the non-recognized clause in the Tax Code applies to all the money received from the transfer transaction, the transferee does not need to deduct if you give notice describing the application of the non-recognized clause. If you are a non-recognized transferee under section 1446(f)(4), the joint venture must deduct distributions to you amounts equal to the tax amount that you did not deduct (plus interest, if any). As of November 30, 2020, the Treasury Department and the IRS have issued final regulations in section 1446(f) in T.D. 9926 (85 FR 76910) to transfer both non-PTP and PTP interests. The final regulations require any transferee to deduct circulation tax amounts equal to 10% of the amount received from any transfer of cooperative interest (except for some PTP interests).

There is no deduction for qualifying scholarships received by applicants for a degree program. See Chapter 3. If you are a student or beneficiary of a foreign resident under an "F", "J", "M", or "Q" visa and you receive a grant or scholarship originating in the United States that is not fully tax-exempt, the deduction agent (usually the scholarship payer) deducts at a rate of 14% (or lower as treated) the taxable portion of the grant or scholarship that is not payment for services. However, if you are not an applicant for a degree program and the grant does not meet certain requirements, the tax is deducted at a rate of 30% (or lower as treated). Any portion of the scholarship or scholarship that is payment for services is subject to cumulative deduction tax as discussed earlier in Deductions from Salary.
Includes the costs that will be deducted on your tax return. These costs include the IRA deduction discussed in Deductions in Chapter 5.
You may exclude a portion of the grant or scholarship that is not taxable under U.S. law or a tax treaty.
If you are a qualifying student under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Income Tax Treaty, you may be eligible for a standard deduction.

Complete the appropriate lines in the Form W-4. Sign and date the form and then file this form to the tax agent. If you file the Form W-4 to reduce or eliminate the deductions on scholarships or grants, you must file annual U.S. income tax to qualify for any deductions you declare on that form. If you have been in the U.S. for more than one taxable year, you must attach an annual report with the Form W-4 stating that you have filed a U.S. income tax return for the previous year. If you have not been in the U.S. long enough to be required to file, you must attach a report with the Form W-4 stating that you will file U.S. income tax when requested. After the tax agent accepts the Form W-4, tax will be deducted from your scholarship or grant at the cumulative rate applicable to your salary. Total income is deducted by the amounts applied on the Form W-4 and the deductions are calculated on the remainder. You will receive a Form 1042-S from the tax agent (usually the payer of your grant) stating the total taxable amount of your scholarship or research grant less any deductions, taxes and deductions. Use this form to prepare your annual U.S. income tax return. For more information, see IRS.gov/FormW4.

If a tax treaty between the United States and your country of residence exempts, or reduces, taxation on certain income, you should notify your payer (tax agent) of your foreigner status to claim tax treaty exemption or reduced tax rate. Typically, you do this by filing Form W-8BEN or Form 8233 to your tax agent. File Form W-8BEN for income that is not personal service income. File Form 8233 for personal service income, discussed below. If you qualify for tax treaty exemption but do not send Form 8233 to your tax agent to claim tax exemption, you can still receive the benefit of the exemption by filing Form 1040-NR. Follow the instructions for line 1a of Form 1040-NR... more

If you perform personal services as an employee or independent contractor and you claim a treaty deduction for that personal service income, provide Form 8233 to each deduction agent from whom the amount will be received. Even if you file Form 8233, the deduction agent may still have to deduct tax from your income. This is because the factors that underpin the treaty exemption may not be determined until after the end of the tax year. In this case, you must file Form 1040-NR to recover any excess tax deductions and provide the IRS with proof that you are entitled to the treaty exemption.

Students, teachers, and researchers must attach the appropriate reports shown in Appendix A (for students) or Appendix B (for teachers and researchers) at the end of this publication to Form 8233 and submit it to the deduction agent. For treaties not listed in the Appendix, attach a report in the same format as for other international treaties. If you receive scholarships or research student grants, as well as personal service income, from the same deduction agent, use Form 8233 to request deductions based on the treaty for both types of income.

A full 30% deduction is mandatory for payments to a foreign resident or foreign company for on-the-spot (or television or other) revenues from music festivals, boxing promotions and other entertainment or sports events, unless the deduction agent has been specifically notified otherwise by letter from the IRS. Depending on the calendar year in which the total income earned from the United States, Form 13930 may be used to request a reduction in the deduction. The deduction may still be requested even if the income is tax-exempt under the treaty. One reason for this is that the exemption is usually based on factors that cannot be determined until after the end of the tax year. We have temporarily waived the income requirement for the form used when filing CWA. Form 13930-A is currently unavailable. When the exemption is in effect, individuals with incomes below $10,000 can file CWA using Form 13930, Guide to Filing a Consolidated Deduction Agreement. For more information on how to file CWA, see Form 13930. For more information, visit IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Central-Withholding-Agreements.. You will be required to pay U.S. tax at the time of departure from the United States on any income that you have declared incorrectly as treaty-exempt. For more details on the terms of the treaty that apply to remuneration, see Issue 901..

The certificates in (3) and (4) shall be irrelevant if the buyer or qualified substitute had actual knowledge or was notified by a representative of the seller or buyer (or substitute) that the certificate was false. This shall also apply to the report of the qualified substitute under (4).

The buyer must file and pay the deductible tax within 20 days of the transfer using Form 8288. This form is filed with the IRS along with a copy A and a copy B of Form 8288-A. A copy B of this report will be stamped after the IRS receives it and sends it back to you (the seller) if it is complete and includes TIN. You must file a copy B with the tax return to be credited for the deductible tax. A stamped copy of Form 8288-A will not be provided to you if the TIN is not included on that form. The IRS will send you a letter requesting TIN and instructions on how to obtain TIN. When you provide TIN to the IRS, the IRS will provide you with a stamped copy of Form 8288-A.
Requests for deductible tax returns on Form 1042-S, Form 8288-A or Form 8805 may require additional time to process. Allow up to 6 months for these refunds to be issued.

If you are an employee in the United States, you are required to pay U.S. social security and Medicare taxes in most cases. The tax payment will contribute to your insurance under the U.S. social security system. Social security provides retirement, survivor and disability benefits, as well as health insurance (Medicare) benefits for individuals who meet certain eligibility requirements. In most cases, $168,600 of the first taxable salary in 2024 for services performed in the United States is subject to social security tax. All taxable salary is subject to Medicare tax. The employer deducts these taxes on each payroll. The employer must deduct these taxes even if you do not intend to qualify for social security or Medicare benefits. You can request an over-limit social security tax credit on your income tax return if you have multiple employers and the amount deducted from the combined salary in 2024 is more than $10,435.20. If any employer deducts more than $10,435.20, you cannot claim a tax credit for that amount. Request your employer to refund the over-limit. If the employer does not refund the over-limit, you can claim a tax refund using Form 843. Generally, U.S. social security and Medicare taxes apply to salary payments for services performed as an employee in the United States, regardless of the nationality or place of residence of the employee or employer. In limited cases, these types of taxes apply to wages from services performed outside of the U.S. territory. The employer can tell you whether social security tax is payable.

There are no special rules for temporary residents for purposes of Medicare supplementary taxation. Wages, RRTAs and self-employed income that are subject to Medicare supplementary taxation will also be subject to Medicare supplementary taxation if they exceed the applicable threshold. Employers are responsible for deducting 0.9% (0.009) of Medicare supplementary taxation on Medicare wages or RRTAs paid to you in excess of $200,000 in the year. If you are filing a general tax return and anticipate that your and your spouse's individual wages will not exceed $200,000 but your combined wages and self-employed income will exceed $250,000, you may want to request an additional deduction on Form W-4 and/or make an estimated tax payment. If you file Form 1040-NR, you will be required to pay Medicare supplementary taxation if your total wages and self-employed income exceed $125,000 if you are married (you have checked the Spouse filing separately box at the top of page one of Form 1040-NR) or $200,000 if you are a single person or a qualifying surviving spouse (you have checked the Single or Qualifying surviving spouse box at the top of page 1 of Form 1040-NR).

Generally, services performed by you as a foreigner temporarily residing in the United States under non-resident status in subsections (F), (J), (M) or (Q) of section 101(a)(15), the Immigration and Nationality Act are not covered by the social security program if the service is performed for the purpose for which you were admitted to the United States. This means that you will not be deducted from Social Security or Medicare taxes on the money you receive for the service. These types of services are very limited and usually only include school work, internships and employment in financially difficult situations. Social Security and Medicare taxes will be deducted from your salary under this service if you are considered to be a permanent resident alien discussed in Chapter 1, even if your non-resident classification (“F,” “J,” “M,” or “Q”) remains the same. Services performed by the spouse or minor child of a foreigner temporarily residing on both F-2,” “J-2,” “M-2,” and “Q-3” visas are covered by both social security and non-social security.

If you are a temporary resident alien who is admitted to the United States as a student, you are usually not allowed to work for a salary or engage in business while you are in the United States. In some cases, students who enter the United States on forms “F-1,” “M-1,” or “J-1” are granted work permits. Social Security and Medicare taxes are not deducted from the salary of the work, unless the student is considered a permanent alien. Any student who is enrolled and regularly attends classes at a school may be exempt from Social Security and Medicare taxes on the salary of the services rendered to that school. USCIS allows students to work at a school on form “F-1” if the work does not cause a U.S. resident to be replaced. “Work at school” means work performed at the school. Work at school includes work performed at an off-campus location that is educationally linked to the school. Work at school under the terms of a scholarship, research grant or lecturer’s grant is considered part of a regular student’s study program and is authorized by USCIS. Social Security and Medicare taxes are not deducted from the salary of the work, unless the student is considered a permanent alien. If the service is performed by a student who is a temporary resident alien is not considered to have been performed for the purpose for which the student was admitted to the United States, Social Security and Medicare taxes will be deducted from the salary of the service, unless the salary is exempt under the Tax Code.

An exchange student is temporarily admitted to the United States under section 101(a)(15)(J) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Social security and Medicare taxes are not deducted from the salary of the exchange student who is authorized to work and who owns or has a letter of authorization from the sponsor, unless the exchange student is considered a permanent alien. If the service is performed by the exchange student is considered to have been performed for the purpose for which that student was admitted to the United States, social security and Medicare taxes are deducted from the salary of the service, unless that salary is exempt under the Tax Code. An exchange student who is temporarily admitted to the United States as a participant in international cultural exchange programs under section 101(a)(15)(Q) of the Immigration and Nationality Act may be exempt from social security and Medicare taxes. The employer must be the person who proposed the foreigner to obtain a “visa-free” Q. Social security and Medicare taxes are not deducted from the salary of the work, unless the foreigner is considered a permanent alien.

Send Form 843 (with attachments) to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Ogden, UT 84201-0038. Do not use Form 843 to claim a Medicare Supplemental tax refund. If the Medicare Supplemental tax was mistakenly deducted from your salary, you can claim the Medicare Supplemental tax credit that was mistakenly deducted from the total tax debt on your return by filing Form 8959 with Form 1040, Form 1040-SR or Form 1040-NR. If the Medicare Supplemental tax was mistakenly deducted in the previous year that you filed Form 1040, Form 1040-SR or Form 1040-NR, you must file Form 1040-X in the year before you received your salary or remuneration to recover the mistakenly deducted Medicare Supplemental tax. See Instructions for Form 1040-X..

Agricultural workers temporarily admitted to the United States under an H-2A visa are exempt from social security and Medicare taxes on wages paid for services performed in connection with the H-2A visa. You can find more information on non-tax deductions at IRS.gov/ForeignAgriculturalWorkers.

Self-employment tax is the social security and Medicare tax for self-employed individuals. Temporary foreign residents are not subject to self-employment tax unless an international social security treaty in force determines that they are covered by the U.S. social security system. Residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Guam, CNMI, or American Samoa are considered U.S. residents for this purpose and are subject to self-employment tax. You can find information on international social security treaties in the section below. Permanent foreign residents are subject to self-employment tax according to the same rules as U.S. citizens. However, a permanent foreign resident who works for an international organization, foreign government or wholly-owned foreign government instrument will not be subject to self-employment tax on income earned in the U.S. Self-employment income you receive as a permanent foreign resident is subject to self-employment tax even if the income is paid for services you have provided as a temporary foreign resident.

Use the SE Form (Form 1040) to declare and calculate self-employed tax. Then, fill in the tax in Table 2 (Form 1040), line 4. Attach the SE Form (Form 1040) with the Form 1040, Form 1040-SR or Form 1040-NR.

If you have both wages and self-employed income, the threshold for applying additional Medicare tax on self-employed income will be reduced (but not less than 0) by the total wages subject to additional Medicare tax. You should not consider loss of employment for the purposes of this tax. If you file Form 1040-NR, you must pay additional Medicare tax if your total wages and self-employed income are more than $125,000 if you are married (you have checked the Spouse filing separately box at the top of page one of Form 1040-NR) or $200,000 if you are a single person or a qualifying surviving spouse (you have checked the Single or Qualifying surviving spouse box at the top of page 1 of Form 1040-NR). See Form 8959 and separate instructions to determine whether you have to pay additional Medicare tax. For more information on additional Medicare tax, visit IRS.gov/ADMTfaqs.

If you are paying self-employment tax, you can deduct a portion of the self-employment tax you have paid to calculate your adjusted total income. This deduction is calculated on the SE form (Form 1040).

The United States has signed social security treaties, often called "totalization agreements," with foreign countries to coordinate social security insurance and taxation for workers employed for part or all of their employment in one of these countries. Under these agreements, double insurance and double contributions (taxation) for the same job will be eliminated. These agreements usually ensure that social security taxes (including self-employment taxes) are paid to only one country. For a list of international social security agreements, visit SSA.gov/international/status.html. When agreements with other countries come into effect, these agreements will be posted on this website. For more information on international social security agreements, visit SSA.gov/international/totalization_agreements.html.

Under this agreement, you are usually only subject to social security tax in the country where you are working. However, if you are temporarily posted to work for the same employer in the United States and your salary is subject to social security tax in both countries, most agreements stipulate that you are only insured under the social security system of the country from which you were posted to work. To confirm that your salary is subject only to foreign social security tax and is exempt from U.S. social security tax (including Medicare tax) under the agreement, you or your employer should request an insurance certificate from the competent foreign authority. This will usually be the same authority that you or your employer pay foreign social security tax to. The foreign authority can provide you with the necessary information they need to issue the certificate. The employer should keep a copy of the certificate as the certificate may be required to explain why you are exempt from U.S. social security tax. Only wages paid on or after the date of the agreement are exempt from U.S. social security tax.

Under most agreements, self-employed individuals are insured under the social security system of the country where they reside. However, under some agreements, you may be exempt from U.S. self-employment tax if you temporarily transfer your business to or from the U.S. If you believe that your self-employment income is only subject to U.S. self-employment tax and is exempt from foreign social security tax, request an Insurance Certificate from the SSA See the reference in the Note above. This certificate will help you to be exempt from foreign social security tax. To prove that your income from your private business is only subject to foreign social security tax and is exempt from U.S. self-employment tax, request an Insurance Certificate from the appropriate foreign agency.

Item (2) does not apply if you have not filed a tax return for 2024. Students who are temporary residents should use Form 1040-ES (NR) to calculate and pay their private business tax. If you have filed your 2024 tax return on Form 1040-NR and anticipate that your income and total deductions in 2025 will be almost equal, you should use your 2024 tax return as a guide to completing the Estimated Tax Estimate Table in the Form 1040-ES (NR) Guide. You do not have to make payments due on January 15, 2026 if you file Form 1040-NR 2025 before February 2, 2026 and pay the full amount due by return.

If your tax return is not annual, the due date will be the 15th of the 4th, 6th and 9th month of the fiscal year and the first month of the following fiscal year. If any of the days falls on a Saturday, Sunday or a public holiday, use the next day that is not a Saturday, Sunday or a public holiday.

Even if you do not pay the estimated tax in April or June, your circumstances may change so that you will have to pay the estimated tax later. This may happen if you receive additional income or if any of your deductions are reduced or removed. In that case, see the instructions for Form 1040-ES (NR) and Form 505 for information on estimating taxes.

If after paying the estimated tax, you find that your estimated tax increases or decreases significantly due to changes in income or exemptions, you should adjust the remaining estimated tax. To do this, see the Instructions for Form 1040-ES (NR) and Form 505.
You will be penalized for not paying the lower estimated tax contribution, except in certain cases. These are explained in Form 2210.

The Federal Disaster Relief Act of 2023 extends the special rules and taxation process for losses from personal injury caused by a number of major federal disasters declared from February 26, 2021 to February 10, 2025. For more information, see Qualifying Disaster Relief Payments, in the following section.

The special rules and tax filing procedures have been extended to claim eligible damages related to losses from personal injury. The Taxpayer's Safety and Disaster Relief Act 2019 and the Taxpayer's Safety and Disaster Relief Act 2020 have extended the special rules and tax filing procedures for losses from personal injury caused by certain severe federal disasters declared in 2018, 2019 and 2020. Eligible damages can be claimed on Form 4684. See Qualifying Disaster Losses, in the section below, for more information. If applicable, you may have to file an amended Form 1040-X to claim these rights on your 2018, 2019 and/or 2020 returns. Form 1040-X is available at IRS.gov/Form1040X. Previous amendments to Form 4684 are available at IRS.gov/Form4684. See How to Report Damages on Form 1040-X, in the section below. Limits on losses from personal injury and theft. For the 2018 to 2025 tax years, if you are an individual, losses from damage or theft of property used for personal purposes not related to trade or business or transactions made for profit are only deductible if the loss was caused by a federally declared disaster. Losses from theft arising from transactions made for profit are still deductible.

This publication explains how property damage, theft and deposit losses are treated tax-wise. Damage occurs when your property is damaged by a natural disaster such as a storm, fire, car accident or similar events. Theft occurs when someone steals your property. Deposit losses occur when your financial institution goes bankrupt or goes out of business. This publication discusses the following topics. Definition of property damage, theft and deposit losses. How to calculate your profits or losses. How to treat insurance and other compensation you receive. Deduction limits. When and how to report property damage or theft. Special rules for losses in disaster areas.
For information on assets that are subject to seizure, see Involuntary Conversion in Chapter 1 of Issue 544, Selling and Other Disposal of Assets.
