Losses from losses are deducted in the tax year in which the loss is sustained. This is usually the tax year in which the loss occurred. However, losses from losses may be sustained for one year after the loss occurred. See Time of Profit and Loss and Table 3, in the following section.

All three types of damage refer to federally declared disasters, but the requirements for each type of damage are different. A federally declared disaster is a disaster determined by the President of the United States to secure federal government assistance under the Stafford Act. A federally declared disaster includes either (a) a declaration of major disaster, or (b) an emergency declaration under the Stafford Act.
Losses from federal damages are losses from damages or thefts to personal property that were not caused by a federally declared disaster.

Disaster losses are damages caused by a federally declared disaster and occurring in an eligible area as declared by the President. Disaster losses must occur in a county eligible for assistance by community or individual (or both). Disaster losses are not limited to property for personal use and can be declared for personal business or income-generating property and by corporations, S-corps and partnerships. If you suffer a disaster loss, you are eligible to claim a deduction for the loss and to opt to claim damages in the previous tax year. See Disaster losses, in the section below.

Eligible disaster losses include losses from damage to or theft of personal property caused by: A major disaster declared by the President under Section 401 of the Stafford Act in 2016; Hurricane Harvey; Tropical Storm Harvey; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; California wildfires in 2017 and January 2018; and A major disaster declared by the President in the period from January 1, 2020 to February 10, 2025.

For tax years from 2018 to 2025, if you are an individual, losses from damage to personal property are only deductible if the damage was caused by a federally declared disaster (loss from federally declared disaster). Personal property is not business property or income-generating property. If the event that caused you to suffer personal damage from a disaster (not caused by a federally declared disaster) occurred before January 1, 2018, but the loss from that damage was not sustained until January 1, 2018 or later, then the loss from that damage is not deductible. See Time of reporting profits and losses, in the section below, for more information on when losses from damage are sustained.

Losses due to damage are not deductible even if the damage does not exceed your personal profits from the loss if the damage or destruction was caused by the following: Accidental breaking of objects such as glass or porcelain under normal circumstances. A pet in the household (explained below). A fire if you intentionally caused it or paid someone else to cause it. A car accident if you were intentionally negligent or caused the accident. This is also true if the intentional action or negligence of someone else on your behalf caused the accident. Deterioration over time (explained below). However, see the Special Procedure for Damage from Corrosion of Plasterboard, in the next section.
Damage to property caused by pets in the household is not deductible as a loss due to injury unless the requirements previously discussed in the Damage clause are met.

Damage to property due to deterioration over time is not deductible as a loss due to damage. This is because the damage is caused by the regular operation or process, rather than by a sudden event. Examples of damage due to deterioration over time are: The regular deterioration of a building due to normal weather and wind conditions. The deterioration and damage of a hot water heater due to an accidental hot water heater explosion. Most property damage is caused by drought. To be deductible, drought-related damage must have occurred in a trade or business or in a transaction carried out for profit.

Because the personal damages requested under this special procedure are not caused by a federally declared disaster, they are only deductible to the extent that the damages do not exceed the personal profits resulting from the damages. If your property was damaged by imported plasterboard installed in your home between 2001 and 2009, under this special procedure, you treat the amount paid for the repairs as a loss due to damages in the year in which the payment was made. For example: the amount you paid for the repairs in 2024 is deductible on the 2024 tax return and the amount paid for the repairs in 2023 is deductible on the 2023 tax return.

If you choose not to follow this special procedure, you must comply with all the conditions applicable to the deduction of loss for damage, as well as complete lines 1 to 9 of the Instructions for Form 4684. For example, this means that you must indicate that the property was damaged, destroyed or lost by an identifiable event as defined above in Damage. Furthermore, you must have proof of the following: The damage is reasonably deducted in the tax year you have reported and not deducted in any other year. See Time of Profit and Loss Reporting, in the next section. The amount of damage is reported. See Evidence of Loss, in the next section. No refund is requested for any part of the loss that is reasonably expected to be recovered. See Time of Profit and Loss Reporting, in the next section.

If you choose to follow this special procedure, complete Form 4684, Part A, as instructed below. The IRS will not make it difficult for you to treat damage from plasterboard corrosion as a loss by damage if you identify and declare the damage as explained below.
Enter the amount of insurance or other compensation you have received (including through litigation). If not, enter -0-.

Enter the amount you paid to repair damage to your house and household items caused by corroded plasterboard. Enter only the amount you paid to restore your house to the state it was in immediately before the damage. Do not enter any amount you paid for improvements or additions that increased the value of your house above the value before the damage. If you replace a household item instead of repairing it, choose to enter the lower of: The current cost of replacing the original item, or The original price (for tax purposes) of the original item (usually its cost).

If line 8 is smaller than or equal to line 3, you cannot claim a deduction for loss by this special procedure. If there is a refund request pending (or an intention to pursue a refund), you may have an additional deduction in the subsequent tax year depending on the actual refund received. See Refunds Received After Deduction of Loss, in the next section.
How you declare profits and losses depends on whether the assets are business assets, income-generating assets or personal use assets.

Individuals report losses from income-generating assets on Form A (Form 1040). Profits from business assets and income-generating assets are combined with losses from business assets and net profits and losses are reported on Form 4797. If you are not required to file Form 4797, please enter only the net profits or net losses on the tax return on the line specified in Form 4797 (for individuals filing Form 1040 or 1040-SR, this line will be line 4 of Form 1 (Form 1040)). In addition to that line, enter “Form 4684.”

If your losses from business assets and property generating income exceed the profits from these assets, please calculate the losses from the combined business assets with the total profits from the business assets and the income generating property. Report the net profits or losses as a regular profit or loss on Form 4797. If you are not required to file Form 4797, please enter only the net profits or losses on your tax return on the line specified in Form 4797 (for individuals filing Form 1040, this line will be line 4 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040)).

If the damaged or stolen asset is a depreciable asset held for more than one year, you may have to consider all or part of the profit as normal income within the scope of the permitted or permissible depreciation. Please calculate the normal income portion of the profit in Part III of Form 4797. See Depreciation Recapture in Chapter 3 of Issue 544 for more information on the recalculation rules.

If you suffer a loss from damage or theft, you must deduct any insurance or other reimbursement received as well as any damages deducted from your original value in the property. The result is your adjusted original value in the property. If you make one of the adjustments to the original described above, the amount you spend on repairs to restore the property to the state it was in before the damage occurred will increase your adjusted original value. Please do not increase your original value in the property by any qualifying disaster relief payments (discussed earlier in Loss in Disaster Areas). See Adjusted Basis in Issue 551 for more information on adjustments to the original value.

If your loss or theft deduction makes your deductions more than your income in the same year, you may incur a net loss from business (NOL). Normally, you can use the NOL to reduce your tax in the following year. You do not have to do business to have a NOL from loss or theft. For more information, see the instructions for Form 172.

The obtaining of money or property through fraud or misrepresentation is an act of theft if this act is illegal under state or local law, or if the act is illegal under the law of the state or local government.

For the tax years 2018 to 2025, if you are an individual, losses from damage and theft of property used for personal purposes are only deductible if the damage is attributed to a federally declared disaster (الخسارة من كارثة على مستوى الاتحاد). أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ أ

You cannot deduct as a theft loss the decrease in the market value of shares purchased on the open market for investment if the decrease was due to fraudulent disclosure of accounting information or other unlawful misconduct of officers or directors of the company that issued the shares. However, you can deduct it as a loss in investment in Schedule D (Form 1040) if the shares are sold or exchanged or become entirely worthless. For more information on selling shares, worthless shares and loss in investment, see Chapter 4 of Form 550.

The mere disappearance of money or property is not theft. However, an accidental loss or disappearance of property may be considered a loss if it is the result of an event that can be identified as sudden, unexpected or unusual. Sudden, unexpected and unusual events have been defined earlier in the section Damage.

If you qualify for the 2009-20 Tax Code, as amended by the 2011-58 Tax Code, and choose to follow the procedures in the guide, first complete Part C of the 4684 Tax Code to determine the amount to be entered in lines 28, Part B. Skip lines 19 to 27, but you must complete lines 29 to 39 of the 2009-20 Tax Code, if applicable.
You can no longer claim any of the confusingly listed deductions, including deductions for losses from ordinary deposits in bankrupt or insolvency financial institutions.

You can choose to deduct deposit losses as losses from loss for any year that you can reasonably estimate the amount of deposits lost in a bankrupt or insolvent financial institution. The choice is usually made on the tax return you file for that year and applies to all of your deposit losses in that year at that particular financial institution. If you treat the loss as a loss from loss, you cannot treat that same loss as a non-business debt when it actually becomes worthless. However, you can deduct non-business debt for any loss that exceeds the estimated amount you have deducted as a normal loss or loss from loss. Once you have made the choice, you cannot change it without the permission of the IRS.

If you are an individual, losses from damage to property used for personal purposes are only deductible if the damage was caused by a federally declared disaster. An exception to the rule limiting the deduction of personal damage from disaster and theft to the extent of federally declared damages applies when you have personal profits arising from the damage. Because losses from deposits are not caused by a federally declared disaster, you can deduct losses from deposits as personal damage from disaster only to the extent that they do not exceed your personal profits arising from the loss.

If you do not choose to report that loss as a loss due to loss for the purpose of offsetting profits, you must wait until the year in which the actual loss is determined and offset that loss as a non-business debt in that year.

If you recover the amount that was deducted as a loss in a previous year, you may have to include the recovered amount in your income for the year of recovery. If any part of the initial deduction did not reduce your tax in the previous year, you do not have to include that part of the recovery in your income. For more information, see Recoveries in Issue 525.
To deduct a loss due to damage or theft, you must be able to prove that you have suffered the accident or theft. You must also be able to prove the amount you deduct.

For loss due to damage, you must be able to prove all of the following: That you are the owner of the property, or if you rent the property from someone else, you are liable under the contract with the owner for the damage. The type of damage (car accident, fire, storm, etc.) and when it occurred. The damage is a direct result of the damage. Whether there is a claim that can be reasonably expected to be recoverable.
To determine the deduction for a loss due to damage or theft, you must first calculate your loss.

If you receive insurance or other forms of reimbursement, you must deduct the amounts reimbursed when calculating your loss. You will not have a loss due to damage or theft against the amounts reimbursed to you. If there is a claim for reimbursement with a reasonable prospect of recovery in the year of the loss, the loss will not be maintained until you are sure whether you will receive that reimbursement. If you expect to receive a refund of part or all of the loss, you must deduct the expected refund when calculating your loss. You must deduct your loss even if you do not receive the payment until the following tax year. See Refunds received after deduction of damage, in the next section.

If your property is insured, you should file an insurance claim in time to be reimbursed for your loss. If you do not file an insurance claim, you cannot deduct the entire amount of the loss that is not covered by your insurance contract. The part of the loss that is not normally insured (i.e., a deductible) will not be subject to this rule.

If you receive money from your employer's emergency fund and have to use that money to repair or replace property that is claimed for damages, you must take that amount into account when calculating the damages deduction. Only enter in the consideration field the amount you used to replace your destroyed or damaged property.

If you receive an excluded cash gift and you are a victim of a disaster and there is no limit on how the money can be used, please do not deduct this excluded cash gift from your loss. This applies even if you use the money to pay for the repair of property damaged by the disaster.

Please do not deduct from your loss any insurance payments you receive to cover your living expenses in one of the following cases. You are no longer allowed to use your main home because of a damage. A government agency does not allow you to enter your main home because of a damage or threat of damage.
Normal living expenses include similar expenses that you would have to pay but cannot realize because of a loss or threat of a loss.

You include the taxable portion of the insurance payment in the income of the year you re-use your main home or of the year you receive the taxable portion of the insurance payment, whichever is later.

Do not deduct from your loss from damage the repayment of the loan used to repair or replace the property you are requesting to deduct from the loss from damage. If you have a cancelled (repaid) federal loan, see Cancelled federal loans, in the section below, in Loss from disaster.

If you have calculated the loss from damage or theft using the estimated refund, you may need to make adjustments. If you have paid for damage to your home with a deteriorated concrete base and requested deductions on your initial federal income tax return or have adjusted and the payments have been made to you (or on your behalf to contractors) by the Connecticut Foundation Solutions Indemnity Company (CFSIC), you must include some or all of the payments in your total income. See Notice 2020-5, 2020-19 I.R.B. 796 (available at IRS.gov/irb/2020-19IRB#ANN-2020-5).

If you subsequently receive less than the expected refund, please count that difference as a loss along with other losses (if any) on the return in that year where you can reasonably expect that there is no further refund.

If you subsequently receive a refund that is larger than expected, after having requested a loss deduction, you may have to include the additional refund in your income for the year that you received that refund. However, if any part of the initial deduction did not reduce your tax for the previous year, please do not include the part of the refund in your income. Please do not recalculate your tax for the year that the deduction was requested. See Recoveries in Issue 525 for the additional refund to be included in your income.
If you subsequently receive the refund exactly as expected, you do not have to include any refund in your income and you cannot deduct any additional losses.

If your repayment is greater than the original adjusted price of that asset, you will make a profit. This is true even if the FMV decrease of the asset is smaller than your original adjusted price. If you make a profit, you may have to pay tax on that amount, or you may have to defer reporting that profit. See Calculation of Profit, in the next section.

There are two ways you can offset losses from damage or theft of inventory, including the items you keep for sale to customers. One way is to offset the loss through an increase in the value of the inventory by accurately declaring the initial and final inventory. Do not report this loss as an accidental or theft loss again. If you suffer a loss from an increase in the value of the inventory, include any insurance or other refund you receive for the loss in total income (not excluding costs and taxes). The other way is to offset the loss separately. If you offset separately, exclude the affected inventory items from the value of the inventory by making a deduction for the initial inventory or purchases. Minimize the loss by the refund you receive. Exclude the refund from total income. If you do not receive a refund at the end of the year, you may not report the loss in the event that you have a reasonable expectation of recovery.

If you are liable for damages due to damage to leased property, then your damages are the amount paid to repair the property less any insurance or compensation you have received or expected to receive.

Normally, if a single accident or theft involves more than one item of property, you will have to calculate the damage for each item separately. Then, combine the damages to determine the total loss from that damage or theft.

FMV is the price at which you could sell your asset to a willing buyer when both parties are not obliged to sell or buy and both know all the relevant data. The FMV deduction used to calculate the amount of loss due to damage or theft is the difference between the FMV of the asset immediately before and immediately after the damage or theft occurs.
The FMV of the asset immediately after it is stolen is considered to be 0 because you no longer have the asset.

A recovered stolen property is property that was stolen and then returned to you. If you recover the property after the loss from theft has been deducted, you must adjust your loss by using the lesser of the adjusted original value of the property (explained in the next section) or the FMV reduction from the time immediately before the property was stolen to the time the property was recovered. Use this amount to recalculate your total loss for the year in which the loss was deducted. If the loss is recalculated less than the loss you have deducted, you usually have to report the difference as income in the year of recovery. But only report the difference that does not exceed the amount of the loss that reduces your tax. For more information on the amount to be declared, see Recoveries in Issue 525.

To calculate the FMV decrease due to accident or theft, you usually need to resort to professional valuation. However, other measures can also be used to set certain decreases. See Valuation, Costs of Cleaning or Repair, and Special Procedures — Safe Harbor Method for Determining Losses Due to Damage and Theft below.

You can use the valuation you used to receive federal loans (or guarantee federal loans) for the consequences of a federally declared disaster to determine the amount of your disaster losses. For more information about disasters, see Losses in disaster areas, in the section below.

The cost of repairing a damaged property is not part of the loss from damage. This is also the case for the cost of cleaning after a disaster. However, you can use the cost of cleaning or repairing after damage as a measure of the reduction in FMV if all of the following conditions are met. The repair has actually been done. The repair is necessary to bring the property back to the state it was before the damage occurred. The amount spent on the repair is not excessive. The repair only focuses on the damage. Because of the repair, the value of the property after the repair is not greater than the value of the property before the damage occurred.

The cost of restoring the landscape to its original state after damage may indicate the amount of loss you have incurred. You can measure your loss by the amount of money you have spent on the following: Removal of trees and shrubs that have been destroyed or damaged, minus any remaining value you may have received. Pruning and other measures to preserve damaged trees and shrubs. Replanting is required to restore the property to its approximate value before the damage occurred.

To calculate the amount of damage and theft, you usually have to determine the actual deduction of the FMV of the lost or damaged property by using a professional valuation or the cost of repairs that you actually performed. But the special safe harbor methods in Taxation Procedures 2018-08, 2018-2 I.R.B. 286 and Taxation Procedures 2018-09, 2018-2 I.R.B. 290 allow you to determine the deduction of the FMV in other ways. If you are an individual, the loss from damage to personal property due to damage is deductible only if you have personal profits arising from the damage. In this case, you may deduct personal losses due to disasters not related to the federally declared disaster to the extent that they do not exceed your personal profits arising from the damage.

The 2018-08 I.R.B. Procedure, 2018-2 I.R.B. 286, available at IRS.gov/irb/2018-02_IRB#RP-2018-08, provides safe harbor methods that you can use to calculate the amount of damage and theft losses to your residential property used for personal purposes as well as your personal belongings. If you meet the standards and use the safe harbor method described in the 2018-08 I.R.B. Procedure, the IRS will not put you in difficulty. The use of the safe harbor method described in the 2018-08 I.R.B. Procedure is optional.

The Safe Harbor Replacement Cost Method for Federally Declared Disasters allows you to determine the FMV of your personal belongings immediately before a federally declared disaster occurs in order to determine the amount of money lost due to damage or theft. To use the Safe Harbor Replacement Cost Method, you must first determine the current cost of replacing your personal belongings with a new property and then deduct this amount by 10% for each year of ownership of that personal belonging. See the Table of Personal Belongings in the Taxation Procedure 2018-08.

Damage determined through the safe harbor method must deduct the value of any repairs provided by a third party free of charge (e.g., work done by volunteers or through a donation) to you. In addition, your damages must deduct the amount of any insurance, reimbursement or other compensation received.

Attach a statement to Form 4684 that you have used the 2018-08 Tax Procedure to determine the amount of your loss. Include the specific safe harbor method used. When completing Form 4684, please do not enter the amount on line 5 or line 6 for each asset. Instead, enter the relevant FMV reduction determined by the safe harbor method on line 7. For damages by Harvey, Irma, and Maria, see the 2018-09 Tax Procedure, 2018-2 I.R.B. 290, available at IRS.gov/irb/2018-02IRB#RP-2018-09, for the cost indexes of the safe harbor method.

Residential property for personal use is usually real property, including improvements, owned by the individual who suffers the damage and has at least one home. Residential property is not considered to include a home if any part of the home is used as a rental property or includes a home office used in a trade or business or a transaction carried out for profit. For more details, see the Tax Service Procedure 2018-08.

The safe harbor repair estimate allows you to determine the FMV of your residential property for personal use by using less than two separately licensed repair estimates. The estimates must state the costs broken down to restore your property to the state immediately prior to the damage. The safe harbor repair estimate is limited to losses from damages of up to $20,000.

The minimal safe harbor method allows you to determine the FMV of your residential property for personal use based on a fair written estimate of the repair costs necessary to restore your property to its condition immediately prior to the occurrence of the damage. You must keep documentation showing how you estimated your damage. The minimal safe harbor method is available only for losses from damages of $5,000 and upwards.

The insurance safe harbor approach allows you to determine the FMV reduction of residential property used for personal purposes based on the estimated damage in the declarations prepared by the homeowner or flood insurance company. These declarations must give the estimated damage that you would have to bear as a result of the property being damaged or destroyed.

If the damage occurred in a disaster zone and was caused by a federally declared disaster, you can use the Contractor Safe Harbor method or the Disaster Loan Valuation Method. Under the Contractor Safe Harbor method, you can use the contract price for the repairs specified in the contract prepared by a licensed independent contractor to determine the FMV reduction of your residential property for personal use. This safe harbor method does not apply unless you are required to adhere to a binding contract signed by you and the contractor, which lists the expenses to restore your residential property for personal use to the state immediately prior to the damage.

Under the safe harbor approach to disaster loan valuation, you can prepare a pre-valuation, try to determine your estimated damages from a federally declared disaster, obtain a loan from the federal fund or guarantee a loan from the federal government to determine the FMV reduction of residential real estate used for personal purposes.

Personal property generally includes items of personal property actually owned by an individual that are lost due to damage or theft if they are not used in trade or business. Personal property does not include an item that can maintain or increase its value over time or some other type of asset. For more details, see Tax Service Procedure 2018-08. The safe harbor approach for personal property is the minimal approach and the safe harbor approach of replacement cost for federally declared disasters.

The cost of protecting your property against damage or theft is not counted as part of the loss due to damage or theft. The amount you spend on insurance or building a floodproof house is not counted as part of the loss. If the property is a business property, these costs are deducted as business expenses. If you make permanent improvements to your property to protect it from damage or theft, please add the cost of these improvements to the original value of the property. An example is the cost of a flood dam.

You cannot add to the original cost of the property or deduct as a business expense for any expenditure made in connection with eligible disaster mitigation payments (discussed later in the section Losses in the disaster area).

Additional costs arising from damage or theft, such as costs for treatment of personal injury, temporary accommodation or car rental, are not counted as part of your loss from damage or theft. However, they may be deducted as business expenses if the damaged or stolen property is business property.
The cost of replacing stolen or destroyed property is not counted as a part of the loss due to damage or theft.

Please do not consider the moral value when determining your damage. If a family portrait, heirloom or souvenir is damaged, destroyed or stolen, you must base your loss on the FMV of that item, this loss being limited by the adjusted original value of the property.

Depreciation of property because it is located in or near a disaster zone or where disasters may recur is not taken into consideration. You have a loss only due to actual damage to your property. However, if your home is located in a federally declared disaster zone, see Loss in a disaster zone, in the section below.

Pictures taken after damage occurred will be useful in determining the condition and value of the property after damage. Pictures showing the condition of the property after repair, restoration or replacement may also be useful. Valuation is used to determine the FMV reduction due to damage or theft. See Valuation in the previous section, in Calculating FMV reduction — Items to consider for valuation information. The costs for taking photos and valuation are used as evidence of the value and condition of the property damaged by damage are not counted as part of the loss. They are only used to determine your tax liability. For tax years 2018 through 2025, they can no longer be deducted as other listed deductions.

The means of your investment in the property you own is the original price of that property. For property purchased, the original price is usually the cost of it to the buyer. For property acquired in another way, such as by inheritance, received as a gift or received in a tax-free form of exchange, you must calculate the original price in a different way, as explained in Section 551.

If you inherit property from a person who died in 2010 and the executor of the deceased's estate has made an option under section 1022 using Form 8939, Distribution of the Increase in the Original Value of Property Acquired from the Deceased, the special rules relating to the original value will apply.

During the ownership of an asset, many events can occur that change your original value. Some events will increase the original value, such as permanent additions or improvements to that asset. Other events will decrease the original value, such as losses from previous damages and discounts off depreciation. After adding the increases and subtracting the decreases from the original value, the result is that you have the adjusted base value. See Issue 551 for more information on calculating the original value of an asset.

After you have calculated the amount of your loss from damage or theft, you must calculate how much of that loss can be deducted. The deduction of loss from damage and theft for property used for personal purposes is limited. For tax years from 2018 to 2025, personal losses from damage and theft caused by federally declared disasters are only deductible to the extent that they were caused by a federally declared disaster. Personal losses from damage and theft caused by federally declared disasters must comply with the $100 per loss rule as well as the 10% rule and will be discussed in the next section. The $100 and 10% rules are also summarized in Table 2. An exception to the above rule is the limitation of the deduction of personal losses from damage and theft to the extent of federally declared disaster losses that applies if you have personal profits from the loss in that tax year. In this case, you can deduct from your personal profits from the loss any loss from damage not caused by a federally declared disaster. Any excess profits are used to reduce the loss from a federally declared disaster. The 10% rule applies to any remaining federal disaster losses. Damage to business property and income-generating property does not comply with these rules. However, if the loss from damage or theft is related to a home you have used for business or rental, your deductible loss may be limited. See the instructions for the Model.

After you have determined your loss from damage or theft to property used for personal purposes, as discussed above, you must deduct that amount of damage by $100. This deduction applies to each total loss from damage or theft, including those non-disaster damages declared by the federal government that are applied to reduce your personal profits arising from your loss. It does not matter how many assets are involved in an event. Only a single $100 deduction is applied.

Typically, events that are closely related in origin will cause a single damage. A single damage is when the damage is caused by two or more causes that are closely related, such as wind damage and flood damage caused by the same storm. A single damage can also cause damage to two or more properties, such as a hurricane that damages both a house and a car parked on your way.
If you have more than one loss due to damage or theft in your tax year, you must deduct $100 in each loss.
If two or more individuals (not the co-declarants) suffer damage from the same loss or theft, the $100 rule will apply individually.

If you and the co-owner are filing a separate tax return, each of you must deduct $100 from your loss. This is true even if you own the property together. If a co-owner owns the property, only the co-owner can claim deductions for the loss on a separate tax return. Neither of you can claim deductions for the entire loss on a separate tax return. Each of you must deduct $100 from the loss.

If two or more individuals (not joint taxpayer) suffer damage to property that is jointly owned, the $100 rule will apply individually to each of them. For example: If two sisters live together in a house that they jointly own and suffer damage to the house, the $100 rule will apply individually to each of them.

You must deduct from your total federal damages an amount equal to 10% of your AGI. Apply this rule after you deduct $100 for each damage. For more information, see the Guide to Form 4684. If you have both profits and losses from damages or theft, please see Profits and losses, later in this section.

If you have more than one loss from damage or theft in your tax year, please deduct $100 plus any reimbursements from each loss. Then, you must deduct from the total loss from federal damage an amount equal to 10% of your total adjusted income.

If you and your co-worker file jointly, you are both treated as one individual when applying the 10% rule. Whether you own joint or separate property is not important. If you file separately, the 10% rule will apply to each return on which the loss is reported.
If two or more individuals (not the co-declarants) suffer damages to property that is jointly owned, the 10% rule will apply individually.

If you have gains from damage or theft of personal property, you must compare the total gains with your total losses. Please do this after you have deducted $100 and any reimbursements for each loss, but not before you have deducted 10% of your AGI from your federal losses. The gains from damage or theft do not include the gains you choose to defer. See Deferring Gains, in the next section.

If your loss exceeds the determined profit, please take the loss minus the profit and subtract 10% of the AGI into that result. The remainder, if any, is the loss deducted from personal use property. If your loss is not due to a federally declared disaster, please see Line 14 in the Guide to Form 4684. Losses not due to a federally declared disaster can only be used to offset profits. If you suffered a loss due to a qualifying disaster, see Line 15 in the Guide to Form 4684 for more information.

If your determined profit is greater than your loss, take the profit minus the loss. The difference is considered interest and must be declared in Schedule D (Form 1040). The 10% rule does not apply to your profit. If your loss is not a federally declared disaster, please see Line 14 in the Guide to Form 4684.
Usually, you have to calculate the damage for each item that is stolen, damaged or destroyed. However, a special rule applies to real estate used for personal purposes that you own.
To calculate damages for real estate used for personal purposes that you own, all improvements (such as buildings, landscaping and land with improvements) are considered.

Personal property is any property that is not real estate. If personal property is stolen, damaged or destroyed by an accident, you must calculate your loss separately for each item of property. Then, combine these separate losses to calculate the total loss. Subtract $100 plus 10% of AGI from the total loss to calculate the loss deduction.

When a loss involves both real estate and personal property, you have to calculate the loss separately for each type of property. However, you only need to apply a $100 deduction for the entire loss. Then you apply the 10% rule to calculate the deduction for the loss.

When property is used partly for personal purposes and partly for business or income-generating purposes, the deduction for loss from damage or theft must be calculated separately for the personal use and the business or income-generating use. You must calculate each loss separately because the losses for these two uses are calculated in two different ways. When calculating each loss, allocate the total cost or original value, FMV before and after loss from damage or theft, as well as insurance or other reimbursements between business and personal use. The $100 rule and the 10% rule apply only to losses from damage or theft for the part of property used for personal purposes.
Even if the FMV decrease of your asset is less than the original adjusted price of the asset, use your original adjusted price to calculate your profit.

The amount you receive includes any money plus the value of any property you receive less any costs incurred to repay it. This amount also includes any repayment used to pay off a home loan or a property lien to collateralize other debt for property that has been damaged, destroyed or stolen.

If you make profits from the destruction of your main home, you can usually exempt the profits from income tax, considering that you have sold or traded in your home. You can be exempt up to $250,000 of profits (up to $500,000 if you are married, joint tax return). To be exempt from profits, you must normally have owned and lived in the property as your main home for at least two years in the five years prior to the date of its destruction. For information on this exemption, see Form 523. If you make more profits than the exempt amount but purchase a replacement property, you can defer the surplus profits. See Deferred Profits, later.

Normally, you must declare your income as income in the year you receive the refund. However, you do not have to declare your profits if you meet certain requirements and choose to defer profit declaration according to the rules explained in Deferring profits in the next section. For information on how to declare profits, please see Declaring profits and losses, in the next section. If you have profits from damage or theft of personal property that you choose to defer (as explained in the next section) and also have a loss from another damage or theft of personal property, please do not consider the deferred profits when calculating your loss or theft deduction. See the 10% rule in Deduction limits, above.

Do not declare profits if you receive a refund in the form of similar or related property to the service or the use of the property that was destroyed or stolen. Your original value in the new property is usually the same as your adjusted original value in the property it replaces. Typically, you must declare profits on the stolen or destroyed property if you are reimbursed or if you have a non-similar property. However, you can choose to defer profits if you purchase a similar or related property to the service or the use of the property that was stolen or destroyed for a specific replacement period discussed in the section below. You can also choose to defer profits if you acquire a controlling right (at least 80%) in a limited liability company that owns the similar or related property to the service or use of that property. See Controlling rights in a limited liability company, in the section below. If you make profits from damaged property, you can defer profits if you allocate the refund to the restoration of the property. To defer all profits, the cost of the replacement property must be at least equal to the refund you received. If the cost of the replacement property is less than the refund, you must add the profits to your income provided that they do not exceed the unused refund.

For the losses and thefts described in (3) above, the profits cannot be offset by any loss when determining whether the total profits exceed $100,000. If the assets are owned by a partnership, the $100,000 limit will apply to that partnership and to each of its members. If the assets are owned by a S-company, the $100,000 limit will apply to that S-company and to each of its shareholders.

If a person dies after having gained, but has not purchased a replacement property, then the profits shall be declared for the year in which the deceased gained profits. The executor or the inheritor of the money resulting from the loss or theft shall not delay the declaration of the profits by buying a replacement property.

You must purchase replacement property for the specific purpose of replacing property that has been destroyed or stolen. Property that you have acquired as a gift or inheritance is not eligible for this. You do not need to use the same amount of money that you received as a refund for your old property to purchase the replacement property. If you spend the money received from your insurance company for other purposes and borrow money to purchase the replacement property, you can still defer profit reporting if you meet the remaining requirements.

If there is a profit from the refund received from the destruction of the main house that exceeds the amount that can be excluded from your income (see Destruction of the main house in Profit calculation, previous section), you can defer the declaration of any surplus profit by purchasing a replacement property that is identical or related in service or use. If you want to defer any surplus profit, the replacement property must be at least equal in value to the amount you received from the destruction of the property minus the excluded profit. Furthermore, if you defer the declaration of any part of your profit under these rules, you are deemed to have owned and used the replacement property as your main house for the period of time you owned and used the demolished property as your main house.
You must deduct the deferred profit from the original price of your replacement asset (the cost of it). In this way, tax on the profit will be deferred until you remove the replacement asset.

Special rules apply to replacement property in relation to the damage or destruction of your main home (or furniture in the house) if this property is located in a federally declared disaster zone. For more information, see Profits from home in disaster zone, in the section below.

If you are an owner-investor, "similar or related in service or use" means that any substitute property must have the same service or use relationship to you as the property it replaces. You determine this by determining all of the following. Whether the property provides the same service to you. The nature of the business risks associated with the property. What the property requires of you in the way you manage, service and relate to your tenants.

If your business property or income-generating property that was destroyed is located in a federally declared disaster area, then any tangible replacement property that you acquire for use in any business activity is considered to be equivalent or related in service or use to the destroyed property. The replacement property does not necessarily have to be located in a federally declared disaster area. For more information, see Losses in Disaster Areas, in the following section.

You can replace the assets by acquiring control in a joint stock company that owns the same or similar assets in terms of service or use as your damaged, destroyed or stolen assets. You can defer the declaration of all your profits if the number of shares that bring control is worth at least the amount received (repayment) for your assets. You have control if the owner of the shares has at least 80% of the combined voting rights of all types of voting shares as well as at least 80% of the total number of shares of all other types of shares.

If two or more assets belong to the same category, please allocate the discount to each asset in proportion to the adjusted original price of all assets in that category. The original discounted price of any individual asset must not be less than 0.

To defer profit declaration, you must purchase replacement assets for a certain period of time. This is called the replacement period. The replacement period is calculated from the date your assets were damaged, destroyed or stolen. The replacement period usually ends two years after the end of the first tax year in which you earned any profits from the assets.

For a main home (or furniture in the home) located in a federally declared disaster zone, the replacement period usually ends four years after the end of the first tax year in which you earned any profits. See Losses in Disaster Zones, later.

Your request must contain all the details describing why you need to renew. This includes: 1. Name, address and tax ID of the taxpayer, 2. A detailed description of the assets being converted, 3. Date of the assets being converted, 4. The original adjusted price of the assets being converted, 5. Date and amount of the payments received, 6. A copy of the declaration of the involuntary assets conversion with the profit rate and the associated profit deferral, and 7. A description of the actions taken to replace the assets.

You defer the declaration of profits from loss or theft by declaring your option on the tax return for the year in which the profits are made. You have profits in the year in which you receive insurance payments or other reimbursements that result in the profits. If a partnership or joint-stock company owns property that is stolen or destroyed, only that partnership or joint-stock company can choose to defer the declaration of profits.

You should attach a report to your tax return in the year you made the profit. This report should include the following: the date and details of the loss or theft; insurance or other compensation you received from the loss or theft; how the profit was calculated.

If you acquire a replacement asset before filing your tax return for the year in which you made a profit, your report should also include details of all of the following: Replacement assets. Deferred profits. The original price is adjusted to reflect the deferred profits. Any profits that you are reporting as income.

If you intend to purchase a replacement property after filing your tax return for the profitable year, your return must also state that you are choosing to replace the property during the mandatory replacement period. Then you should attach a separate return to your tax return for the year in which the replacement property is acquired. This return must contain details of the replacement property. If you acquire part of the replacement property in one year and part in another year, you must file a return for each year. This return must contain details of the replacement property acquired in that year.

Once you have obtained the eligible replacement property that you designated as the replacement property in a return attached to your tax return, you cannot subsequently replace it with another eligible replacement property. This is true even if you obtain another property during the replacement period. However, if the original replacement property is found not to be a qualifying replacement property, you can (within the replacement period) replace it with a new qualifying replacement property.

You are required to file an adjusted return (using Form 1040-X for individuals) for the tax year in which you made the profits in one of the following cases. You did not acquire the replacement property during the extended mandatory replacement period. On this adjusted return, you must declare the profits and pay any additional taxes due. You acquired the replacement property during the extended mandatory replacement period, but at a cost lower than the amount you received for the damage or theft. On this adjusted return, you must declare the non-deferred profits and pay any additional taxes due.

The period for tax assessment on any profits ends after 3 years from the date you notify the director of the IRS office in your area of any of the following. You have replaced the property. You do not intend to replace the property. You have not replaced the property during the replacement period.

If you receive an insurance or other refund that is greater than the original adjusted value for a property that has been destroyed or stolen, you will receive a profit from that loss or theft. You must add this profit to your income in the year you receive the refund, unless you choose to defer the profit declaration, as explained above.

Normally, you can deduct losses from damage that cannot be recovered only in the tax year in which the damage occurred. This is true even if you did not repair or replace the damaged property until one year later. (However, please see Loss in Disaster Areas in the next section for an exception.) You can deduct losses from theft that cannot be recovered only in the year in which you discovered that your property was stolen. If there is a claim for refund with a reasonable prospect of recovery in the year in which the damage occurred, the loss will not be maintained until you are relatively certain that you will receive the refund. If you are unsure whether a part of your loss from damage or theft can be recovered, please do not deduct that part until the tax year in which you have reasonable certainty that that part will not be recovered. Your loss will be maintained in the following tax year.

If you lease a property from another person, you may deduct a damage for that property in the year in which your debt due for the damage is determined. This is true even if the damage has occurred or the debt due has been paid in another year. You do not have the right to deduct until your debt due under the lease can be determined with reasonable accuracy. Your debt due can be determined when the claim for recovery is settled, ruled or rejected.

This section discusses the special rules applicable to damages in federally declared disaster areas. This section contains information on when damages can be deducted, how to file for damages, how to deal with homes in disaster areas, and the tax filing deadlines that can be deferred. This section also lists the telephone numbers of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). (see Contacting the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA)"), in the following section.) Disaster losses are damages that occur in an area designated by the President of the United States to secure federal government assistance under the Stafford Act and that are caused by a federally declared disaster. Disaster areas include areas that secure community or individual assistance (or both). A federally declared disaster includes a major disaster or a declaration of emergency. A list of areas that secure community or individual assistance (or both) under the Stafford Act is available at FEMA.gov/Disaster.

If you are reporting loss due to damage or theft caused by a federally declared disaster, please check the box and enter the DR or EM declaration number assigned by FEMA in the space provided on line 1 of Form 4684. A list of federally declared disasters as well as the FEMA disaster declaration number is available at FEMA.gov/Disaster. The FEMA disaster declaration number consists of the letters "DR" and 4 digits, or the letters "EM" and 4 digits. For example, enter "DR-4832" in the respective spaces for Tropical Storm Helene.

Your home will only be considered unsafe if both of the following factors are present: Your home becomes significantly more dangerous after a disaster than it was before the disaster. The danger comes from the significantly increased risk of future destruction by a disaster.

At the time of choosing to deduct your loss in the previous year, unless there is a qualifying loss from a natural disaster that has been discussed in the previous section, you must calculate the loss according to the usual rules for loss from a natural disaster, as if it had occurred in the year before the disaster occurred.

You should adjust your deductions on Form 1040-X. The instructions for Form 1040-X show how to do this. Explain your adjustments and attach Form 4684 to show how you calculate your loss. See Calculating Loss in the previous section. If the property is damaged or destroyed and you have not listed any deductions on your original tax return, you must first determine whether the loss deduction at this time would be more beneficial for you if you listed the amounts. It would be more beneficial to list the amounts if the sum of the deductions for damage and any other deductions listed is greater than your standard deduction. If you list the deductions, please attach Form A (Form 1040) or Form A (Form 1040-NR) to your adjusted return. Fill out Form 1040-X to recalculate your tax to find the amount of the refund.

You should keep records of your loss deduction. You do not need to attach them to your adjusted return. If the records are destroyed or lost, you may need to rebuild them. Information on rebuilding records is available at IRS.gov/Newsroom/Reconstructing-Records-After-a-Natural-Disaster-or-Casualty-Loss or see Issue 3067, IRS Disaster Assistance-Federal Disaster Areas.

Preparing a Form 1040-X will be easier if you have a copy of your previous year's tax return. If your tax return has been filled out by a tax professional, then he or she will be able to provide you with a copy of that tax return. If not, you can obtain a copy by filing Form 4506 with the IRS. There is a fee for each tax return requested. However, if your home, main office of a business establishment or tax file is located in a federally declared disaster area, this fee will be waived. Write the specific disaster name in the top margin of Form 4506 (for example, "Tennessee Tropical Storm Helene").

If your inventory loss qualifies as a loss due to loss and is attributed to a federally declared disaster in an area designated by FEMA to support the public or individuals (or both), you can choose to deduct the loss on your return or amended return for the immediately preceding year. However, reduce your opening inventory range for the year of loss so that the loss will not be re-declared in the inventory for that year.
If part of your federal disaster loan is cancelled under the Stafford Act, this loan will be considered as a refund for damages. The cancellation reduces the discount for your loss.

Please do not add the Stafford Act disaster relief benefits to your income if the benefit is given to help you meet your essential or urgent medical, dental, housing, personal property, transportation or funeral expenses. No losses due to injury or medical expenses are deducted in the event that they are reimbursed separately from these disaster relief benefits. If the losses due to injury are reimbursed separately from the benefit and you receive the benefit after the loss deduction is made, please see the Refunds received after loss deduction in the previous section. Unemployment benefits under the Stafford Act are taxable unemployment benefits.

Subsidies that a business receives under a state program for the purpose of reimbursing businesses for losses arising from property damage or destruction by a natural disaster are not excluded from income under the exclusion clause for ordinary social assistance payments, such as gifts, such as qualifying disaster relief payments (explained in the next section), or capital contributions. However, a business may choose to defer reporting the money earned from the subsidy if it purchases qualifying replacement property for a certain period of time. See Deferred profits, in the previous section, for the rules that apply.

Eligible disaster relief payments also include payments to individuals affected by a disaster from the federal, state, or local governments related to the federally declared disaster. These payments must be drawn from government funds, based on the needs of the individual or household, and are not payments for services. Payments to businesses often do not meet the standard.
You cannot deduct or record, or increase the basis in your assets, relating to any expenses that you have been compensated for by qualifying forest fire relief payments.

Qualifying disaster relief payments made under the Stafford Act or the National Flood Insurance Act (effective on April 15, 2005) are not included in income. These are payments that you, as the owner of the property, receive to reduce the risk of future damage to the property. You cannot increase the original value of the property, or deduct or underwrite the expenses associated with those payments.

In general, if you sell or transfer an asset, you must identify any gains or losses for tax purposes. (You cannot deduct losses on personally used assets unless the loss is caused by a damage, as discussed in the previous section.) However, if you sell or transfer an asset to a federal, state or local government or a tribal government under a risk mitigation program, you may choose to defer the deferral of the gains if you purchase a qualifying replacement asset for a certain period of time. See Deferred Gains, in the previous section, for the rules that apply.

The IRS may defer tax filing for up to one year for taxpayers affected by a federally declared disaster. The tax filing periods that the IRS may defer include those for filing income tax, surplus tax and employment tax; paying income tax, surplus tax and employment tax; and contributing to a traditional IRA or Roth IRA. If any tax filing period is deferred, the IRS will announce the tax deferral in your area and publish a notice and, if necessary, will publish this in tax laws, tax collection procedures, notices, notices or other guidance in the IRS Bulletin. Visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief to find out whether tax filing is deferred for your area.

If the IRS defers the tax return, the following taxpayers are eligible to be deferred. Any individual whose principal home is located in the disaster area is covered in the declaration (defined in the following section). Any business organization or private single-owner enterprise with its principal business location in the disaster area is covered. Any individual who is a relief worker associated with the government or recognized charity and is carrying out relief activities in the disaster area is covered. Any individual, business organization or individual enterprise that needs to have records to meet the deferred tax return period, provided that those records are maintained in the disaster area are covered. The principal home or principal business location of a business establishment does not necessarily have to be located in the disaster area is covered. Any estate or trust that needs to have tax records to meet the deferred tax return period, provided that those records are maintained in the disaster area are covered. A taxpayer who is a co-declarer who is eligible for deferral. Any individual, business organization or individual enterprise that is not in the disaster area is covered, but needs to have records to meet the deferred tax return period, provided that those records are located in the disaster area are covered. Any individual who visits the disaster area is covered and is killed or injured as a result of the disaster. Any other person identified by the IRS as affected by the federally declared disaster.
This is an area that has been declared a federal disaster, where the IRS has decided to defer tax filings for up to one year.

Certain taxpayers affected by a federally declared disaster that occurred after December 20, 2019, may qualify for a mandatory 60-day deferral for certain tax due dates, such as filing or paying income, consumption, and employment taxes; and contributing to a traditional IRA or Roth IRA. The period of time beginning on the earliest day of the event specified in the disaster declaration and ending on the 60th day after the earliest day of the event or the declaration, whichever is later, is the period of time for which the deferral is granted. For more information on disaster relief in your area, including deferral, visit the IRS's National Roundtable.
The IRS may deduct interest and penalties on income tax outstanding for the period of the deferred tax deadline.

You can get information from FEMA by visiting DisasterAssistance.gov, or by calling the following telephone numbers. Call 711 and provide the TRS number 800–621–3362 if you are deaf, hard of hearing or have a speech disability.

The disaster year is the tax year in which you have suffered damages caused by a federally declared disaster. Normally, disaster losses are retained for the year in which the disaster occurred. However, disaster losses can also be retained for up to one year after the disaster occurred. For example: If there is a claim for reimbursement with a reasonable prospect of recovery, then no part of the damages that can be reimbursed is retained until there is a basis for being certain that you have been reimbursed or not.

Normally, you must deduct losses from losses caused by a disaster declared by the federal government to have occurred in an area that provides community or individual support (or both), you can choose to deduct those losses on your tax return or adjusted tax return for the tax year immediately preceding the disaster. If you make this choice, the amount of losses caused by disasters in the previous year is considered to have occurred in the previous year.

If you have filed a tax return for the previous year, you can choose to report disaster losses on your income for that year by filing an adjusted return. For individuals, please file an adjusted return using Form 1040-X. (See How to Report Damages on Form 1040-X, in the next section.) To make this option, please complete Part I of Section D on Form 4684 in 2023 and attach it to your 2023 tax return or adjusted return to claim disaster losses. You must make the disaster loss deduction option for the previous year no later than 6 months from the normal deadline for filing the original (non-extendable) tax return for the disaster year. For calendar taxpayers, the deadline for making a disaster loss deduction option for 2024 on your 2023 tax return is October 15, 2025. See the Year Guide for Form 4684 for more detailed information on how to report these losses on your original or adjusted 2023 tax return. If you have already filed disaster losses on your tax return for the disaster year and want to deduct losses for the previous year, you must file an amended return to remove the losses that were already deducted on or before the tax return or adjusted return for the previous year, this return already includes the disaster loss deduction. Claiming disaster losses on the previous year's tax return may result in a lower tax amount for that year, which usually creates or increases the tax refund by money.

Complete Part II of Section D on Form 4684 in 2023 if you wish to cancel the option of the 2024 disaster year to offset the disaster losses declared federally in the previous tax year. Attach the completed Part D to the adjusted return for the previous year (i.e., the tax return for the year amended to cancel the option of the 2024 disaster year). The adjusted return for the purpose of cancelling your option must be filed no later than 90 days from the deadline for making the option and on or before the date you file any tax return or adjusted return for the year of the disaster loss. Your adjusted return (cancelling the option of declaring disaster losses prior to the 2024 disaster year) will require a recalculation of the tax liability due to the cancelled option. You must pay or arrange to pay any taxes and dividends due as a result of the cancelled option.

Eligible disaster losses include personal damage from disaster or theft to personal property caused by: A major disaster declared by the President under section 401 of the Stafford Act in 2016; Hurricane Harvey; Tropical Storm Harvey; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; California wildfires in 2017 and January 2018; and A major disaster declared by the President under section 401 of the Stafford Act that occurred in 2018 and before December 21, 2019 and continued until February 10, 2025 (except for those disasters caused by California wildfires in January 2018 that received prior exemption).

The substitute minimum tax adjustment for the standard tax deduction cannot be applied retroactively to net losses caused by qualifying disasters. See Taxpayers Must File Additional Form 6251 in 2024, Substitute Minimum Tax for Individuals, in the Guide to Form 4684 for more information.

If your home is located in a federally declared disaster zone, you may defer your income tax return if you spend compensation money to repair or replace your home. Special rules apply to replacement property related to damage or destruction of your main home (or contents thereof) if located in these areas. For more information, see Profits from home in disaster zone, previously.

If your home is in a federally declared disaster area, the state or local government may order you to demolish or move the house because it is no longer safe to live in due to the consequences of the disaster. If this happens, treat the loss of value as a loss from disaster damage. The state or local government must order you to demolish or move the house within 120 days after the area is declared a disaster area. Your loss is calculated in the same way as for losses from damage to personal use property. (See Calculation of damage in the previous section.) To determine the reduction in FMV, use the value of the house before you moved or demolished it as its FMV after the damage occurred.

The EIC is a tax credit for a certain number of people who work and earn less than $66,819. A tax credit usually means more money in your pocket. It reduces the amount of tax you owe. The EIC can also bring you a tax refund.
To request an EIC, you must meet certain rules. These rules are summarized in Table 1.

Your total adjusted income (AGI) must be less than: $59,899 ($66,819 for a jointly filing spouse) if you have three or more eligible children with a valid SSN, $55,768 ($62,688 for a jointly filing spouse) if you have two eligible children with a valid SSN, $49,084 ($56,004 for a jointly filing spouse) if you have one eligible child with a valid SSN, or $18,591 ($25,511 for a jointly filing spouse) if you do not have a qualifying child with a valid SSN.

Your AGI is the amount on line 11 of the 1040 or 1040-SR. If your AGI is equal to or greater than the applicable limits listed above, you cannot claim an EIC. You do not need to read the rest of this publication.

If you are married, but qualify as a householder or spouse filing separately under the special rules for married taxpayers not living together (see Rule 3), and live in a state with a common-property law, your AGI includes the portion of both your and your spouse's wages that you must include in your total income. This is different from the common-property rules that apply under Rule 7.

To claim an EIC, you (and your spouse if filing jointly) must have a valid SSN issued by the Social Security Administration (SSA) no later than the 2024 tax filing deadline (including extensions). Your eligible child must have a valid SSN on or before the 2024 tax filing deadline (including extensions) so that you can claim a higher EIC based on that child. If you have at least one child who meets the requirements to become eligible for purposes of claiming an EIC, but that child does not have a valid SSN on or before the 2024 tax filing deadline (including extensions), you may apply for an EIC for yourself if you qualify. You may qualify to claim a single EIC if you qualify. For information on how to complete an EIC form if your child is eligible, see the EIC form. A valid SSN for an EIC is one that was issued after your 2024 tax filing deadline (including extensions) or it was issued only to claim or receive federally funded benefits and not to be allowed to work. An example of a federally funded benefit is Medicaid. If you, your spouse, or your child have a Social Security card with “Not valid for employment” printed on it and your immigration status has changed to individual, your spouse, or your child is now a U.S. citizen or resident, apply to the SSA for a Social Security card without an explanation.

If your Social Security card says "Valid for work only with INS authorization" or "Valid for work only with DHS authorization," you have a valid SSN, but only as long as that authorization is still in effect.

If your or your spouse's SSN is missing on the tax return or is inaccurate, you may not receive the EIC. If your or your spouse's SSN is missing on the tax return because you or your spouse did not have a valid SSN on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including the extension period) and you subsequently receive a valid SSN, you cannot file an amended return to claim the EIC. However, if you or your spouse were issued an invalid SSN for the EIC, but on the 2024 tax return due date (including the extension period), you or your spouse were eligible for a Social Security card without "Not valid for employment" printed on it, you may claim the EIC on the original return or the amended version of the 2024 tax return even if the Social Security card was not updated by the 2024 tax return due date (including extensions).
You cannot receive an EIC if instead of an SSN, you (or your spouse if filing jointly) have an ITIN. An ITIN is issued by the IRS to non-citizens who cannot have an SSN.

If you do not have a valid SSN on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including extensions), enter “No” on the dotted line next to line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR). You cannot claim an EIC on the original or adjusted 2024 tax return.

If you (or your spouse if you are filing jointly) do not have an SSN, you can file an SSN by filling out Form SS-5 with the SSA. You can obtain the SS-5 online at SSA.gov/forms/ss—5.pdf, from your local SSA office, or by calling the SSA at 1-800-772-1213.

If your tax return is due and you do not have an SSN, you can request an automatic 6-month extension to file your tax return. You can be extended by filing Form 4868, Request for Automatic Extension of Time to File U.S. Personal Income Tax Returns. For more information, see the instructions for Form 4868. Instead of filing Form 4868, you can request an automatic extension by making an electronic payment on or before the due date.
If you are married, you usually have to file a joint tax return to claim an EIC.

If you meet the above requirements, check the box at the top of the EIC Table (Form 1040). Make sure that you complete and attach the EIC Table to your application to list your eligible child. Complete and attach the EIC Table whether or not your eligible child has a valid SSN. If your child meets the requirements to become your eligible child for the purpose of claiming an EIC without a valid SSN, you may still qualify for an EIC for yourself.

If you are a nonresident alien at any time during the year, you cannot claim an EIC unless your tax status is a spouse filing jointly. You can only use that tax status if your spouse is a U.S. citizen or a permanent alien and you choose to be treated as a U.S. resident. If you make this choice, you and your spouse are taxed on income worldwide. If you need more information about this choice, get Form 519. If you are a nonresident alien at any time during the year and your tax status is not a spouse filing jointly, enter “No” on the dotted line next to line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR). See Nonresident aliens and dual-status aliens in the Form 1040 guide for more information, including information on making the choice to treat your spouse as a nonresident alien or dual-status alien for the entire tax year.

You cannot claim an EIC if you file Form 2555, Foreign Earned Income. You file this form to exclude foreign earned income from your total income, or to deduct or exclude the amount for foreign residence. U.S. territories are not foreign countries. See Form 54 for more information.

You cannot claim an EIC unless your investment income is $11,600 or less. If your investment income is more than $11,600, you cannot claim this tax credit. Use Table 1 in this chapter to calculate your investment income.

This tax credit is called the "earned income" tax credit because, to qualify, you must work and earn income. If you are married and file jointly, you meet this rule if at least one spouse works and earns income. If you are an employee, earned income includes all taxable income you receive from your employer. Rule 15 provides information to help you calculate your earned income. If you are self-employed or a statutory employee, you will calculate your earned income on the EIC Sheet B in the instructions for the Form 1040.

Earned income includes all the following types of income. 1. Salary, wages, bonuses and taxable amounts paid to employees. Salary paid to employees is only earned income if it is taxable. Non-taxable salary paid to employees, such as certain dependent care benefits and adoptive rights, is not earned income. But there is an exception to non-taxable wages that you can choose to include in earned income, as explained later in this chapter. 2. Net income from self-employment. 3. Total income received when you are a statutory employee.
The wages, salaries and bonuses you receive for your work are declared to you on Form W-2, in box 1. You should declare this number on line 1a of Form 1040 or 1040-SR.

Other earned income not reported on Form W-2, in box 1, includes wages of home workers, cash income not reported to your employer, certain Medicaid-exempt payments if you choose to include payments not taxable in earned income for the purpose of claiming an EIC, taxable dependent care benefits, employer-provided adoptive rights from Form 8839, wages from Form 8919 and other earned income.

You can choose to include your tax-free combat salary for the purpose of receiving EIC. The amount of your tax-free combat salary must be shown on your Form W-2, in box 12, with code Q. The choice to include tax-free combat salary in your earned income can increase or decrease your EIC. For details, see Tax-free combat salary in chapter 4.
You may have net income from self-employment if: You own your own business, or You are a pastor or member of a monastery.

The value of the rent or housing allowance provided to a pastor as part of a pastor's salary is generally not subject to income tax but is included in net income from self-employment. For that reason, it is included in the earned income to claim the EIC (except in the cases described in Form 4361 or Form 4029 approved in the following section).
You are a statutory employee if you receive a Form W-2 on which the box “Statutory employee” (box 13) is checked. You declare your income and expenses as a statutory employee on Form C (Form 1040).

Benefits paid to you in the form of strike or shutdown rights, including both cash and the fair market value of other property (not true gifts), are usually taxable. If strike and shutdown rights are taxable, then these benefits are usually earned income. You should report your taxable strike and shutdown rights on Form 1040 or 1040-SR, line 1h.

Each form is approved with an exemption of certain income not subject to social security tax. Each form is discussed here as to what is earned income and what is not earned income for the purpose of claiming an EIC.

Whether you have an approved Form 4361 or not, the amount you receive for performing pastoral duties as an employee is considered as earned income. This includes wages, salaries, bonuses and other taxable employee remuneration. If you have an approved Form 4361, tax-free rent allowance or tax-free rental value of a home will not be considered as earned income. In addition, the amount you receive for performing pastoral duties, but not as an employee, is not considered as earned income. Examples include fees for weddings and honorariums for speeches.

Whether you have an approved Form 4029 or not, all wages, salaries, bonuses and other taxable employee compensation are considered earned income.
