However, the amount you receive as a self-employed individual is not considered earned income. In addition, when calculating earned income, do not deduct the losses on Schedule C or F that have been reported on lines 1a to 1h of Form 1040 or 1040-SR.

If you retire due to disability, the taxable benefits you receive under your employer's disability pension scheme are the income you earn until you reach the minimum retirement age. The minimum retirement age is generally the earliest age at which you can receive a pension or annuity if you are not injured. You must declare your taxable disability payments on line 1h of Form 1040 or 1040-SR until you reach the minimum retirement age. Starting from the day after you reach the minimum retirement age, the payments you receive will be taxed as a pension and not as earned income. Declare your taxable disability pension payments on Form 1040 or 1040-SR, lines 5a and 5b.

The payments you receive from a disability insurance policy that you have paid to purchase are not earned income. It does not matter whether you have reached the minimum retirement age. If this policy is made through your employer, the amount may be shown in box 12 of your W-2 with the code J.

Examples of non-earned income include dividends and dividends, pensions and annuities, social security and railway pension benefits (including injury benefits), divorce and child benefits, social security benefits, compensation benefits for workers, unemployment benefits (insurance), non-taxable maintenance care payments, and veterans' benefits, including rehabilitation payments from the Department of Veterans Affairs. Do not include any of these in your earned income.
The money you receive for the services you performed while being a prisoner in the penitentiary is not already earned income when calculating the EIC.

Tax-free employment incentive payments are not earned income for claiming an EIC. These are cash payments that some people receive from a state or local agency that administers federally funded public assistance programs under the TANF in exchange for certain work activities such as (1) work experience activities (including renovating or repairing public housing) if there are not enough jobs in the private sector, or (2) community service program activities.

If you are married, but eligible to file as a head of household or spouse under the special rules for married taxpayers not living together (see Rule 3), and live in a state with common property laws, your earned income for claiming the EIC does not include any amounts your spouse earns that are considered to belong to you under those laws. That amount is not earned income for claiming the EIC, although you must include it in your total income on your income tax return. Your earned income includes the entire amount you earn, even if part of it is considered to belong to your spouse under the common property laws of your state.

If you are a registered partner in Nevada, Washington or California, the same rules apply. Your earned income for claiming the EIC does not include any amount your partner earns. Your earned income includes all of your earnings. For more information, see Form 555.

If you are receiving Social Security pension benefits or Social Security benefits for the disabled at the time you receive any CRP payment, then your CRP payment is not earned income for claiming an EIC.

Tax-free cash for members of the Armed Forces is not considered as earned income for the purposes of claiming the EIC. Examples of tax-free military salaries are combat salary, Basic Housing Allowance (BAH) and Basic Subsistence Allowance (BAS). See Issue 3 for more information. Combat salary. You can also choose to include your tax-free combat salary in your earned income for the purposes of claiming the EIC. See Tax-free combat salary in chapter 4.

If you have met all the rules in Chapter 1, use this chapter to see if you have a qualifying child. This chapter discusses Rules 8 to 10. You must meet all three of these rules, in addition to the rules in Chapters 1 and 4, to qualify for an EIC with an eligible child. Follow these rules if you have a child who meets the conditions to become your qualifying child for purposes of claiming an EIC, even if the child qualifies for you to claim an EIC without a valid SSN being issued on or before the due date of your 2024 tax return (including renewals). When you file Form 1040 or 1040-SR, you must attach an EIC form to your return if you have at least one child who meets the requirements to become your qualifying child for purposes of claiming an EIC even if the child does not have a valid SSN on or before the due date of your tax return (including renewals). For more information on how to complete an EIC form if your child does not have a valid SSN, see the EIC form. If you meet all the rules in Chapter 1 and this chapter, read Chapter 4 to find out what to do next.

If you do not meet Rule 8, you do not have a qualifying child. Read Chapter 3 to find out if you can receive an EIC without a qualifying child. If your child meets the requirements to be a qualifying child, but also meets the requirements to be someone else's qualifying child, only one of you can consider the child as a qualifying child to claim an EIC. If the other person can declare the child under the reconciliation rules, you cannot claim an EIC as a taxpayer with a qualifying child unless you have another qualifying child. However, you can claim an EIC without a qualifying child.

The school may be a primary school, junior high school or high school, college, university or technical, commercial or mechanical school. However, on-the-job training classes, integrated schools and schools that only offer online courses do not count as schools for the purposes of applying for the EIC.
Students work in intermittent periods with semesters (co-op jobs) in private industry as part of the school's regular coursework and the internships are considered as full-time students.

Significant earning activity means the performance of significant tasks for a reasonable period of time while working for pay or profit, or in a job that is usually performed for pay or profit. Full-time work (or part-time work performed at the convenience of the employer) in a competitive job context at the minimum wage level indicates that the child is able to engage in significantly earning activities. Significant earning activities are not work to care for yourself or your home. It is not unpaid hobby work, institutional therapy or psycho-training, schooling, clubs, social programs and similar activities. However, doing this kind of work may indicate that the child is able to engage in significantly earning activities. The fact that the child is not working for a period of time does not in itself prove that the child is unable to engage in significantly earning activities. For examples of significantly earning activities, see the Guide to Form R (Form 1040).

Your child must have lived with you in the United States for more than half of 2024. You cannot claim an EIC for a child who has not lived with you for more than half of the year, even if you have paid most of the child's living expenses. The IRS may require you to provide documentation showing that you have lived with a qualifying child. Documentation you may want to keep for this purpose includes school and child care records and other records showing your child's address. The following sections explain the residency status test for many.

Your home can be any location where you regularly live. You do not need a traditional home. For example, if your child has lived with you for more than six months in one or more homeless shelters, your child will meet the residency status test.
Soldiers serving outside the United States during extended service are considered to have lived in the United States during that period of service for the purposes of the EIC.

Extended duty means that you are called or ordered to serve for an indefinite period or for more than 90 days. When you begin to perform extended duty, you are still considered to have completed extended duty even if you have not served more than 90 days.
A child born or dying in 2024 is considered to have lived with you for more than half of 2024 if your home has been the child's home for more than half of the time it is alive in 2024.

If you adopt a child in 2024, and that child has been legally adopted by you in 2024, or that child is a qualifying temporary foster child to be raised with you in 2024, that child is deemed to have lived with you for more than half of 2024 if your main home was the main home of that child for more than half of the time the child was adopted or lived with you in 2024.
If your eligible child has been abducted and meets these requirements, enter "KC," instead of a number, on line 6 of the EIC sheet.
To achieve this challenge, the child must not file a single tax return in the year.
An exception to the common tax return standard applies if your child and his/her spouse file a joint return only to claim a refund of deducted income tax or estimated tax paid.
If you have more than one eligible child and only one of them has a valid SSN, you can only claim that child for the higher amount of EIC. For more information on SSN, see Rule 2).

The other person cannot receive any of these benefits based on this qualifying child. In other words, you and the other person cannot agree to divide the resources from this taxation between you. The other person cannot receive any of these resources from this taxation unless that person has another qualifying child. The conciliation rules (applied to solve the deadlock when the normal measures fail), in the following section, explain who can claim the EIC when several people have the same qualifying child. However, the conciliation rules do not apply if the other person is your spouse and you are filing jointly.

If your eligible child is considered, under the reconciliation rules, as someone else's eligible child for 2024, you can receive EIC by using the rules in Chapter 3 for taxpayers without eligible children. Under these reconciliation rules, you and the other person can choose which of you declares the child as an eligible child. See examples 1 to 12. If you cannot claim EIC because your eligible child is considered, under the reconciliation rules, as someone else's eligible child for 2024, you can receive EIC by using another eligible child or by using the rules in Chapter 3 for those who have no eligible children.

If you and another person have the same eligible child but the other person cannot claim the EIC because he/she is ineligible or their earnings or AGI is too high, you can consider the child as an eligible child. See examples 6 and 7. But you cannot consider the child as an eligible child to claim the EIC if the other person uses the child to claim any of the other 5 tax-free resources listed earlier in this chapter.
The following examples may help you determine whether you can claim an EIC when you and someone else have the same eligible child.

For more information, see Form 501. If a child is considered to be a qualifying non-custodial parent under this special rule for a child of divorced or separated parents (or parents who do not live together), then only the non-custodial parent can claim a child tax credit or other dependent tax credit for the child. However, only the both guardian parents, if both qualify, or both other qualifying taxpayers can claim the child as a qualifying child for EIC. For details and examples, see Applying the Dissolution Rules to Divorce or Separation Parents (or Parents Who Do Not Live Together) in Form 501.

For more information on the challenges to becoming an eligible child, see Rule 8. If you are an eligible child of another taxpayer, you cannot claim an EIC. This is true even if the person you are the eligible child of does not claim an EIC or meets all the rules to claim an EIC. Enter “No” on the dotted line next to line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR).

You are not the eligible child of another taxpayer (and therefore may be eligible to claim an EIC) if the person with whom you have met the challenges of relationship, age, residency status and general taxation is not required to file an income tax return and: Does not file an income tax return, or Files a return only to be refunded deductible income tax or estimated tax paid.

Use this chapter if you do not have a qualifying child and have met all the rules in chapter 1. This chapter discusses rules 11 to 14. You must meet all four of these rules, in addition to the rules in chapters 1 and 4, to qualify for an EIC without a qualifying child. If you meet all the rules in chapter 1 and this chapter, read chapter 4 to learn what to do next.

If you meet Rule 8, you have a qualifying child. If you meet Rule 8 and do not apply for an EIC with a qualifying child, you can apply for an EIC without a qualifying child. If your child meets the requirements to be a qualifying child, but also meets the requirements to be someone else's qualifying child, only one of you can consider the child as a qualifying child to claim an EIC. If the other person can report the child under the reconciliation rules, you cannot apply for an EIC as a taxpayer with a qualifying child unless you have another qualifying child. However, you can apply for an EIC without a qualifying child.

You must be at least 25 years old but under 65 years old at the end of 2024. It does not matter which spouse meets the age test, as long as either spouse meets it. You meet the age test if you were born after 31 December 1959, and before 2 January 2000. If you and your spouse do not meet the age test, you cannot claim an EIC. Enter "No" on the dotted line of line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR).
If you filed your tax return with your spouse and he or she died in 2024, you would have met the age test if you were at least 25 years old at the time of his or her 25th birthday.

You were married and filed taxes together with your spouse who died in August 2024. You are 67 years old. Your spouse will reach 65 years of age in November 2024. Since your spouse was under 65 years of age at the time of his death, you meet the age test.

A taxpayer who dies in 2024 meets the age test if the taxpayer is at least 25 years old but under 65 years old at the time of death. A taxpayer is considered to be 25 years old on the day before the taxpayer's 25th birthday. However, the rule for reaching 65 years is different; a taxpayer is considered to be 65 years old on the taxpayer's 65th birthday. Even if a taxpayer was born before January 2, 2000, they are not considered to be at least 25 years old at the time of death unless they were at least 25 years old at the time of death.

If you do not file a general tax return, you meet this rule if you do not check the box below your name that says "Someone may declare you a dependent." If you do file a general tax return, you meet this rule if you do not check either of the boxes that say "Someone may declare you a dependent" or "Someone may declare your spouse a dependent." If you are unsure whether someone else may declare you a dependent, see Form 501 and read the rules for declaring dependents. If someone else may declare you a dependent on their tax return, but they do not declare, you still cannot claim a tax credit unless the person who may claim you on their tax return is not required to file income tax and does not file tax or only files tax to claim a refund of deducted income tax or estimated tax paid.

In general, you cannot be declared a dependent by another person if you are married and file jointly. However, another person may declare you a dependent if you and your spouse file jointly only to claim a refund of deductible income tax or estimated tax paid. But neither you nor your spouse can be declared a dependent by another person if you apply for an EIC on your joint tax return.

For more detailed information on the challenges to becoming an eligible child, see Rule 8. If you are an eligible child of another taxpayer, you cannot claim an EIC. This is true even if the person you are the eligible child of does not claim an EIC or meets all the rules to claim an EIC. Enter “No” on the dotted line next to line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR).

In general, you cannot be the eligible child of another taxpayer if you are married and file jointly. However, you can be the eligible child of another taxpayer if you and your spouse file jointly only to claim a refund of deductible income tax or estimated tax paid. But neither you nor your spouse can be the eligible child of another taxpayer if you apply for an EIC on your joint return.

You are not the eligible child of another taxpayer (and therefore may be eligible to claim an EIC) if the person with whom you meet the criteria of relationship, age, residency status and general taxation is not required to file an income tax return and: Does not file an income tax return, or Files a return only to be refunded deductible income tax or estimated tax paid.
Your home (and your spouse's if you file jointly) must have been in the United States for more than half a year. If not, enter "No" on the dotted line next to line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR).

Your home can be any location where you regularly live. You don't have to have a traditional home. If you have lived in one or more temporary shelters for homeless people in the United States for more than six months, you meet this rule.

U.S. soldiers serving outside the United States during extended service (defined in Chapter 2) are considered to be living in the United States during that period of service for the purposes of the EIC.
You must meet one more rule to claim an EIC. You need to know your earnings to see if you meet the rules in this chapter. You also need to know that amount to calculate your EIC.

Your earned income must be less than: $59,899 ($66,819 for jointly filing spouses) if you have three or more eligible children with a valid SSN, $55,768 ($62,688 for jointly filing spouses) if you have two eligible children with a valid SSN, $49,084 ($56,004 for jointly filing spouses) if you have one eligible child with a valid SSN, or $18,591 ($25,511 for jointly filing spouses) if you have no eligible children with a valid SSN.

Earned income generally means salaries, wages, bonuses, other payments to taxable employees and net income from self-employment. Employee payments are only earned income if they are taxable. Non-taxable employee payments, such as certain dependent care benefits and adoption allowances, are not earned income. But there is an exception to non-taxable battle pay that you can choose to include in earned income. Earned income will be explained in detail in Rule 7 in Chapter 1.

If you are a self-employed person, a statutory employee, or a member of the clergy or a church employee filing the Form SE (Form 1040), you will calculate the earned income by using the spreadsheet in Step 5 of the Form 1040 guideline line 27 and filling in Part 4 of the EIC spreadsheet B of the Form 1040 guideline.

If you are a member of the clergy who has filed the Form SE and the amount on line 2 of that table includes the amount also reported on Form 1040 or 1040-SR, line 1z, take the amount on line 1z of Form 1040 or 1040-SR subtract that amount and enter the result on line 1 of the spreadsheet in Step 5 of the Form 1040 instructions line 27.

A church employee means an employee (not a priest or member of a congregation) of a church or eligible organization administered by the church who is exempt from the employer's social security and Medicare taxes. If you receive a salary as a church employee and have included any amount on both line 5a of Schedule SE and Form 1040, line 1a, take the amount on line 1 of Form 1040 or 1040-SR subtract that amount and enter the result on line 1 of the spreadsheet in Step 5 of the Form 1040 instructions, line 27.

When completing the spreadsheet in Step 5 of the Form 1040 instructions, line 27, enter the Medicaid free payments you exclude from your income on Table 1 (Form 1040), line 8s, unless you choose to include this amount in your earned income, in which case enter -0-. For more information on these payments, see Form 525. Your non-taxable Medicaid free payments may have been reported to you on Form W-2, box 12, with Code II. If you and your spouse both received Medicaid free payments in the year, you and your spouse can make different choices about including your entire payments in your earned income. Enter only the Medicaid free payments that you and your spouse, if filing jointly, do not want to include in your earned income. To include all the non-taxable Medicaid free payments in your earned income, enter -0-.
If you choose to use tax-free combat money to calculate your EIC, enter that amount on Form 1040 or 1040-SR, line 1i.

To calculate your EIC yourself, use the EIC Calculator in the Guide to Form 1040. If you have a qualifying child, complete the EIC Calculator (which will be discussed later in this chapter) and attach it to your tax return. If you want the IRS to calculate your EIC, see IRS will calculate your EIC, in the previous section.

You will need to decide whether to use EIC Spreadsheet A or EIC Spreadsheet B to calculate your EIC. This section explains how to use these spreadsheets and how to declare your EIC when you file your tax return.
Use EIC A if you are not self-employed at any time in 2024 and are not a member of the clergy, a church employee filing SE, or a statutory employee filing C.

Use EIC B if you are self-employed at any time in 2024 or a member of the clergy, a church employee filing SE or a statutory employee filing C. If any of the following applies to you, read that section and then complete EIC B.

If your net income from self-employment is $400 or more, make sure you fill in the SE Form (Form 1040) correctly and file the appropriate amount of self-employment tax. If not, you may not receive all the EIC you are entitled to. When calculating your net income from self-employment, you must declare all your permitted business expenses.

Using the optional methods in the SE Table to calculate your net income from self-employment may help you qualify for an EIC or provide you with a larger tax credit. If your net income (without using these optional methods) is below $6,920, see the SE Table Guide for details on the optional methods.

You must complete both Part 1 and Part 2 of the EIC B Form if all of the following conditions apply to you. 1. You are a spouse filing jointly. 2. Both you and your spouse have income from self-employment. 3. You or your spouse file the SE Form and the other does not file the SE Form.

Statutory employees report wages and expenses on Schedule C. They do not file Schedule SE. If you are a statutory employee, enter the amount from Schedule C line 1 in Part 3 when you complete Schedule EIC B.
You must complete an EIC form and attach it to your tax return, including the name, age, SSN, relationship with you and how long they have lived with you during the year.

If your EIC for any year after 1996 is denied (unauthorized) or reduced by the IRS, you may need to complete a supplementary form to claim that tax credit for 2024. This chapter is for those who have an EIC for any year after 1996 that has been denied or reduced by the IRS. If this applies to you, you may need to complete Form 8862, Information to Request a Tax Credit After Unauthorized, and attach it to your 2024 return to claim the tax credit for 2024. This chapter explains when you need to attach Form 8862. For more information, see Form 8862 and separate instructions. This chapter also explains the rules for some people who cannot claim an EIC for a period of years after their EIC has been denied or reduced.

If your EIC for any year after 1996 is denied or reduced for any reason other than a mathematical or typographical error, you must attach the completed Form 8862 to your next tax return to claim the EIC. You must also qualify to claim the EIC by meeting all the rules described in this publication.

Do not file Form 8862 or receive EIC for: 2 years after the final decision that your EIC claim was due to negligence or intentional disregard of the EIC rules, or 10 years after the final decision that your EIC claim was due to fraud.

For more information, see Are you banned from requesting an EIC for a number of years? in this chapter. The date your EIC was denied and the date you file your return in 2024 affect whether you need to attach Form 8862 to your 2024 or later returns. The following examples explain whether Form 8862 is required for 2024 or 2025.

If your EIC is denied or reduced due to math or typing errors, please do not attach Form 8862 to your next tax return. For example: if your arithmetical calculation is incorrect, the IRS can correct it. If you do not provide the correct SSN, the IRS can deny your EIC. These types of errors are called math or typing errors.

If you are asked to attach a completed Form 8862 to your 2024 tax return and you apply for an EIC without attaching a completed Form 8862, your application will be automatically denied. This is considered a mathematical or typing error. You will not be allowed to apply for an EIC without a completed Form 8862.

You may have to provide the IRS with additional documents or information before the EIC-related tax refund you request is transferred to you, even if you have attached a fully completed Form 8862 to your return.

If your EIC for any year after 1996 is denied and it is determined that your fault was due to negligence or intentional disregard of the EIC rules, then you cannot claim an EIC for the next 2 years. If your fault was due to fraud, then you cannot claim an EIC for the next 10 years. The date your EIC was denied and the date you filed your return in 2024 affect the years in which you are prohibited from claiming an EIC. The following examples show the years in which you are prohibited from claiming an EIC.

Jamie Smith is 63 years old and retired. Jamie received $7,000 in social security benefits in the year and $17,000 from a part-time job. Jamie also received a taxable retirement salary of $7,400. Jamie was not married and lived alone in the United States for the whole year.

Cameron and Jordan Grey have two children, 10 and 8 years old. The children live with Cameron and Jordan throughout 2024. Cameron earns $15,000 and Jordan has a salary of $18,030. The Grey family receives $525 in income into their savings account. They have no other income in 2024. Cameron and Jordan have a 2024 Form 1040 and instructions. They want to see if they qualify for the EIC, so they follow the steps for Row 27 in the instructions for the Form 1040.

The amount Cameron and Jordan entered on Form 1040, line 11, was $33,555. Both have a valid SSN, which they have had for many years. They are married and file taxes together. Neither Cameron nor Jordan are a temporary resident. Therefore, their answers to the questions in Step 1 allow them to proceed to Step 2.
The only investment income the Greys had was from their $525 interest, which was no more than $11,600, so they answered "No" to the second question in Step 2 and went on to Step 3.

Their child meets the challenges of relationship, age, residency and joint taxation to be Cameron and Jordan's eligible child, so Cameron and Jordan answer "Yes" to the first question in Step 3. Their child is not anyone else's eligible child. Both children have a valid SSN, which they obtained immediately after birth. Cameron and Jordan are filing jointly, so they answer "Yes" to the second question in Step 3. This means that they can skip questions 3 through 6 and Step 4 and go to Step 5.
Cameron and Jordan calculated their earned income to be $33,030, their total gross salary, which is less than $62,688, so they went to Step 6 to calculate their tax credit.
Cameron and Jordan wanted to calculate their EIC themselves, so they completed the EIC Calculator Sheet following the instructions of the 1040 form.

Cameron and Jordan complete their spreadsheet as follows. 1. Cameron and Jordan enter their total earned income ($33,030) on line 1. 2. To find their tax credit, they access the EIC table. They find that their earned income is $33,030, which is between $33,000 and $33,050. Since both of their children have valid SSNs, they follow this table to the column for the two children below. 4. They search for $33,555 in the EIC table and enter the $6,131 on line 5. 5. They enter the $6,131 on line 6. This is the smaller amount between the $6,247 on line 5 and the $6,131 on line 27 of their Form 1040. Now they will complete the EIC table and attach it to their return. They will keep the EIC table for filing.

If you have questions about tax matters; need assistance with preparing your tax return; or want to download free publications, forms or guides, visit IRS.gov to search for resources that can help you immediately.

After you have received all of your payroll and income statements (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.); unemployment benefit statements (by mail or in digital format) or other government payroll statements (Form 1099-G); and copies of interest, dividends and pension statements from banks and investment companies (Form 1099), you have a number of options for preparing and filing your tax return. You can prepare your tax return yourself. See if you qualify for free tax return preparation or hire a tax expert to prepare your tax return for you.

Taxpayers who need information about the helpline can call 833-690-0598. The Helpline can answer questions about current and future products and support services available through alternative means (phone, email, big print, audio, etc.). The Helpline does not have access to your IRS account. For help with tax law, tax refunds, or account-related issues, visit IRS.gov/LetUsHelp
Visit IRS.gov/DisasterRelief to see available disaster relief.
Visit IRS.gov/Forms to view, download or print all the required forms, instructions and publications. Or you can visit IRS.gov/OrderForms to order them.

You will need an IRS Online Account (OLA) to complete the mobile-friendly forms that require a signature. You will have the option to submit the forms online or download a copy to send by mail. You will need scans of your documents to support the filing. Visit IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms for more information.

Download and view most popular tax publications and guides (including Guide to Form 1040) on mobile devices as eBooks at IRS.gov/eBooks. The IRS eBook has been tested using Apple's iBooks for iPad. Our eBook has not been tested on other specialized eBooks, and the eBook functionality may not work as intended.

Visit IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. View the amount you owe and break it down by tax year. View payment plan details or sign up for a new payment plan. Make payments or view your 5-year payment history and any pending or scheduled payments. Access your tax file, including the core data from your most recent tax return, and records. View digital copies of IRS screening notifications. Approve or reject proxy requests from tax professionals. View your address in the file or manage your favorite methods of contact.

With an online account, you can access a variety of information to help you through the tax season. You can take a record, view your most recently filed tax return and receive your total adjusted income. Create or access your online account at IRS.gov/Account.
This function allows your hired professional to send a proxy request to the IRS OLA of an individual taxpayer. For more information, visit IRS.gov/TaxProAccount.
The safest and easiest way to receive your refund is to e-file and choose a direct deposit, which will transfer your refund directly to your financial account in a secure and electronic way.

Your choices to prepare and file your tax return online or file it at your local community, if you qualify, include the following. Direct File. Direct File is a standard option for filing your federal personal income tax return online—free—directly and securely with the IRS. Direct File is an option for taxpayers in participating states who have a relatively simple tax return to declare certain types of income and claim certain tax credits and deductions. Although Direct File does not prepare state returns, if you live in a participating state, Direct File will guide you to a state-supported tool that you can use to prepare and file your state tax return for free. Visit IRS.gov/DirectFile for more information, program updates and FAQs. Free File. This program allows you to prepare and file your federal personal income tax return for free using software or the Free File self-complete form. However, state tax returns may not be available through Free File. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile to see if you qualify for the free federal online tax return options, electronic tax return and direct deposit or payment. VITA. The Voluntary Income Tax Assistance Program (VITA) provides free tax assistance for low- to medium-income, disabled and English-speaking taxpayers who need help preparing their own tax returns. Visit IRS.gov/VITA, download the free IRS2Go app or call 800-906-9887 for information on how to file.

The IRS does not proactively contact taxpayers via email, phone calls, text messages (including short links) or social media channels to request the provision or verification of personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords or similar information for credit cards, bank or other financial accounts. Visit IRS.gov/IdentityTheft, the IRS's web page on Identity Theft Center, for information on identity theft and data security for taxpayers, tax practitioners and businesses. If you lose or steal your social security number or you suspect you are a victim of tax-related spoofing, you can learn what steps you should take. Get an Identity Protecting PIN (IP PIN). An IP PIN is a six-digit number given to taxpayers to help prevent the misuse of their SSN in federal income tax fraud. When you have an IP PIN, it will prevent others from filing their tax returns with your SSN. For more information, visit IRS.gov/IPPIN.

The IRS is unable to issue refunds before mid-February for returns that claim an EIC or an Additional Child Tax Credit (ACTC). This applies to the entire amount of the refund, not just the portion related to these tax credits.

U.S. tax payments must be filed with the IRS in U.S. dollars. Electronic assets are not accepted. Visit IRS.gov/Payments for information on how to make payments using any of the following options. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax amount directly from your account using a voucher or savings account free of charge for you. Debit card, credit card, or e-wallet: Choose an approved payment processor to pay online or over the phone. Electronic Bank Transfer: Schedule payments when filing federal taxes using tax filing software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System: Best choice for businesses. Registration is required. Check or money order: Mail your means of payment to the address listed in the notice or instructions. Cash: You can pay taxes in cash at a participating retail store. In-day transfer: You can make transfers within the same day from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution for availability, cost, and timeframe.

Visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn more about your options. Sign up for an online payment agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to meet your tax obligations by paying monthly instalments if you are unable to pay your taxes in full today. After completing the online process, you will receive immediate notification of whether your agreement has been approved or not. Use the Settlement Offer Assessment Tool to see if you can settle your tax debt for less than the total amount you owe. For more information about the Settlement Offer program, please visit IRS.gov/OIC.

Visit IRS.gov/WMAR to track the status of your amended Form 1040-X. It may take up to three weeks from the date you filed your amended return for this information to appear on our system, and processing time can be up to 16 weeks.
Visit IRS.gov/Notices for more information on responding to an IRS notice or letter.
Please note that many questions can be answered on the IRS.gov website without the need for a TAC. Visit IRS.gov/LetUsHelp to see the most frequently asked questions.

The Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS. The TAS helps taxpayers resolve problems with the IRS, makes administrative and legislative recommendations to prevent or remedy problems, and protects taxpayer rights. We strive to ensure that all taxpayers are treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We are your voice at the IRS.

TAS can help you solve problems that you cannot solve with the IRS yourself. Always try to solve your problem with the IRS first, but if you cannot, come to TAS. Our services are free. TAS assists all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, businesses and tax-exempt organizations. You may be eligible for TAS assistance if your IRS issue is causing you financial difficulties, if you have tried and are unable to solve your issue with the IRS, or if you believe that the IRS system, processes or procedures are not working as expected. For assistance at any time on general taxation topics, please visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov.

The Bill of Rights of the Taxpayer describes the ten basic rights that all taxpayers have when dealing with the IRS. Visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/Taxpayer-Rights to learn more about the rights, what they mean to you and how they apply to the specific situations that you may encounter with the IRS. The TAS strives to protect the rights of the taxpayer and ensure that the IRS is administering tax law in a fair and equitable manner.

Although the taxpayer always signs the return, you are ultimately responsible for providing all the information necessary for the taxpayer to prepare your return correctly and to ensure that all items declared on the return are correct. Anyone who is paid to file a tax return for another person must have a thorough understanding of tax matters. For more information on choosing a taxpayer, see Choosing a taxpayer on IRS.gov.

The Department of Social Security (SSA) provides online services at SSA.gov/employer with fast, free and secure W-2 filing options for CPA, accountants, registered agents and those who process Form W-2, Payroll and Tax Report, and Form W-2c, Revised Payroll and Tax Report.

If you are a sole proprietorship, partnership, or S-corp, you can see your tax information stored in the IRS files and do more with a corporate tax account. Visit IRS.gov/BusinessAccount for more information.

Visit IRS.gov/SocialMedia to see the various social media tools that the IRS uses to share the latest information about tax changes, fraud warnings, initiatives, products and services. At the IRS, privacy and security are our top priorities. We use these tools to share publicly available information with you. Please do not post your Social Security Number (SSN) or other private information on social media sites. Always protect your identity when using any social media site. The following IRS YouTube channels have short informative videos on various tax-related topics in English, Spanish and ASL. Youtube.com/irsvideos (English). Youtube.com/irsvideosmultilingua (English). Youtube.com/irsvideosASL (English).

The IRS is committed to serving taxpayers with limited English proficiency (LEP) by providing OPI services. OPI services are a federally funded program and are provided at Taxpayer Assistance Centers (TACs), most IRS offices, and all VITA/TCE tax filing locations. OPI services are accessible in over 350 languages.

Intermediate Service Provider. A checkbox has been added to line 5a on Model 2848: Power of Attorney and Declaration of the Representative, to allow the taxpayer to authorize the designated representative(s) to access the taxpayer's IRS file through the Intermediate Service Provider. For more information, see Electronic Access to IRS Files through the Intermediate Service Provider in the Guide to Model 2848. Representatives of a Joint Venture. For joint venture tax years beginning after December 31, 2017, the 2015 Bipartisan Accounting Act has removed the role of "Member Responsible for Tax Issues" and replaced it with "Representative of Joint Venture". For more information, see Representative of Joint Venture in the Guide to Model 2848. Appointment of Representative. The designation of the representative is a Law Student or CPA has been changed to a Qualified Student. Only the same person can call the IRS on your behalf. Warning: When the representative has the Power of Attorney, they must go through the same verification procedures before the IRS can talk to them about your tax information.

Practitioner Priority Service® (PPS). The Practitioner Priority Service is a free, nationwide hotline that provides professional assistance to taxpayers with questions regarding their accounts. The toll-free number for this service is 1-866-860-4259. The Annual Filing Season Program (AFSP) and the Federal Taxpayer List. The Annual Filing Season Program is a voluntary program that allows limited professional rights to taxpayers who are not lawyers, certified accountants, or registered representatives. The IRS issues the Annual Filing Season Program Completion Certificate to taxpayers who have received a certain number of regular educational hours to prepare for a particular tax year. Participants in the Annual Filing Season Program do not have the right to practice unlimitedly (unless they are also lawyers, certified accountants, or registered representatives). Their rights are limited to representing clients with returns that they prepare and sign, but only before tax officials, customer service representatives, and similar IRS staff, including the Taxpayer Representation Service. They cannot represent clients whose returns they do not prepare and sign, nor can they represent clients before collection or appeal functions. See IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Annual-Filing-Season-Program for more information about the AFSP. See IRS.Treasury.gov/rpo for an online searchable database of taxpayers with PTINs who have professional rights.

This publication discusses who can represent a taxpayer before the IRS and what forms or documents are used to authorize a representative for a taxpayer. Typically, lawyers, certified public accountants (CPA) and registered representatives can represent a taxpayer before the IRS. Registered pension program representatives and registered statisticians can represent specific sections of the Tax Service Act as described in Regulation 230. In special and limited cases, other individuals, including unregistered taxpayers, family members, employees and students can represent a taxpayer before the IRS. For details on taxpayer representatives, see Who Can Act Before the IRS?, in the section below.
Many of the terms used in this publication, such as "registered representative" and "practitioner", are defined in the Terminology at the end of this publication.

We welcome your comments on this publication and your suggestions for future publications. You can send us your comments at: Internal Revenue Service Tax Forms and Publications 1111 Constitution Ave. NW, IR-6526 Washington, DC 20224.

Visit IRS.gov/FormsPubs to download forms and publications. Alternatively, you can visit IRS.gov/OrderForms to order current and previous year forms and instructions. Your order will arrive within 10 working days.
If you have any tax questions not answered in this publication, please check out IRS.gov and How to Get Tax Assistance at the end of this publication.

Any individual may also be paid to prepare or assist in the preparation of a tax return or tax refund claim, appear as a witness for a taxpayer before the IRS, or provide information at the request of the IRS or any IRS official or employee.

The following individuals must comply with the provisions of Regulation 230. However, any individual who is authorized to practice in general (a recognized representative) must be appointed as the taxpayer's representative and file a written declaration with the IRS stating that they are authorized and qualified to represent a particular taxpayer. Form 2848 may be used for this purpose.

Any individual who prepares a valuation to assist in the valuation of property involving one or more federal tax matters must comply with the provisions of Circular 230. The valuationist has no power of representation but may appear as a witness on behalf of the taxpayer.

Because of their special relationship with the taxpayer, the following individuals may represent the taxpayer specified before the IRS, provided they provide valid identification and, except for an individual described in section (1) below, proof of authority to represent the taxpayer. 1. An individual. An individual may represent himself or herself before the IRS and is not required to file a written declaration of qualification and authority. 2. A family member. An individual may represent members of his or her immediate family. An immediate family includes the person's spouse, children, parents, brothers/sisters. 3. An official. A good-faith official of a corporation (including a parent company, subsidiary or other affiliated company), association or organized group may represent a corporation, association or organized group. An official of a unit, government agency or authority, in the course of his or her official duties, may represent the unit, government agency or authority before the IRS. 4. A joint venture member. A common member of a joint venture may represent the joint venture before the IRS. 5. An employee. A full-time employee may represent his or her employer. An employee may be, but is not limited to, an individual, joint venture, corporation (including a parent company, subsidiary or other affiliated company), association, trust, litigation trust, trusteeship, inheritance, organized group, government unit, agency or authority. 6. A mandatary. A mandate recipient (the mandated person, executor, personal representative, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee, trustee,

The Tax Commissioner, or the person to whom the power of attorney is vested, may authorize an individual who is not qualified to practice before the IRS to represent another person on a specific matter. The prospective representative must request this power of attorney in writing from the Office of Special Responsibility. However, the power of attorney is only granted in extremely compelling circumstances. If approved, the Commissioner, or the person to whom the power of attorney is vested, will issue a letter detailing the conditions relating to the representation and the specific tax matter(s) for which the power of attorney is vested. A power of attorney letter should not be confused with a letter from an IRS center informing an individual that they have been assigned a Central Authorization Number (CAF). The CAF number does not indicate that an individual is recognized or allowed to practice before the IRS. It merely confirms that a central file for the power of attorney has been set up for the individual under that number.

A student working at the Low Income Taxpayer Center (LITC) or the Student Tax Center Program (STCP) must be authorized to represent a taxpayer before the IRS as a law, business, or accounting student. The request for a power of attorney must be sent to the Taxpayer Representation Service. If approved, a letter of special student representation power of attorney, detailing any conditions related to the representation, will be issued. A student who receives a power of attorney letter may generally represent a taxpayer before any IRS function or office depending on any of the terms in the power of attorney letter and must be under the direct supervision of an individual authorized to practice before the IRS. If you intend to have a student represent you, review the power of attorney letter and ask your student, student supervisor, or Taxpayer Representation Service if you have any questions about the terms of the power of attorney.
Any registered representative in an operating state who is not currently suspended or banned from operating before the IRS may practise before the IRS.

Any registered pension program representative who is not currently suspended or prohibited from operating with the IRS may practice before the IRS. The activities of registered pension program representatives are restricted by certain parts of the Tax Service Act that relate to their field of expertise, primarily those parts that regulate employee pension programs.

Any individual who is registered as a statistician by the United States Board of Registry Statisticians and is not currently suspended or prohibited from practising the profession before the IRS may practise before the IRS. The activities of registered statisticians are restricted by certain parts of the Tax Service Act relating to their field of expertise, primarily those parts that regulate the retirement of employees.

In certain cases, a student supervised by a practitioner at a law school or equivalent program providing tax services to low-income taxpayers may request a power of attorney to represent the taxpayer before the IRS. For more information, see Special Power of Attorney, in the section on the IRS.

An unregistered taxpayer is an individual who is not a lawyer, CPA, registered representative, registered pension program representative or registered statistician who prepares and signs a taxpayer's return as a paid taxpayer, or who prepares a taxpayer's return but is not required (by form guidelines or regulations) to sign the return. An unregistered taxpayer may only represent a taxpayer before tax officials, customer service representatives or similar officials and staff of the Department of Taxation (including the Taxpayer Representation Service) and only when reviewing tax returns that they have prepared and signed before December 31, 20152015. An unregistered taxpayer may not represent a taxpayer before appeals officials, tax collectors, lawyers or similar officials or staff of the Department of Taxation or the Department of Finance. An unregistered taxpayer may not enter into settlement agreements, extend statutory time limits for tax assessment or collection, make waivers or sign any documents on behalf of a taxpayer. If an unregistered taxpayer does not meet the requirements for limited representation, you may delegate the power to this unregistered taxpayer to review and/or request your tax information by filing Form 8821. Completing Form 8821 does not authorize the unregistered taxpayer to represent you before the IRS. For more information, see Form 8821 and separate guidelines. Certificate of Completion of Annual Tax Season Program. Only unregistered taxpayers have a valid PTIN and have completed filing for ALL tax return years (2015 or 2016).

In general, individuals who are ineligible, or who have lost their privileges due to certain actions, cannot practise before the IRS. If an individual is ineligible to practise, the IRS will not recognize a power of attorney in the name of that individual as a representative.

In general, individuals lose their license to practice before the IRS in the following ways. Failure to meet the requirements for renewal of registration (such as regular professional education). Application as a registered representative to be placed in inactive retirement. Suspension or disqualification from the Office of Professional Responsibility or determination of inappropriateness for the practice of the profession due to violation of the provisions of the Regulation 230 or the standards of the Tax Service Procedure 81-38. Loss of the license to practice as a certified lawyer or accountant, regardless of the grounds for the revocation of the license.

Individuals who have registered and who have a Certificate of Completion AFSP that does not meet the eligibility requirements for renewal will be notified by the IRS. The notification will explain the reasons for the ineligibility and provide the individual with a timely opportunity to provide information for reconsideration.

Individuals who have registered a request to be placed in inactive retirement status will not be eligible to practice before the IRS. They must continue to comply with all extension requests. They may be restored to active registration status by filing an extension request and providing proof that they have completed the hours of regular professional education required for the registration cycle.

All individuals practising before the IRS are subject to disciplinary proceedings and may be suspended, disqualified, or fined for violating any of the provisions of Regulation 230. This includes engaging in conduct that shows incapacity or is reprehensible. For more information, see What is Insufficient Competence and Responsible Conduct under the Code of Professional Conduct, in the following section. Practitioners who are suspended or disqualified in a disciplinary proceeding are not allowed to represent taxpayers before the IRS during the period of suspension/disqualification. A practitioner may request the Office of Professional Responsibility to reinstate him/her before a specific period of suspension or after 5 years of suspension. See What is Responsible Conduct before the IRS, in the previous section. If a practitioner seeks to reinstate himself/herself, he/she is not allowed to practise before the IRS until the Office of Professional Responsibility grants permission for reinstatement. The Office of Professional Responsibility may grant the practitioner's reinstatement: if the future conduct of the practitioner is not likely to violate the regulations, and if the grant of reinstatement is not contrary to the public interest. Depending on other conditions within a reasonable period of time.

The IRS website IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Enrolled-Agents/Become-an-Enrolled-Agent provides complete information on the steps to become a registered agent. For rules on receiving the Certificate of Completion of the Annual-Filing-Season-Program, see IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/General-Requirements-for-the-Annual-Filing-Season-Program-Record-of-Completion.

The rules governing the conduct of the profession before the IRS are published in the United States Code at 31 C.F.R. Subsection A, Part 10 and are issued electronically as Circular 230 (Circular 230) by the Department of the Treasury. The regulations can be accessed at IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Circular-230-Tax-Professionals. Lawyers, CPA's, registered representatives, registered pension program representatives, or registered statisticians who have been authorized to practise before the IRS (abbreviated as practitioners) and property valuation professionals are required to perform certain acts and are restricted from performing other acts. In addition, a practitioner is prohibited from performing reprehensible acts (discussed in the following section). Any practitioner who fails to comply with the rules of conduct or performs incompetent or reprehensible acts is subject to disciplinary action. In addition, unregistered taxpayers must comply with the rules of conduct and conduct to exercise the restricted prerogatives of practice before the IRS. There are two specific sets of rules that apply, both contained in Circular 230: 1. Duties and restrictions relating to the conduct of the profession (Subsection B of Circular 230), and 2. Conduct that is deemed incompetent or reprehensible (Subsection C, Section 10.51 of Circular 230).

Individuals complying with the 230 Rule must promptly provide records or information that is appropriately and lawfully requested from IRS officials or employees, unless the practitioner reasonably and in good faith believes that the information is confidential. Communications related to tax advice between a federally authorized tax practitioner (see IRC section 7525) and a taxpayer are generally protected to the same degree as communications would be confidential between a taxpayer and a lawyer if the advice related to: Non-criminal tax matters before the IRS, or Non-criminal tax litigation, brought before a federal court by or against the United States.

This protection for the exchange of tax advice does not apply to any written exchange between a federally authorized tax practitioner and any person, including a director, shareholder, officer, employee, agent or representative of a company, if the exchange is related to encouraging the direct or indirect participation of the company in any form of tax avoidance.

An individual complying with Instruction 230 who becomes aware that his or her client is not complying with the tax law or has an error or omission in any of the returns, documents, affidavits or other required documents, is responsible for advising the client immediately about the non-compliance, error or omission and the consequences of such non-compliance, error or omission.

Individuals subject to Directive 230 are responsible for the following duties: Preparing or assisting in the preparation, approval, and filing of tax returns, documents, affidavits, and other documents relating to IRS matters; Determining the accuracy of oral or written statements made by that person to the Department of Finance; Determining the accuracy of oral or written statements made by that person to clients relating to any matter administered by the IRS.

The assumption that a choice of authority has been made will apply in cases where there is confidence in the product of another's work if the involvement, supervision, training and evaluation of that person is carried out in a careful manner appropriate to the nature of the relationship between the Instruction 230 and that person.

Individuals complying with the 230 Directive shall not intentionally, directly or indirectly, do any of the following: Accept assistance from, or assist in, anyone who is disqualified or suspended from the IRS if the assistance relates to matters considered to be the practice of the IRS. Accept assistance from any former government employee if the provisions of the 230 Directive or any federal law are violated.

Individuals complying with Instruction 230 are not permitted to admit, swear, certify documents or perform any official act in their capacity as notaries in connection with any matter administered by the IRS and in matters in which such individuals are hired as advisors, lawyers or representatives, or in matters in which such individuals may be interested in any way.

A person complying with Circular 230 shall not post or cash any cheque (including directing or accepting payment in any form, electronically or otherwise, to an account owned or controlled by the trader or any other company or organization to which the trader is associated) issued by the government to a customer in connection with federal tax liability.

Individuals complying with Regulation 230 may be disqualified or suspended from practising before the IRS, or be held responsible, for reprehensible or incompetent conduct. In addition to any other form of disciplinary action, penalties may also be applied to both the individual and their company. The following list includes examples of conduct considered reprehensible. Other examples are listed in Regulation 230, Section 10.51(a). Conviction of any criminal offence under the tax law or any offence related to dishonesty or breach of trust. Intentionally providing false or misleading information relating to federal tax matters or engaging in such activities. Attracting employment by prohibited means as discussed in Section 10.30 of Regulation 230. Failure to file federal tax returns, evade or attempt to evade any federal tax or payment, or engaging in such actions. Misappropriating or failing to transfer correctly and timely money received from clients to pay taxes or U.S. debts. Directly or indirectly attempting to influence official actions of IRS employees by using threats, false accusations, coercion, favors or any special lures. Disqualification or suspension from the practice of law, CPA, public accountant, or statistician, by the District of Columbia or any state, territory, Commonwealth, or federal court, or any federal agency, unit, or board of directors. Attempt to assist and assist another person in practising before the IRS during the period of such suspension, suspension or disqualification.

The Chief of the Treasury, or his or her delegate, may, after notice and opportunity to do so, reprimand, suspend, or disqualify an individual from complying with Regulation 230 in the conduct of his or her profession before the IRS if that individual is deemed to be incompetent or to have conducted himself or herself in a reprehensible manner, to have failed to comply with the provisions of Subpart B; or to have intentionally deceived, deliberately and intentionally deceived, or threatened a client or prospective client. Reproach is a publicly punishable act. Individuals who comply with Regulation 230 include any lawyer, certified accountant, registered representative, registered pension program representative, or registered statistician who engages in taxpayer representation or advice, as well as any person who has an Annual Tax Season Program Completion Certificate representing a taxpayer, and any auditor who engages in the valuation of property for federal tax purposes.

A proxy is a written authorization from you for an individual to receive your confidential tax information from the IRS and to perform certain actions on your behalf. If the proxy is not limited, the individual may generally perform all actions that you may perform, except for agreements or cheque notarization. The authorization is granted to registered pension program representatives, registered statisticians, and unregistered taxpayers with a completed certificate. For information on limitations related to certified persons completing the annual tax season program, see Tax Service Procedures 2014-42 and IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Return-Preparer-Office-RPO-At-a-Glance.

Attorneys, certified accountants and registered representatives may perform the following acts: 1. Represent you before any IRS office or employee. 2. Sign a proposal or waiver limiting the taxation or collection of missing taxes, or a waiver notice not allowing the claim of tax credits or refunds. 3. Sign an agreement extending the statutory period for taxation or collection. 4. Sign an agreement terminating the taxation or collection of taxes.
When the form is signed by a representative, a power of attorney (or a copy) must be attached to authorize the representative to sign the form. For more information, see the Guide to Form 2848.

A recognized representative may replace or delegate by proxy to another recognized representative only if you have specifically authorized that action on the proxy. After the replacement is performed, only the newly recognized representative is recognized as the taxpayer's representative. If a proxy has been performed, both the original representative and the delegated representative will be recognized by the IRS as your representative.

Your representative cannot make arrangements to allow the IRS to disclose tax return information or tax returns to a third party unless you specifically delegate this authority to your representative on line 5a of Form 2848.

The power of attorney is usually terminated if you become incapacitated or incompetent. However, the power of attorney may continue in the event that you become incapacitated or incompetent if you authorize this on line 5a “Other acts authorized” on Form 2848 and if the long-term power of attorney not provided by the IRS meets all the requirements for acceptance by the IRS. See Power of Attorney Not Using the IRS Form, in the section below.

File a power of attorney when you want to authorize an individual to receive your confidential tax information and represent you with the IRS, whether or not the agent performs any of the other actions listed in What is a Power of Attorney. A power of attorney is usually required when you want to authorize another individual to perform at least one of the following actions on your behalf: 1. Represent you at a meeting with the IRS 2. Prepare and send a written response to the IRS only once per year.

Use the IRS Form 2848 to appoint a representative to represent you before the IRS. The individuals who are recognized as your representatives before the IRS are listed in Part II, Declaration of Representative, of the IRS Form 2848. Your representative must complete that part of the form.

You must also attach a signed and dated statement by your representative. This statement, called the Declaration of the Representative, is included in Part II of Form 2848. The statement should include: 1. I am not currently suspended or disqualified from my profession before the IRS or from any other agency, 2.

The IRS will not accept a non-IRS model power of attorney if it does not contain all the information listed above. You can sign and submit a completed Form 2848 or a new non-IRS model power of attorney containing all the information. If you cannot sign an acceptable replacement document, your authorized attorney may complete (for IRS acceptance) your non-IRS model power of attorney by using the procedure described below.
Subject to the following conditions, the authorized lawyer named in your non-IRS power of attorney may sign the Form 2848 on your behalf. 1.

The IRS has a centralized computer database system called the CAF system. This system contains information about the authority of the taxpayer's representative. Generally, when you submit a proxy document to the IRS, that document will be processed for entry into the CAF system. Entering your proxy into the CAF system allows IRS employees, who do not have a copy of your proxy, to verify the authority of your representative by accessing the CAF. It also allows the IRS to automatically send copies of IRS notices and other correspondence to your representative if you indicate that your representative will receive correspondence from that contact. You can have your non-standard IRS proxy entered into the CAF system by attaching it to the completed Form 2848 and filing it with the IRS. Your signature is not required; however, in practice, your proxy attorney will sign the Dec-laration of Representative (see Part II of the Form 2848).

The IRS will accept a copy of the power of attorney sent by fax. If you choose to file the power of attorney by fax, please make sure that the appropriate IRS office is equipped to accept this form of submission.

Send any updates or amendments to the existing power of attorney in writing. Your signature (or the signature of the person(s) authorized to sign on your behalf) is required. Do this by sending an updated Form 2848 or non-IRS power of attorney to the IRS office(s) where you previously submitted the original(s), including the service center where the relevant tax return was or will be submitted. The accredited representative may substitute or delegate if you specifically authorize your representative to substitute or delegate in the original power of attorney. To substitute or delegate, the representative must file the following items to the IRS office(s) where the power of attorney was filed. 1. A document noting the substitution or delegation signed by the accredited representative. 2. A written statement of the representative made by the new representative. 3. A copy of the power of attorney authorizing the substitution or delegation.

A new power of attorney filed for the same matter will revoke the previous power of attorney if it states specifically that it does not revoke the previous power of attorney and one of the following documents is attached to the new power of attorney.

If you want to revoke the previously enforced power of attorney and do not want to name the new one, you must write “REVOKE” on the first page of the Form 2848 with your current signature and date immediately below this note. Then, you must send a copy of the power of attorney with the cancellation note to the IRS, using the Where To File Chart in the Form 2848 Guide, or if the power of attorney is for a specific issue, send it to the IRS office that handles the issue. If you want to revoke the power of attorney altogether, write “remove all years/periods” instead of listing the specific issues and years/periods.

If your representative wishes to withdraw his/her power of attorney, he/she must write "WITHDRAW" on the first header of Form 2848 with his/her current signature and date immediately below the note. Then, he/she must provide a copy of the power of attorney with a cancellation note to the IRS in the same manner as described in the Cancellation by Taxpayer section above. If your representative does not have a copy of the power of attorney that he/she wishes to cancel, he/she must send the IRS a cancellation statement stating that the power of attorney has been cancelled, listing the issues and year/period, and listing the name, TIN number and address (if known) of the taxpayer. The representative must sign and date this statement. The student power of attorney will be stored on the CAF system for 130 days from the date of receipt of the file. If you authorize a student to represent you after that time, you will need to submit a new updated Form 2848.

For the tax years beginning after 31 December 2017, the Bipartisan Accounting Act 2015, abolishing the TEFRA review and litigation process as well as the rules for the election of large joint ventures and replacing it with a “joint venture representative”, pursuant to the Ministry of Finance Regulation 301.9100-22T, certain joint ventures may elect to apply the new regime for joint venture returns for the tax years beginning after 2 November 2015 and before 1 January 2018.

The proxy will be recognized after the IRS has received, reviewed and determined that the requested information has been provided. However, until a proxy is entered into the CAF system, the IRS staff may not be aware of the authority of the person you have named to represent you. Therefore, during this interim period, the IRS staff may ask you or your representative to bring a copy to any meeting with the IRS.
How the power of attorney is processed depends on whether or not the document has been completed.

If Form 2848 is not complete, the IRS will attempt to obtain the missing information by writing to or calling you or your representative. For example, if your signature or date is missing, the IRS will contact you. If information relating to your representative is missing and there is sufficient contact information (such as an address and/or telephone number) in the document, the IRS will attempt to contact your representative. In either case, the power of attorney is not considered valid until all required information is entered in that document. The individual(s) named as representative(s) will not be recognized as practising before the IRS, on your behalf, until the document is complete and accepted by the IRS.

If the proxy is complete and valid, the IRS will take action to recognize the representative. In most cases, this includes processing the document on the CAF system. Recording the data on the CAF system allows the IRS to forward copies of the letter to the authorized representatives and easily identify the scope of the powers granted.

Power of attorneys for specific purposes are not processed in the CAF system (see Standard Forms — Useful Hints, previously). For example, power of attorneys for one-time or specific purposes are not processed in the CAF system. These documents are still stored with the relevant case files. In this case, you should check the box on line 4 of Form 2848. In these situations, the representative should bring a copy of the power of attorney to each meeting with the IRS.

After a valid proxy has been filed, the IRS will recognize your representative. However, if it appears that the representative is unreasonably delaying or impeding the expeditious resolution of an IRS issue by failing to provide mandatory information after repeated requests, the IRS may contact you directly. For example, in most cases where a proxy is recognized, the IRS will contact the representative to set appointments and provide the representative with a list of required items. However, if the representative is not present, does not respond to repeated requests and fails to provide mandatory items (other than those considered privileges), the IRS may ignore your representative and contact you directly. If the representative has conducted as described above, the matter may be referred to the Office of Special Responsibility to consider possible disciplinary action.

If you want to authorize your representative to receive copies of all notices and communications sent to you by the IRS, you must check the box provided below the name and address of the representative. No more than two representatives may receive copies of notices and communications sent to you by the IRS. Please leave this box unchecked if you do not want copies of notices and communications sent to your representative(s).

If you have questions about tax matters, need assistance preparing your tax return, or want to download free publications, forms or guides, visit IRS.gov and find resources that can help you immediately.

The IRS uses the latest encryption technology to ensure that your electronic payments are secure and secure. You can make electronic payments online, via phone, and from your mobile device with the IRS2Go app. Electronic payments are quick, easy, and faster than sending checks or money orders. Visit IRS.gov/Payments to make payments with any of the following options. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax amounts directly from your check or savings account without charge. Debit or credit card: Choose an approved payment tool for online payment, via phone and mobile device. Electronic Banking Transfer: Provided only when filing your federal tax with our tax software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System: Best choice for businesses. Registration is required. Check or money order: Send your payment to the address in the notice or instructions. Cash: You can pay your tax in cash at a participating retail store.

Visit IRS.gov/WMAR to track the status of your adjusted 1040X. Please note that it may take up to 3 weeks from the date you send your adjusted tax return by post for it to appear in our system and it may take up to 16 weeks for it to be processed.
Visit IRS.gov/Notices for more information on responding to IRS letters or notices.

Please note that many questions can be answered on IRS.gov without going to the Taxpayer Assistance Center (TAC). Visit IRS.gov/LetUsHelp for the topics that people ask the most. If you still need help, the IRS TAC will provide assistance when a tax issue cannot be handled online or over the phone. All TACs currently offer appointment services so you will know ahead of time that you can get the service you need without having to wait. Before you visit, visit IRS.gov/TACLocator to find the nearest TAC location, check the opening hours, available services and booking options. Or, on the IRS2Go app, in the Stay Connected tab, select the Contact Us option and click on “Local Offices”.
The IRS's video portal (IRSvideos.gov) has video and audio presentations for individuals, small businesses and tax professionals to view and share.

The Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS that assists taxpayers and defends taxpayer interests. Our job is to ensure that all taxpayers are treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights.

The Taxpayer's Bill of Rights describes the 10 basic rights that all taxpayers have when dealing with the IRS. Our Taxpayer Advocate at TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov can help you understand what these rights mean to you and how they apply. These are your rights. Know them. Use them.

The Low Income Tax Center (LITC) is independent of the IRS. LITC represents individuals with incomes below a certain level and needs to resolve tax issues with the IRS, such as tax review, appeals, and disputes. In addition, the centers can provide information about taxpayer rights and responsibilities in various languages for individuals who speak English as a second language. Services are provided free of charge or for a small fee. To find a center near you, visit TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/LITCmap or see IRS Issue 4134: Low Income Tax Center Directory.

Visit IRS.gov/Forms to view, download or print all the forms and publications you may need. You can also download and view popular tax publications and guides (including the 1040 guide) on your mobile device as free e-books. Or, you can visit IRS.gov/OrderForms to order and receive the forms within 10 working days.

Visit IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. View the amount you owe, pay online or set up an online payment arrangement. Access your tax files online. Review your payment history for the past 18 months. Visit IRS.gov/SecureAccess to review the required authentication process.

The fastest way to receive your tax refund is to combine the use of a direct deposit with an electronic tax return from the IRS. A direct deposit is a secure way to transfer your tax refund directly to your bank account. Eight out of 10 taxpayers use the direct deposit form to receive their tax refund. The IRS issues more than 90% of their tax refunds within 21 days.

Due to changes in the law, the IRS cannot issue refunds before mid-February 2018, for tax returns that validly claim an Earned Income Tax Credit (EIC) or an Additional Child Tax Credit (ACTC).This applies to the entire refund, not only the portion related to these types of tax credits.

The fastest way to get your tax transcript is to visit IRS.gov/Transcripts. Click on “Get Transcript Online” or “Get Transcript By Post” to request a transcript of yours. If you prefer, you can: Request your transcript by calling 1-800-908-9946. Send it by post on Form 4506-T or Form 4506T-EZ (both available on IRS.gov).

Access IRS.gov/Tools for the following tools. The Import Income Tax Credit (EITC) (IRS.gov/EIC) determines whether you qualify for an EIC. The Online EIN Application (IRS.gov/EIN) helps you get your employer's tax number. The IRS Retention Deduction Calculator (IRS.gov/W4App) estimates the amount you must deduct from your paycheck for federal income tax purposes. The First Time Home Buyer Tax Credit Check (IRS.gov/HomeBuyer) tool provides information on your refund and account balance. The Sales Tax Deduction Calculator (IRS.gov/SalesTax) calculates the amount you can claim if you deduct each item on Schedule A (Form 1040), choose not to claim state and local income tax, and have not filed your receipts showing the sales tax you paid.

The IRS does not contact taxpayers via telex to request personal or financial information. This includes any form of electronic communication, such as text messages and social media channels. Visit IRS.gov/IDProtection for information and video. If your SSN has been lost or stolen or you suspect you have been a victim of tax-related identity theft, visit IRS.gov/ID to learn what steps you should take.
